Home Mush Mush Advice Ask the SDF! #2
This thread contains Announcement(s) from community representatives :
[On 27 July 2014] Hello mushlings, and welcome to the second it[...]
On july 27, 2014
[6826491]

Hello mushlings, and welcome to the second iteration of this thread! This post and thread should help clarify what is reportable/sanctionable or not. If you have any questions regarding the rules or which behaviour you could report, please, ask here.

If you have a question regarding a sanction you've received or wish to speak to us personally, send us a message. Do not post a forum thread to ask about a sanction. The thread will be deleted, and repeatedly posting to get attention will lead to your posting privileges being removed for a while.

Rules of English Mush


When reporting rule breaking on your ships, please, you must type in a reason for the report! If you leave it blank, the judges have to pick through the whole ship's logs to find out what went on.

In addition, do not just type, "Griefer". More information will only help us. More details (specific days/cycles of incidents, as well as locations) are useful, because they give us starting points to work from, and that can only help our investigations. They can also help prove the innocence of an accused player, if they weren't responsible for the rule breaking for which they're accused.


Anonymity
Many find anonymity to be one the best features of this game and choose to keep anonymity at all times. There is no Twinoid fame in Mush, no long time member hero worship and you are free to role play the character you've chosen without anyone knowing who you really are. Because most of us do want to keep our anonymity and not know the identity of others on our ships, we strongly suggest everyone preserve anonymity because it's more enjoyable to play that way.


Spreadsheets, other tools, and external communication
We won't be sanctioning for spreadsheet use. That said, there will plenty of time for total organization in private ships when they come. Spreadsheet encouragement on public ships is often futile as not everyone will use them and remember, the mush can see them as well and destruction of important documents is a valid mush strategy. Lists can also lead to tensions as the super organized might pressure the under organized. You can post your link once and please, don't expect new players or those who would rather stay in game to use these tools.

A note on IRC use - while it's very convenient its use is discouraged on public ships. No one will be sanctioned for using it nor scolded on the forums (/me puts his whip away) it must be used very carefully. IRC logs cannot be used to contest a sanction because like screenshots, they can be tampered with. All pertinent information gleaned from an IRC conversation must be summarized in game. This is the only way for the SDF to see the evidence of the ship's happenings.


Inactivity or Idlers
Inactivity (new players, players not communicating or playing) will not be sanctioned, do not report them. We do not want to sanction new players who might not be engaged. Learning to work around these players is part of our game. You *can* succeed on as ship that has many deaths and/or a fair number of inactive players. Luck and team work amongst those left will be in order but it can be done. Thoughtful communication and patience can go a long way.

There are a couple, very specific, instances of inactivity or perceived inactivity which can be reported. If there is proof of idling for XP farming without actually playing, this can be reported. Proof though would include an admission of this type of activity. Widespread idling for XP gain isn't happening and it shouldn't be assumed that someone inactive is engaging in this activity. Over reporting this will result in a sanction for the unnecessary reports if there isn't solid proof of this behaviour.

The other type of inactivity that can be reported is surrender or giving up. For example, a player has had a disagreement on the ship and stops playing. This is not allowed, ships must be played out.


Ships filling slowly, and Neutral Play
There will be the rare times ships might take longer to fill, when this happens we will expect "neutral play". Which means, we don't do anything that specifically will help either team. As an example, killing hunters is acceptable as a mush goal can potentially be to live longer as much as it is a human goal. What's not acceptable is holding the wrench, apron, weapons and other critical items prior to Mush selection; and you may be sanctioned if found doing so. These items may be moved, but not kept in your inventory. We consider holding onto items in order to have an advantage after Mush selection as a violation of Neutral Play.

The main point of Neutral Play is to give neither side a distinct advantage at the moment of Mush selection. If you have both blasters, and you are selected as Mush, it gives you and your team a significant advantage. The same can be said if you are selected as human. A griefer could pick up critical items before Mush selection, then hold onto them; this gives them a personal advantage, but more importantly, you'll probably have to kill them in order to get those items back. It is better (at the very least, it makes for a more interesting game) for neither side to have a distinct advantage after Mush selection, and that is why these Neutral Play rules exist.

Note: Neutral research before Mush selection IS allowed. Neutral research examples include - Ultra-healing Pomade or the NCC Lenses.

It is at the discretion of judges in this matter, if they feel the game has been spoiled for humans or Mush, they will give a sanction.

Mush Tests updated Jan 29/14
While Mush tests are allowed it is not just to kill someone who refuses to take one. The player might not have AP, might not want to be sick if the test would make them so or the player might just not want to partake in the test because they don't like them. Refusing to do the test alone is not a valid reason to kill someone. If this is the only evidence you have that someone is Mush, it's not enough and could be seen as an unjustified killing which will net a sanction.

Communicate, Communicate, Communicate!
This isn't a rule, per se, but it's crucial to the success of any ship. As simple as it sounds, following this bit of advice is something that may keep you alive longer. As a social game, other players are dependent upon you for information. People who wander around and don't communicate are often the first to be suspected of being Mush. Note that they're usually the first to be assassinated. Communicate more, and you have an easier time earning the trust of your shipmates...and trusted people are less likely to be killed over a misunderstanding!

Remember, Mush is a teamwork game! You can't actively work against your team be it mush or human! If you play as a human and you sabotage the humans (killing for no reason relate to the advancement of the human cause, taking both showers apart, cooking all the rations and letting them spoil, etc) this is griefing and it will be taken very seriously. If you are mush, you cannot denounce your fellow mush or impede the mush cause, you must work as a team.

Have fun!
Mush mods. Peanutz, scout, @Spazticus, and Impet

Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Oh, that. It's usually at the end of a season or at the end of the beta. It didn't happen last season, but sometimes all ships end when there's a new episode.

And sometimes (but rarely) a ship can be terminated by a dev if it's affected by a big bug.

On july 31, 2014
[6826491]
RedTigerCan we report someone who is eating all of our pills for no reason?

If you've warned the player, and they don't respond, much less explain why, you might have sufficient reason to kill them (particularly if they're engaging in other suspicious behavior.) If they're human, you can report it.
Darjus
What if i reported someone and realized that person i have reported is not playing against her team , but is only trying to do something in a different way ? Haven't read forums for a while so no idea if it is possible to cancel it or not
If that happens, send a message to the Mod Inbox, and explain the situation. Send a followup message once the ship finishes. Mods can see who filed a report, and we can be on the lookout for it.
On august 1, 2014
Syvaris

Is it illegal for Chun do violate the neutral play rule?

And if so, why?
On august 1, 2014
[6826491]
Syvaris

Is it illegal for Chun do violate the neutral play rule?

And if so, why?

Yes, Neutral Play rules apply to Chun. Sure, she's always human, but that's actually a big part of why she has to follow them, too. Read the very first post of this thread, specifically this sentence:

The main point of Neutral Play is to give neither side a distinct advantage at the moment of Mush selection.

As an example, if Chun has the armor and the knife prior to Mush selection, that might make it significantly harder for you to kill her, if you're chosen as Mush. This gives her (and by extension, the human team) a distinct advantage. Ultimately, we want to give both sides as fair a start as possible.

Here's another scenario, in which Chun could be sanctioned for violating Neutral Play rules: This Chun is a player who is somewhat experienced, but doesn't like to communicate. She picks up the Hacker Kit and Apron prior to Mush Selection, doesn't tell anyone, and then goes inactive. Now not only has she given the Mush team a distinct advantage, but she's hindered the human team's early research efforts. In order to get the Apron back, the crew is forced to either kill her or let her die naturally. Either way, it makes things more difficult for her team, and they can and should report her for it.

Would you want this player to be considered an exception to the Neutral Play rules, despite spoiling the game? Even if the intent wasn't to grief, the damage is done.
On august 1, 2014
Syvaris

On august 3, 2014
[7950824]

This has recently become a topic on the current MMM thread, The Massive Mush Move Community Jump (2) so I'll pull a quote from there and bring it here, as it's something I'd love to see discussed and I think it maybe should have an SDF stance about. Perhaps it already has such a stance, if so maybe it can be clearly stated so we all know what to expect and what the intended behavior is.

SaboteurWell if the majority votes for returning to Sol I guess it is not against the rules, is it?

There was an earlier thread with some discussion about how disappointing early returns to Sol can be for some players.
You can't trust anyone after mush die

A lot of good points, from multiple sides, were discussed in that thread, but there was no consensus.

One of the things there was no consensus about is How many players need to agree the ship should end for it to be a lawful, not harmful, return?

I personally suggested it should be unanimous to return to Sol, or the ship should continue. Several other players suggested a majority was sufficient.

Now we have a player discussing this:

PatrykSzczescieLOL My ship similar, but there are 10 crewmates. Half of crew agreed to get back to Sol, 2 disagrees, 3 of them didn't tell us their opinion (including commander), so I'll hack on d10c1 and finish the game.

And

PatrykSzczescieNo! I hacked into the Command Terminal because commander Gioele would be inactive, but he kicked me out the Bridge, so I can't back to Sol now

There's some missing details here, for all that we discuss a ship seemingly still in play; is 5 of 10 a majority? We don't even know how long this was discussed, only that 7 of 10 players had enough time to give an opinion. To me, 5/10 is NOT a majority, that could well be a tied vote once all votes are in. Presumably Gioele's 'kick' off the bridge is a form of vote 'no' about the return as well, bringing it to 5 yes, 3 no, and perhaps 2 still not spoken. Sounds like Gioele, at least, wasn't given much time to answer.

Regardless, now that ship is in some form of conflict; AP has been spent both to hack the terminal and to remove a player from the bridge, apparently breaking that hack.


Soooo. SDF people. Would you please discuss, and at some point state, what the standards you wish to have players follow are, for such discussions? We know nothing of this ship's condition, save that 10 live, and at least 2 or 3 want to continue; tentatively it can be assumed the ship is not in a lethal situation at the moment.

But is a majority sufficient to decide upon an early return to Sol? What is a majority, for these purposes?

I greatly appreciate the clear stance on what Neutral Play is and is not, and how and why even Chun is expected and required to follow it. I would love to see a clear stance about 'Early return to Sol or Eden', and when that is and is not considered 'Hostile', in the face of not-unanimous agreement.
On august 3, 2014
[1757645]

My opinion is that people should try to say why they feel one way or the other.
It shouldn't be a simple majority, but you also can't have 1 player just stonewalling the ship (and maybe not even be doing anything.)
Do active players count more than inactives? And how inactive is inactive?

Also in question is if there is a clear goal that can be achieved. Just one more day can go on forever, but until day 10, 15, 20 is doable and has a clear achievement goal.
Same also with Eden. Is it reasonable?
And of course, is the ship almost dead?

The post was in the MMM thread. And "let's return so we can do MMM" is a pretty crappy reason, but is understandable if the ship is down to 20 hull and 8 O2 and you have no planets to head to. (Not saying that was the case.)

And I agree, 5/10 is not a majority, but if 3 are inactive, then that would be 5/7 active players.

(Also, it should be unanimously decided to HAVE a vote, even if the vote itself isn't unanimous.)
On august 3, 2014
[6826491]

We don't have a hard and fast rule regarding the criteria for an early (not Harmful) return. However, guidelines might cover the issue in a better fashion. This will be long, but know that I've made sure they are both reasonable and fair.

The guideline I've used on my ships is the one I partially laid out in this thread: Most crews should at least discuss an expected and predetermined point of return, once their Mush have been dealt with. This doesn't have to be set in stone; putting it to a vote on more than one occasion should also be an option. So if the majority of active crew have agreed, "Let's consider returning D11C1 for our casting tickets, and re-vote before that if the situation changes." then that is totally acceptable. Returning at that point may mean that you return with a full shield and hull, and the supplies to go on at least a few more days...however, this is still not considered a Harmful Return, if the active crew agreed by a majority vote. You can even say on D7-8, "Let's go to D11C1, and we can re-vote then. A lot can happen in the next few days, and if people want to keep going after D11C1, then we will." When it comes to early (not Harmful) returns, communication well in advance is what's best for everyone.

Let me step back for a moment...if we're only counting the votes of the active crew, and you have a majority in favor of a particular course of action, AND there has been a reasonable amount of time to discuss it in advance, then the majority (say, ~70%) should have their way. It's better if it's unanimous...but you might end up with one or two people that want to keep trying for Eden, when you're past D12, have no Diplomats, no Babel Module, and no map pieces yet. In cases like these, if the majority wants to return, the few who want to keep going may face resentment, even if they get their way.

Harmful Returns usually result from the reverse of the above situation. The majority wants to keep going, but the minority (usually just one or two people) wants to return. If those in the minority force a return without immediate circumstances justifying that return, that constitutes a Harmful Return. They are usually initiated without any immediate discussion. Exceptions can be made when you lose one or more active players in a cycle, the ship is close to being destroyed if you don't return, or you're about to start suffocating/starving to death, etc. Those are some immediate circumstances under which you might want to cut your losses early; I would consider them justified, and have had to invoke them myself on occasion. It's not exactly fair to let one or two people hold the rest of the crew hostage, in the same sense that it's not fair for one or two people to unilaterally end the voyage for everyone else, without extenuating circumstances. This is why we'll let the majority rule, and expect re-votes when they're called for.Returning early because you want to join a community jump is strictly sanctionable, and can lead to a quarantine. DO NOT DO THIS, or you may screw over that community jump by being quarantined. It's not worth the consequences. If you appeal a sanction earned under these circumstances, it will probably be denied outright.

In light of all this, here are the guidelines I'd suggest for everyone:

1. Discuss and vote on it early, before disaster strikes, and be reasonable about your odds for Sol/Eden. Be flexible, too, because circumstances can change rapidly. I've been on ships that held an informal vote every day, sort of like this: "I think we're good to keep going today. Any objections?" If there were none, then we'd keep going. If there were any, then we'd discuss it further. It was always understood that if someone had to return us without a vote, it would only be due to dire circumstances. Planning things out this way virtually eliminates the chance of a Harmful Return by an active player, because the active players had agreed to return earlier than planned only in the event of an emergency. You can always vote to extend the return point, too!

2. Communicate, communicate, COMMUNICATE. My mantra for this game applies even more so here. If you're active but muted by an injury, you probably still have post-it notes to use. Inactive players don't count for a vote, because they aren't putting in any effort. So take your votes from the active and communicative players, since you're only going to reach Sol or Eden with their help. If people CAN communicate, but choose not to, then they have no right to complain if the crew's vote doesn't swing their way. Harmful Returns aside, if they don't tell anyone they want to go to D15, and the crew votes to return on D13, whose fault is it that they didn't speak up? Also, if you have to make an emergency return, and there's no time to wait a few cycles for a vote, it might be a good idea to note why you initiated the return in a PM; the judges will see that, just in case there is an investigation. It's to your benefit to do this.

3. If you can't get the majority (~70%) on your side for an early return, the default response should be to keep going, and not end the voyage early for everyone else. If you're deadlocked, keep going, until you have a vote that isn't deadlocked. You can always call a re-vote when things start to look grim, and others may be more agreeable to returning early. Give people ample time to voice their opinions, and if they change their minds later, so be it. This is another reason why this topic should be discussed well in advance of a planned return. How much time is "reasonable"? That will vary from ship to ship...a few cycles, perhaps. That's why a daily vote (informally, even) is a smart idea.

4. One way to think of a Harmful Return is "A suicide that takes the rest of the ship along with you." You're not allowed to surrender or commit suicide, and a Harmful Return is basically both at once; you're giving up and committing suicide, AND the rest of the crew is brought along with you, whether they like it or not. As noted, if it can be proven that you ended a ship early just so you could join a community jump, then you should expect an extra special sanction for that. Community jumps are not so important that regular ships deserve to be screwed over, and they're especially not worth risking a quarantine. Even if it's not for a community jump, Harmful Returns are still sanctionable, and may result in a quarantine.

5. This should go without saying, but it must be said: No matter your opinion, don't be an asshat about it. Likewise, it's not acceptable to kill the people that simply disagree with you, when you know they're human and they're not breaking any rules. I've been on ships where someone threatened to kill anyone with a dissenting opinion, and those making threats were ultimately killed and reported to protect the rest of the crew. Votes don't have to be unanimous, but you'll probably get more people on your side if you make valid points, AND aren't an asshat about it.



I think that should cover the major sticking points, and address a few questions as raised in the MMM thread. While these are guidelines, they should clearly define whether an early return was actually a Harmful Return.

npfan

I honestly don't give a damn about majority vote. Majority vote only works if the majority are reasonable. What I care about are the motives of the person pushing the button to go to Sol and the circumstances of the ship and crew. If the guy pushing to go to Sol did it just to be on an MMM or simply did not care to go longer even though the crew was more than capable of surviving a few days longer, that is a harmful return. If there is good reason to believe that the ship won't last much longer, someone could return to Sol majority or not.
On august 3, 2014
[6826491]

That's what it comes down to though, isn't it? "This is the day/cycle we shoot for, and if things go all to hell before that point, get us back to Sol. If we reach that point and want to keep going, we will take a vote." As long as everyone understands that's the intended plan, a return that happens without a vote before that point would either have to be in an emergency, or it would be a Harmful Return.
On august 3, 2014
Dzanek

Impet

I'll explain what happened there: http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/5040
It was day 6 or something. I was Stephen. A few inactives, Frieda was a Mush, as the only astrophysicist, I wasn't able to copy her skill because I didn't have any time or AP. Came back 3 cycles later (I was sleeping in real), it was too late. Mage books have been printed. No astrophysicist. All Mush dead and Janice asked what to do, what was our goal.
I was respecting following rules:

Playing against one's team
Dying voluntarily to leave the game (Suicide)
Rudeness, insults
Malicious return to Sol by a human

I said that I wanted to finish this game on D10C1, to earn the gold ticket, and I admited to my deside for MMM. Trust me, I'd stay there if this ship was going well, but it wasn't. The crew picked bad projects (Automatic Sprinklers instead of Armored Corridors? Anyway we've got most fires, most broken equipments by then and the armor wasn't going well), no astrophysicist there, problems with armor, of course. We were going well with oxygen, and morale, but that was all.
In this thread, Terrence and Roland agreed to get Sol on day 10. But Raluca said that it looks like "Giving up" and "Resigning of Eden", but my contrargument was strong: no way to get Eden, because we had no astrophysicist and no starmap fragments, as we were before day 10 and it was hard, after day 10 the game would be harder and harder. Anyway, no one disagreed, nobody said "No, we stay!" or something.
In later, when someone was doing Quantum Sensors instead of Fire Detector, I mentioned that we were finishing on day 10 and then (no earlier) Andie said something like "No, we stay!". She (or he) said, that we wouldn't get Sol on day 10 just because I wanted to join MMM, but I said it wasn't just my desire for MMM, but bad ship there. Also Derek joined my side that he want to finish it on day 10. Andie said that we would be voting on day 10 if we wanted continue or finished on day 11 for gold ticket. I said it would be too late for this MMM and gold ticket we may get on D10C1 (I wasn't sure, maybe it was just 9 days after Mush selection, but I was investigating Mushpedia which mentioned that we may get ticket finishing on D10C1; I knew finishing on day 10 might not give gold ticket sometimes, but someone said "first person joined" and if someone got ticket on D10C1 and I wouldn't believe that the Mush selection was on D1C1, I trusted Mushpedia btw).
Later... When Janice also agreed to get back on day 10, Raluca said about day 11 or 12 to get the ticket. And then, Andie also agreed, but she/he hoped to get the gold ticket. I said that we'd prove that with first person on D1C1 we'd earn the ticket and she was happy. No disagrees? 6 votes. Paola, Chun, Gioele didn't vote, so it was indifferent for them.
I was pilot. On day 9 I asked our commander Gioele if he'd be online on D10C1. He said that he'd be on D10C2. As no hunters were in the sky, I decided to find for the Hacker Kit (Frieda hid it in the Bravo Bay, Chun said that she died there, she helped me). I told in the public that I was going to hack because our commander would be inactive on D10C1 (it wasn't anonymous). Then I went hack the Command Terminal. If there had been any hunter, I'd have advanced the Terminal and moved away. D9C7, I managed to hack it, all my APs used. Now, just to wait till D10C1. It'd be against the rules if I did it earlier.
D9C8 - I was in one of Front Turrets. All the buttons of actions in the Command Terminal disappeared. I've got angry. I could only exit the Terminal and get back to the Bridge, and hack again. Gioele said nothing against returning to the Sol on D10C1, suddenly he just kicked me out and guarded. I was surprised that Gioele, who had just Solid skill and said he was newbie, suddenly used "Guard" action. Chun died on D9C8 (or D9C7, I can't recall). I said that I was sad. It was too late for her. I said that I'd have healed her if the medikit had been there, but it hadn't been. Gioele just said "You wasted all the AP to hack into the Terminal instead of shooting hunters." Nothing more. When I said about attempting to hack again, Roland said "Dude, I'm outside, I'll come back on D10C2". I complained him, that returning to Sol doesn't cause him abandoned.
Terrence said that he'd hack and get us back to Sol, with fruit and coffee. I told Janice if she helped because her IT Expert skills doubles chance of hacking. She agreed. Terrence asked if he could kill Gioele, then I'd be a commander next cycle, but it would be breaking the rules now, I prevented from doing it.
It was D10C1. Gioele lied that he wouldn't be then, because he accessed the Terminal. I asked Janice if she was ready to pick the Hacker Kit up, she said "yes" and I dropped it. Then joined Terrence, took it and finished the game. Raluca should be happy that she got the gold ticket, as I promised.
I know. It looks like human team fights with each other for returning to the Sol, but... how does it look in fact? 66% of crew agrees to get to the Sol (we could say ~70%), Gioele without words prevents from doing this. He looked like a griefer then. I presented rational (and volitional) arguments, nobody opposed them. To get MMM, I didn't finish the game without saying anything, because I'd get quarantined in MMM and no MMM for me, I knew it. But I was clear. I asked the crew for it and this was dependent on their mind. I'd be ready to continue this bad ship if they disagreed, because every attempt to get MMM would finish being quarantined then, wouldn't it?

2. Is SMS language allowed in the Mush Channel?
3. If RFS is invented, can the Mush take it and use it on human in order to be exposed and killed?
On august 5, 2014
SummerMcLovin

1) You always play for your team, so as a human you would want to out the remaining Mush team. There was a previous mod/judge comment that the least you could do is morally refuse to, but you cannot lie about there being no AnonyMush left.
2) As long as it is understandable to those you're talking to (making it different from your "general chat persona" could be a tactic in case of Pheromodem) it shouldn't be against the rules.
3) Mush being able to waste the Serum would further their cause, although you should always try and get away with it without dying.
On august 5, 2014
[7950824]

1) was stated by Summer a little stronger than I understand the SDF stance to be.

A cured mush is free to do anything but lie.

You do not have to tell your teammates anything. But what you tell them must be true. You are now human and your future actions must support a human win, but that does not mean you must (but you may) compromise your past actions and your past team.

As a cured mush, you are allowed to say nothing about any other mush. Allowed to say nothing about existing trapped rooms and fungal kitchened rations you are aware of.

Note that you are not allowed to run off and use such things to turn yourself back into being a mush. You are human now and must work for a human win and work to stay human.

As a cured mush, you are allowed to reveal anything and everything you knew while you were a mush. You're allowed to out your whole team, plans, and any threats to the human side you are aware of. Just be honest about what you do say, whatever that is.

And one more question: In Mush Channel, can I talk in other language than English if my partner understands?

Yes, imagine you had a ship full of russians or something and you all had to speak english, you can speak any language you like as long as the majority of the crew are okay with it.

A cured mush is free to do anything but lie.

As a cured mush, you are allowed to say nothing about any other mush. Allowed to say nothing about existing trapped rooms and fungal kitchened rations you are aware of.

Note that you are not allowed to run off and use such things to turn yourself back into being a mush. You are human now and must work for a human win and work to stay human.

On august 5, 2014
[6826491]

I've answered this one before, but here's officially what a cured Mush can say:

1. They can reveal if there are any Mush left, if so, and any divulge any traps/plans/list any spored humans. They may confirm that there are no more Mush, if that is the truth.

2. They may choose to say nothing, but they also risk being killed by the other humans if they do this. It is not sanctionable to kill a cured Mush who refuses to confirm or deny the existence of any other Mush. Likewise, the cured Mush isn't going to be sanctioned for choosing to say nothing. Let me emphasize that: If you choose to say nothing after being cured, they may justifiably kill you, if they wish.

As Summer and Impet noted, They may not lie. They can't claim there are still Mush if they were the last one, nor can they claim the Mush are dead if any others remain. To do so would be playing against their team, as would actively trying to become Mush again. True, saying nothing gets a pass, but only because at worst, it's a lie of omission, and they're not confirming or denying anything. The Mush could be wiped out, and the cured Mush might still choose to say nothing...but they still risk being killed for it.

And of course, they must ultimately play for their team, so trying to work with any remaining Mush in secret is definitely sanctionable for anyone involved.
On august 5, 2014
sperbi

Can you give any understandable reason why a cured mush - now human can decide to say nothing about the mushes without hurting their new team - the humans by doing so? it is obvious that humans would like to know that information, not telling that information is refusing to help and therefore hurting of the team.
On august 5, 2014
SummerMcLovin

It's in the benefit of the human team for everyone to prove themselves human with food tests right away (although that can be wasteful of resources, so not as strong an example) but people feel that spoils the game. Out of some sense of fairness or because they enjoy the hunt (although they kind of preclude themselves since they know exactly who to look for), they might not want to, and I guess the SDF allow it for those sort of reasons.
On august 5, 2014
[6826491]

That's really the crux of it. Think of it in the same vein as being unable to print Eleesha's List because the Mush are dead, versus printing it early, and not being 100% sure that no Mush remain later. When the SDF was debating how this would be enforced, some judges successfully argued that a cured Mush shouldn't be forced to reveal who the other Mush were, and in effect spoil the hunt. From an RP standpoint, one can say that they "have amnesia regarding their time as Mush", as long as they're not lying about what they divulge.

The upshot of this is that if there are other Mush, the hunt will continue as normal. If there are no Mush, the humans will have to remain vigilant until everyone is proved to be human (assuming they no longer have the option to print The List.) The tradeoff is that the other humans can kill them without a risk of a sanction, if the vote swings in that direction. So it is not without risk, but it's still allowed as an option.

It is not sanctionable to kill a cured Mush who refuses to confirm or deny the existence of any other Mush. Let me emphasize that: If you choose to say nothing after being cured, they may justifiably kill you, if they wish.

[1757645]

Think of it this way. Being inactive isn't sanctionable. So why would being more helpful than an inactive be sanctionable?

The cured MUSH is helping, just not being as effective at helping as they could be. They're better than an inactive player, but not as good as them being super helpful.
On the flip side, what if a human is converted and has access to the anti-MUSH channel? Can they not say that the MUSH hunters are targeting someone? What you knew that they had completed the cure and were planning on curing one of your new MUSH? Are you still allowed to say nothing?

At any rate, you can be killed for being inactive (well, grande inactive) so not informing people of your old teams activities is sort of being inactive.

On the subject of using foreign languages in the MUSH channel. The humans have a way to get access to your channel, if it's in a foreign language then it's like you are talking in code. That's not really fair. (Unless it's a code you just made up.)

[7896920]

It is not sanctionable to kill a cured Mush who refuses to confirm or deny the existence of any other Mush. Likewise, the cured Mush isn't going to be sanctioned for choosing to say nothing. Let me emphasize that: If you choose to say nothing after being cured, they may justifiably kill you, if they wish.

Is an ex-mush who is pretending to have amnesia allowed to defend themselves if the crew tries to kill them?

It seems odd to me that the team is free to kill the ex-mush as that actually does hurt the team. An ex-mush pretending to not remember doesn't hurt the human team. The team is no worse off for it, they simply don't have a piece of information they wouldn't have had anyways. But by killing the ex-mush they are hurting the human team. They don't gain anything by killing them, they are removing someone who could have contributed ap around the ship, and it seems like a waste of ap to research RFS, cure someone, then spend more ap killing them with nothing to gain. I wouldn't trust that 'confirmation', at least.

On august 7, 2014
[7950824]

I agree. That's why I only discussed that tiny focused part of the statement.

I think the rule was made from mercy and acceptance, that it was a hugely emotional grey area, and one that 'should' be left up to each set of players on each individual ship.

Do I agree that curing, then killing, someone who had been mush is a pretty big waste? Sure. Would I do it myself? Only if they clearly were seriously breaking rules, and I needed them dead because they were playing against their new team in a way that wasn't about if they talk about their old team or not.

Thing is though, this is the rule. We know what it is, we understand it. So we can play with it, legally, ourselves. And we have utmost freedom. Personally, I think that's awesome and generous. Here's this giant grey area.... and it has almost no rules for the parts which are grey. Great, the rule is 'freedom', in this case.

By all means, discuss with your team about what you intend to do if you are cured/discuss with your team what you want your team to do if the cured one doesn't talk, so no one is surprised and everyone on the same team is on the same page.

The SDF is not saying you should kill a mush that doesn't talk. They are not saying that a cured mush shouldn't talk. All they've said is that this is an area where there are no set rules, do as you please yourself. They get to do that too, and actually it takes a good bit of courage to be a lawmaker/law enforcer and to decide 'I agree this isn't in my jurisdiction' and withhold judgment. After all, the individual judges and mods probably each have strong and differing viewpoints about what is right in this case.... a huge reason why it was probably named a grey area without official rules.
On august 8, 2014
[6826491]

At the risk of bring a slippery slope argument into this discussion: "Where does it end?"

If we were to compel every cured Mush to immediately disclose whether there are any Mush left, who they are, and any plots in place (traps, spored food, etc.) then the Mush hunt would be over almost instantly. Some human players enjoy the thrill of the hunt, and that could ruin their fun.

But this is where the crux of my question lies: Is it fair to compel that action for all cured Mush, without any exceptions? Do we sanction them if they don't reveal the other Mush within a certain amount of time? Do we sanction players who don't believe the cured Mush, and kill them? What happens if the remaining Mush manage to convert a new beta, unbeknownst to the cured Mush...is the cured Mush deserving of a sanction?

Let's take it one step further: At what point can the SDF reasonably define "not playing for your team" in this case? We don't sanction for just being inactive. We don't sanction for choosing to not help when a Mush is on the loose - a Lethargic Chun comes to mind. We don't sanction someone who is a Technician, but doesn't spend a single AP in the Nexus. (In this last case, it's still assumed that their AP is still being used to help the ship, perhaps on research instead.)

As Impet stated, there is a lot of gray area to be found here.

A cured Mush can choose to reveal everything they know, from the moment they've been cured. They may also choose to say nothing. It's up to them, as long as they're 100% truthful with the information they provide - that's the only thing we can reasonably compel them to do in this case.

As for the other humans, they too have choices to make. Most will let the cured Mush live, regardless of whether or not they give up the other Mush...it was a huge effort to identify them, and keep them "pacified" enough to not disrupt the work on the RFS. Granted, the faster solution would be to kill them outright. So we can understand how some humans would be frustrated if they go through all that effort, only to find the cured Mush won't give up the other Mush, or confirm that the hunt is over.

This is why the humans have the option to kill a cured Mush that doesn't talk. It's not necessarily advised to kill them. All we're saying is that IF they don't talk, then you MAY kill them. Most cured Mush will talk, and most crews won't have any reason to kill them. This is just one sole exception to the usual rules on this matter.

And yes, I will acknowledge that there have been very few occasions where a cured Mush not only refused to talk, they refused to work with the human team. By that, I mean they tried to become Mush again, or acted in ways that would specifically benefit the remaining Mush. In these cases, we throw the book at them, because they are undoubtedly griefing.
On august 8, 2014
[7896920]

Sorry, wasn't trying to reopen the discussion on whether its okay to kill the ex-mush or not. The SDF policy is clear and I'm fine with it.

The questions I was trying to ask were related to self defense. If a human tries to kill a cured mush for not talking, can the cured mush fight back? If a human is accused of being mush by Chun (or anyone, just chose Chun because they would know she isn't a mush) and attacked by her, can they fight back? In those cases will the person defending themselves get sanctioned if they kill their attacker?
On august 8, 2014
Dzanek

Spazticus is supposely convincing, such as Mush. Imagine: Raluca, the only Technician, ex-Mush says nothing, and everybody let her alive, except Derek, who kills her and no chance to return to Sol.

On august 8, 2014
[6826491]
kumquatThe questions I was trying to ask were related to self defense. If a human tries to kill a cured mush for not talking, can the cured mush fight back? If a human is accused of being mush by Chun (or anyone, just chose Chun because they would know she isn't a mush) and attacked by her, can they fight back? In those cases will the person defending themselves get sanctioned if they kill their attacker?

You have the right to defend yourself, whether you're human or a cured Mush. Obviously, don't kill them just because they kick you out of a bed, or take the day's coffee. But that's a separate issue, and this one is a tricky one.

The facts:

They can't report you for choosing to maintain silence. They CAN justifiably kill you for it.

You can't report them for trying to kill you, just because you maintained silence. You CAN defend yourself, however. Trying to kill the other humans first would give them reason to report you, so that's not a viable option.

From the above, I can derive these options:

Plan A: Let them kill you. It's not a suicide, unless you asked them to kill you, or implied that they "should" kill you. Result: You're dead. Very, very dead. They never get the confirmation only you can provide, and nobody wins - it's technically a loss for both teams, since both lost a player in the curing and subsequent murder.

Plan B: Defend yourself, without killing anyone else, and try to get them to cease their attack. Result: You might die in the attempt, or you might convince them it's not worth the AP to kill you...yet.

Plan C: If you know the identity of a remaining Mush, attack and kill them, without confirming or denying anything else. Result: Varies. They might still kill you for keeping your silence, but they may instead leave you alive for killing a Mush. It's a far better shot at staying alive than either Plan A or B, if you succeed.

Plan D: If you know the identity of another Mush, attack and try to kill them, without confirming or denying anything else...but fail miserably (not by choice, heh.) Result: Varies. If they're not high on the list of suspects, you could end up dead for instigating a "random" attack. Or they might finish the job themselves, and leave you alive afterward.

Plan E: The obvious one, I suppose...agree to talk. This has the highest chance of defusing a tense situation, and is most likely to leave your body free of bruises, cuts, and blaster wounds.

Those are your primary options, as a cured Mush under attack by other humans. I'll cover the option in the original question last.

Back to whether killing a human who is trying to kill you (also a human) is sanctionable: Probably not, if it can be proved that you only acted in self defense, and avoided conflict before that point. We'd have to take it on a case by case basis.
On august 8, 2014
sperbi
kumquatThe questions I was trying to ask were related to self defense. If a human tries to kill a cured mush for not talking, can the cured mush fight back? If a human is accused of being mush by Chun (or anyone, just chose Chun because they would know she isn't a mush) and attacked by her, can they fight back? In those cases will the person defending themselves get sanctioned if they kill their attacker?

On august 8, 2014
SummerMcLovin

The thing with killing someone who is attacking you is that unless your connection is drastically better than theirs and you happen to be online and notice right at the moment of the attack, they're going to get you before you get them... and then you have the other active crew to deal with (extremely likely on a ship that can cure a Mush, even if there are others out there...)
In "fight or flight", flight works so much better. Maybe you can take that literally and hide out in a patrol ship while you explain things to them, or simply run off to the Medlab to heal some damage then ask for them to stop punching you in the mouth while you're trying to talk.

[7896920]

Thanks for the answers Spazticus.

Sperbi, when I say self defense I'm talking about when someone is attacking you, not simply pushing you out of bed or accusing you in chat. I find that when people get to the point where they are attempting to kill you they have generally already decided you're a mush it usually doesn't matter how much you try to explain if you are not. And if you try and type up an explanation of how you are not a mush, you will probably find you are dead by the time you hit enter to post it. Sure you could go food test or something, but I don't like playing that way. And just because someone is attacking you doesn't mean they have solid evidence. I've killed people that I was sure were mush that turned out to be human, and Ive seen people killed for ridiculous reasons that turned out to be human. Some people wait until they have solid evidence to kill, and some people kill as soon as they have circumstantial suspicions. How can killing Chun be self defense? If I log in and see that she's tried to shoot me 3 times and then started punching me I consider fighting back self defense at that point.

SummerMclovin, just because it takes luck to catch someone attacking you doesn't mean it doesn't happen. Ive logged in right as someone was attacking me and killed them. Running or taking a patrol craft doesn't always work either. Lots of crews are willing to abandon people if they think they are a mush out in a patrol craft and there is no net. Self healing is expensive. If you are say wrestler Derek and dont have a ton of ap you probably have a better chance of surviving that attacker by fighting back.

Sure you will probably get killed by the rest of the crew after killing the attacker, but if you are human it could teach them a lesson about collecting more or better evidence before deciding to kill next time.

But its really a moot point since Spazitcus already said if someone is actively trying to kill you, you have a right to defend yourself.

The reason why retaliating against the person attacking you is okay is that the person attacking you to get you to talk might be in the minority about attacking you.

Say, only Chao is trying to get you to talk and so attacks you. You kill him, and everyone else doesn't do anything else. Maybe because Chao has been very aggressive and they are sick of him and thus don't care.

As the SDF have said, it's a very grey area, and thus too hard to really make a verdict on it, so they are sort of saying let the ship figure it out.

[6474534]

On august 14, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieAs Mush, can I spam the public chat to make communication more difficult?

You can still be reported for Flooding, so I wouldn't advise doing that. Making replies to several threads (as long as the replies are relevant) is acceptable, though. If doing that buries a post you're hoping to hide, that's the better way to do it.


DewyUnfortunatly this is a question about a ship that's happening now. Our Gioele is a level 6 and at least silver as he has taken the skills Astrophysicist and Victimizer post mush selection. Meaning hes skipped all the skills which are awful when your mush (Solid, Caffeine Junkie and Paranoid) and taken those two especially suspicious as we have an active Frieda. If I killed him would it be reportable as having not enough evidence?

Suboptimal skill choices aren't necessarily enough evidence on their own to kill someone... e.g. a Chun without MOH may still be helpful to the crew, and may not actually be trolling the ship. If said Chun were to conduct any griefing actions however, then you could reasonably kill and report her.

So let's apply that concept to your ship: If all you have is the skill choice to go on, you need a bit more than that. Is he entering the dorm with the shower a little too often? Is he claiming to spend his AP in a way that doesn't make sense? He's obviously not new, so there's a reasonable chance he won't make those sorts of mistakes. It's quite possible he took those skills because he feared he might become a Beta, and then be in a rough position skill-wise. But if you have suspect answers to these sorts of aforementioned questions, then discuss it with Chun and any other verified humans, and kill him if your vote swings that way. At least there's a record of it, and if you're wrong, you tried to discuss it and perhaps exonerate him.

At the very worst, you could ask him to Mush test himself, and be ready to react if he panics. Or he could refuse the test - anyone can refuse to Mush test themselves, and you can't kill them solely based on their refusal. If he refuses, you can only kill him if there was already enough evidence to suspect him in the first place. Asking a person to test themselves is usually a last-ditch effort to exonerate someone you otherwise would have killed anyway.
On august 14, 2014
npfan
SpazticusIt's quite possible he took those skills because he feared he might become a Beta, and then be in a rough position skill-wise.

Honestly though, if I was playing Gioele and found out I'm not Alpha Mush, I'd probably choose those very skills that Mush would lose so that it would make me unappealing to be beta Mush.

Daniel1310Is it legal to kill my mush friend if he is inactive to eliminate suspicion from humans?

Oh, and if this is a real scenario, I would hold off on it for a while. If someone happens to read the forums about this, and then, say, Terrence, pipes up about killing an inactive, it could look a bit weird.
On august 17, 2014
npfan
Daniel1310Is it legal to kill my mush friend if he is inactive to eliminate suspicion from humans?

If they're Super Inactive, yes. If they're just inactive, just make sure it seems likely the player isn't going to come back. Keep in mind though that killing your Mush partner can possibly hurt your team considering that new research becomes unlocked with a dead Mush and it can be easy to defeat the Mush team unless you have converted someone.

On august 17, 2014
Syvaris

Can I hide MAD KUBE before the Mush are selected?
On august 17, 2014
[6826491]
RedTigerNo, its a harmless action really because the person they flirted with must start the "Do the thing" action.

Flirting still costs 1 AP, so an argument can be made that AP is being wasted. However, I don't think that's enough reason on its own to justify killing someone.

SyvarisCan I hide MAD KUBE before the Mush are selected?

No items may be hidden prior to Mush selection - the option is not available until the moment of Mush selection. You can't keep in it your inventory prior to Mush selection, either - since that would violate Neutral Play. (That said, after Mush selection, you're able to hide it if you wish. Just know that if you get caught after hiding it, your crew might suspect you of hiding other items from them.) If it were me, I'd announce that I want to hide it, explain why, then get the experienced crew to agree with me before hiding it.

Chime

Well unless the attacker doesn't have enough AP you're usually dead before you can run. And let's be honest. If you attack someone as a human believing they are mush. And they run away hiding behind Ian. Or flying out or hiding in medlab to heal themselves. Would you as attacker draw the conclusion: "Ah no, that can't be a mush. I must be mistaken." and stop?

As the person who's attacked you usually aren't in the group that discusses your case. So you don't even know if it was a discussed decision. Or if that guy that attacks you is a mush going on rampage. Sure Chun can't be mush. But how do you know that she isn't a griefer? Because humans are reluctant to kill her, she's quite liked be griefers. Not playing against your team is one thing, but which human would actually go: "Oh well, once I'm dead they'll see how wrong they were."

De facto. It usually goes the other way. The human is killed and the killers, worrying over their own life justify the murder by insulting the dead. Saying how careless he was. And how suspicious. Or that it was his own fault. Because humans would never do mistakes, right?
On august 19, 2014
sperbi

There are 2 cases (and sometimes cases which can't assigned properly to one of them): either you were killed without any reason. Then the attacker was a griefer and attacking the griefer is fully fine.
Or the second case is that you did a mistake. A mistake which made yourself suspicious like killing the wrong person (you thought it was a mush) or being dirty without reporting or whatever . It is your mistake, so I think you also have the responsibility to face the consequences without doing more harm to the human team.
And you can still try to avoid being killed without being too suspicious or at least help the human team to get the real mush - for example you can say, that they will see that you are no mush when they kill you and tell them who the real mush is if you have already any idea. Maybe they will even believe you without killing you first if you have strong evidences within your hand. Although I don't like these tests, it is also possible to do a mush test - I wouldn't recommend it personally and tests shoudl also not be excuses to do what you want, but a test to save your life seems more ok to me than tests without any reason. or maybe you just have a good explanation regarding the use or amount of aps you used which makes it very unlikely that you are a mush and makes them believe you.
On august 19, 2014
npfan
XxeroxSo, what if i do the food test 1 minute after mush are chosen, and later someone kills me. Can i report him because i am confirmed human , and the one who killed me is human too. The point is i never go out of a dorm, and use all my ap as fast as i can so no one can infect me, so i am 100% confirmed human like chun.And even if i was infected by some super silly chance, i would not be a mush. And since i usually kill fast the mush, since its easy to deduce, there is only 1 mush left ... soooo can i report the one who killed me ?

You're always welcome to report someone you have to good reason to believe may have broken the rules. The SDF doesn't expect anyone who reports to know everything that is said and done on the ship, so don't worry if there is a possibility that the person who killed you might have a good reason to. The judges will sort that out.


sperbiI really don't get why people are doing that, but that's only my opinion. You are helping the mush when you kill humans, especially Chun. If you manage to escape and make it so calmer heads rule and no one gets killed, great. You still have the right to fight back though since this kind of situation usually ends up being kill or be killed.

On august 21, 2014
Cwovictor

Is it reportable if someone drops an F-Bomb with their last words? If so, is it possible to report them after entering your last words yourself?
On august 21, 2014
SummerMcLovin

spacekadt (a Judge [right?]) has stated in the past that swearing alone isn't enough to warrant a sanction. I believe the example was that when it is a repeated problem on a ship with no reason it would be something to report, but if you kept screwing up and they moaned at you every time with bad language then they'd be justified.
In general though, has it really harmed your life by seeing a swear word on the internet?

Even if you were going to report them though, you can't report anyone once you have entered your last words. It is advisable to check the Honours via your Mush Profile before you finish for hidden Mush etc., but of course that doesn't help if they hadn't put their entry at the time.
On august 21, 2014
[6826491]
SummerMcLovinspacekadt (a Judge [right?]) has stated in the past that swearing alone isn't enough to warrant a sanction. I believe the example was that when it is a repeated problem on a ship with no reason it would be something to report, but if you kept screwing up and they moaned at you every time with bad language then they'd be justified.

In general, this is correct. (And yes, Spacey is a judge.) Occasional swearing in context is allowed some leeway, but people shouldn't go overboard with it, and they shouldn't repeatedly harass others with it, either. RP be damned, this is still a social game, and if your RP comes at the expense of the other players' morale, then it's gone too far.

This is rule of thumb to use, and you can quote this post if/when needed: Occasional swearing is fine, when it's in context and not directed at anyone in particular. Insulting others repeatedly is not fine, so don't make yourself look like an asshole in the process of telling people they did something wrong. It might earn you a sanction, even if you were saying was correct.

Exceptions are often made for racist, homophobic, and sexist insults (particularly comments involving rape) to name a few, and these can indeed lead to sanctions. The SDF doesn't allow any leeway for these, because they violate the site's Terms of Service. I don't need to give you specific examples here, but if it crosses into hate speech territory, there may be consequences. Use some discretion.
On august 21, 2014

Or not. I've been close to reporting some people in the past for excessive swearing (not directed at anyone) but it seems like they were in their right.

On august 21, 2014
[6826491]
Syvaris

Is this legal?

Janice: Solution for players that don't want to waste gold days or time on a ship with grief and inactives.

Repair pilgred and then return to sol even if mush win...

It is a form of surrender and in some way suicide...

It is not legal. If you go back to Sol, knowing that you have Mush aboard, you not only lose the game, but the person who initiated the jump to Sol can be reported for a Harmful Return. It's a form of surrender, and like other Harmful Returns, "it's a form of suicide that also takes the rest of the ship with you." Games have to be played out to their natural conclusion, and at the very least, your Janice can be reported for incitement to spoil the game.

If your Mush (anonymush, more often than not) initiates the jump, and there is no collusion or "nudges" to make it happen, that would be quite different. Basically what your Janice said, while leaving open the suggestion for the Mush to hack the Command Terminal, is a definite nudge, at best, and collusion at worst. It's about as bad as initiating the Jump to Sol because a person wants to join a community jump. Don't do that, people...we sanction for that!

[8353852]

Does installing cameras violates neutral play?
On august 28, 2014
[6826491]
pimpernelDoes installing cameras violates neutral play?

No, it's fair game. Even with a Paranoid Gioele, you can't cover every room. On the other hand, it would give a distinct advantage to the Mush if cameras couldn't be installed prior to Mush selection.
On august 28, 2014
Kyubey

Is that so, Spazticus ?
Cameras looks exactly like mush sample and gas/serum research before mush selection.
Start of the game: research on 0%, cameras are not installed - so it's up to players to change the situation.

- Neutral option -
Don't do gas/serum research before selection (now, in Season 4 you are forced not to do it because lack of sample)
Don't touch cameras - don't install them, don't hold.

- Human advantage -
Do gas/serum research before selection
Install cameras before selection

- Mush advantage -
Hide or Hold mush sample, delay research if you were choosen as mush, if you held/hiden sample
Hold cameras, install them after selection, with spiking humans in the room before installing

Installing cameras is giving one of teams great advantage, so I really see no reason to call that "fair" start. I'm ok with that, as mushes are strong enough anyway and have a lot of ways in very start, but I would be much more logical, if mushes have different weak points, but cameras swawn like sample and mage book - after selection.

Saying "cameras cannot cover all the rooms anyway" sounds like "gas and serum before selection is not big deal, they still can do 2 spores for 4ap each"
On august 28, 2014
[6826491]

My point still stands; it's fair to install them. Mush have skills designed to break or remove cameras, and many new players idle outside of rooms with a camera. There usually won't be a shortage of targets at the start of the game, and if the human crew wants to accomplish anything, they usually have to leave the safety of a camera. As I also pointed out, that safety can be broken/removed.
On august 28, 2014
Kyubey

Mush has also skills to counter anti-mush research - Mycelium Spirit and Fertile. Mush has also ways to finish humans, when they hold armor and all weapons before selection like Demoralize. Still - those actions were either blocked by game mechanic or reportable.
So - what's the difference?
And if players are allowed to change the start conditions where all cameras are in storage in one team favor, why they are not allowed for example to dismanle both showers before selection or hack bios and get hull to 50 with taking off and landings, to make start conditions better for mush side?

I can understand - 3-5 installed cameras is something like "default settings" in player mind, and from that point a lot of mush tactics and human counter tactics start, changing that will change the whole early game greatly, but does just that makes it right?
On august 28, 2014
[6826491]

It's a fair start, because Mush have such countermeasures. Humans not under a camera have exactly zero protection from being spored, at least at the start of the game. But at the start of the game, and even during it, you will often find there are often players outside of a camera room. In effect, it's fair because the humans will still present you with opportunities to spore them, even with low level Mush skills.

Research is a different matter, however. It's not fair to make a comparison to research, because there is no way to "undo" research, once completed. An installed camera can be removed or broken by the Mush, and the game can break it randomly without any Mush involvement - this often leads to the humans tripping over each other to find a culprit. Research has no such equivalent situation.

On september 2, 2014
en2que

If there are 2 mushes on board and humans use the serum on one, is that one forced to tell the humans who was his teammate?
On september 2, 2014
[7950824]
Anno9000If there are 2 mushes on board and humans use the serum on one, is that one forced to tell the humans who was his teammate?

Not forced, no. The cured used-to-be mush must tell the truth, but they are allowed not to answer.

So if there are other living mush, the Cured-Mush can tell you who the mush are, where any trapped rooms and fungal-kitchened edibles are, and whatever the mush plans are.

Or, if there are no mush left, the Cured-mush can tell you they were the last mush and there are none left.

Or, no matter if there are mush left or not, the Cured-mush can tell you nothing. Tell you they won't answer you, won't tell you anything about the mush. Claim not to remember.


What the Cured-mush is not allowed to do is lie. So if there are mush left alive, the Cured-mush may not tell you there are no mush left. And if there are no mush left, the Cured-mush cannot tell you that so-and-so is a mush.

You are allowed to kill the Cured-mush if the Cured-mush refuses to tell you about the other mush, or that there are no mush left, if you choose to do that.

The only thing that breaks any rules would be if the Cured-mush lies to you.
On september 2, 2014
horusboyd

I have a question here. If you get cured and don't tell your new team about the other Mush (assuming there is one), you are not violating the rule that you are not allowed to actively play against your team. But does this mean it's fine to play against your team passively? This is obviously vital information that you choose to not share in this case, and depending on circumstances, it could decide which team ends up winning, and at least some people are going to be unhappy. Can the rules be made a little clearer regarding this? Or will people just never be punished in this situation?

Edit: for clarity, I'm mentioning this because this is the type of confusion that can lead to dangerous precedents and nasty situations, which we probably want to avoid.
On september 2, 2014
[7950824]

The case of a cured mush is an exception to the rule of 'never play against your team'. As of right now, it is not a precedent, but the sole exception to the rule 'never play against your team', and it exists as an exception because of the vast gray area of the situation required to have a cured mush in the first place. However, this is not 'a dangerous precedent', though a cured mush is potentially a nasty situation, one with so many variables that the SDF has decided 'this is not an area where judging will happen, unless the cured mush lies about the status of other mush'.

The exception exists because our judges and/or mods of the time this was being decided contained a wide range of individuals, who managed to convince each other that this was a huge gray area. There are two main reasons for this gray area:

1) The mush hunt. If a mush is cured and then 'tells all', the hunt is entirely ended. This can be seen as spoiling the hunt, and it can also be seen as spoiling the hunt to -not- tell all; that the cure of a mush is a satisfactory end to the mush hunt. But both sides of this debate have value and meaning.

2) The mush team. By the point a mush has been cured, a lot of game has happened. The cured player arguably has extremely conflicted loyalties at this point, being aware of and possibly heavily involved in days-long plans to destroy the ship. Revealing all once cured can feel like a vast betrayal of all that preparation, both of the cured player and the remaining mush. Thus, an 'out' is allowed, if the cured player wishes to take it; that player may 'claim not to remember', and give no information at all. The players who would wish to do this typically will be the players who actually do perceive this discrepancy, for whom revelation will feel like betrayal. The SDF has decided to allow this 'escape clause', completely understanding and accepting that the human team may feel betrayed in turn by this reaction - there will be no sanction for failing to reveal information about the remaining mush. If the other humans wish to kill the cured mush for failing to communicate about the other mush - that is allowed, there will be no sanction for doing so, if that's what the humans choose.

This was seen as the only possible fair answer, given understanding and acceptance of the category of player for whom 'telling all' was an absolutely unacceptable answer, for one or both of the above reasons.

I personally believe I would tell all, if I was a cured mush. Then again, that hasn't happened to me yet, so I wait my chance to play through it and really learn from the inside why this gray area exists and what it really feels like to experience it.
On september 2, 2014
horusboyd

Thanks for clearing it up. Can your post be linked in the OP? I bet the question will come up again, and it'd be good to be able to find it easily.
On september 2, 2014
[7950824]

Unsure, but this has been discussed before, with more and less detail, which is why I knew the answer.
On september 2, 2014
npfan
horusboydThanks for clearing it up. Can your post be linked in the OP? I bet the question will come up again, and it'd be good to be able to find it easily.

I really feel like the post in question is extrapolating a bit too much. Yes, some have argued that forcing a tell-all will ruin the Mush hunt and some have argued that they feel a sense of betrayal if the cured Mush were to tell everything, but to say this is somehow an exception made to playing against the team is not really the right way of looking at this, at least from my perspective. I'm going to be honest and say that when this issue was first brought up, I was on the side of purposely telling nothing because of either of the two stated reasons or some other reason being a sanctionable offence. However, some argued that from an RP perspective that the human side of a character may be unaware of what the Mush side of the character was doing, so a cured Mush could claim not knowing anything or ' have amnesia' and not be playing against the team. Of course, we all recognise that the player behind the character will know everything, so I made sure that if a cured Mush can claim amnesia, that cured Mush can also be killed with impunity if such claim is made. If that scenario happens, either it would be as if the cured Mush was never Mush and is allowed to live to help the humans or just one more Mush dead.
On september 4, 2014
Matt

I have a question. I'm fairly new, but believe I read all the appropriate threads, please point me in the right direction if i missed something.

We've killed two mushes fairly quickly (mushes selected D1C7 or so, first one killed D2C7, pheromodem rushed D3C2, second mush identified from mush channel and killed D3C3), but after both were dead, someone posted a taunt in the mush channel mentioning two characters by name (one as a mush, another as the next target), talking about transfers and anonymush. The mush channel only shows a single spiking which resulted in someone having a single spore, but it is possible that the alphas were super active the first few cycles and successfully infected someone too early in the mush channel for the humans to see. The comrades bar shows 14 humans and 2 dead mush.
I am assuming that the mush is paying attention and knows that pheromodem is active.

What leads me to suspect that this is "playing against the team" is that:
1) If this player is a human, pretending to be a mush for the purposes of extending the mush hunt does not seem to help the humans at all.
2) If this player is a mush, extending the mush hunt would be valid team play, BUT
2a) using names of real mushes (or self) is playing against the mush team
2b) using names of non-mushes to try to get them killed is helping humans because of 2a
2c) speaking up at all to let the humans know that there are surviving mush seems like throwing away the advantage of anonymush.

Should I report the post in the mush channel?

On september 4, 2014
[7950824]

Humans spoofing through pheromodem seems pretty common to me, on my ships. I usually ignore it, or even play back. I believe more experienced players put no faith in what is said on the mush channel after pheromodem. That said, if you feel it goes over the line, you should report it. Unless you report really unwisely/unless the report you make looks intentionally inappropriate, judges can clear it fast and you would face no repercussions. And if it is an inappropriate comment you report, that allows it to be sanctioned.

You mentioned you were a new player, so I want to mention some things that can be done to attempt to verify if you still have living mush. For one, you mentioned someone got a spore as shown on the mush channel? Was that from before or after the second mush died? If after, did it come from a trapped shelf or an edible, or from direct spiking? Direct spiking means you have a live mush for sure. The other two could be from a spore that was placed before the mush making it died.

Two, is Eleesha alive, a tracker, and has she printed the list yet? If she is alive and hasn't.... have her see if she can print the list through the tabulatrix on the shelf in the bridge. If there are no living mush, she cannot print the list and the game will tell her so. If she can print it.... maybe better not print it, maybe hold the list until a third mush is killed (or cured) and then have her see if she can print it then.... cause maybe there's even a 4th mush or more.

Three, and harder... just keep track of the human things people do. Getting sick is uniquely human; so is eating two things in the same cycle. Slowly identify the humans, and hopefully everyone is proven human over time. Pheromodem can help ensure more conversions never occur; they surely won't happen secretly.
On september 4, 2014
npfan

Once Pheromodem is complete, people usually pretend to be Mush on the Mush channel for fun since it's well understood by most players that they're joking.
On september 4, 2014
Matt
ImpetFor one, you mentioned someone got a spore as shown on the mush channel? Was that from before or after the second mush died? If after, did it come from a trapped shelf or an edible, or from direct spiking? Direct spiking means you have a live mush for sure. The other two could be from a spore that was placed before the mush making it died.

The spike was from a trapped shelf before the second mush died, and the mush channel actually had a warning from before the 1st mush died that they had trapped a particular room.

One of the "human" players has since taken credit for the comment, stating that it was just to confuse people. I think I will just let it go, but use some of your verification suggestions as a failsafe.

Thanks for your help, Impet and Npfan!

On september 8, 2014
Kyubey

Two questions:

1) If person has broken rules on the current ship (holding weapons/extinguisher before mush selection), then was quarantined for his previous ship, is there any reason to report him for that ship. or his punishment is already given and cannot become longer?

2) If the ship was won by few active humans - they found and killed mushes, then repaired PILGRED (optional - were killing hunters/do repairs) can they decide to finish the game when they want, ignoring unskilled "cargo"-players who log in around once a day (while playing characters like Jin Su, not Ian), spend ap very inefficiently, cannot be trusted to deal with emergencies in time and so on.
On september 8, 2014
[6826491]
Kyubey

Two questions:

1) If person has broken rules on the current ship (holding weapons/extinguisher before mush selection), then was quarantined for his previous ship, is there any reason to report him for that ship. or his punishment is already given and cannot become longer?

You can still report the player for their actions on your ship, and you should. You don't know what they did to get quarantined.
2) If the ship was won by few active humans - they found and killed mushes, then repaired PILGRED (optional - were killing hunters/do repairs) can they decide to finish the game when they want, ignoring unskilled "cargo"-players who log in around once a day (while playing characters like Jin Su, not Ian), spend ap very inefficiently, cannot be trusted to deal with emergencies in time and so on.
In general, yes you can, with one major caveat: Make sure the return decision is well discussed and voted on before you do so. Sometimes the people who barely participate/communicate cause avoidable problems because they don't keep up with the events on the ship, and the most active players still have to deal with the brunt of the external problems.

Basically, they still have a say, but if they've been given plenty of time to weigh in, and they don't make their opinion known, then their opinion doesn't count for much when the time comes to return.
On september 8, 2014
Kyubey

You can still report the player for their actions on your ship, and you should. You don't know what they did to get quarantined.
I did, it's not difficult to click on button and write few words. Just intreresting - how he will see that. Would he just see message "judges changed their mind, not 3 days for you, but 30" or he will be killed on next ship again, or punishments don't stack at all.
On september 8, 2014
Elentari

i get no answer to my post /question...so again :

on my last ship we had a griefer. but we must wait until the end, if he is really one, because we did not know, if he transfered. so the game is over and he was really human ..no transfer. he killed hua and try to kill chun. of course we all thought he is mush an he had transfered to another person. ...so we killed all which were in the near of him...
so my question now....is there a possibility to report a player if the game is over.
On september 8, 2014
Rain

Elentari: You can report a player until you confirm your last words. So you can report once dead, from the ship end page. If you've already confirmed your death, it is too late, and you will just have to hope someone else reported.
On september 8, 2014
SummerMcLovin

As Rain said, you can report them by checking the ship through your Mush Profile before sending your last words. Be sure to check their character logs for "swapped bodies with" or "left your host body".
However, if there's someone who has rampaged or griefed in some way and turns out to be human, you can still report them straight away. The SDF will be able to see that they were Mush while rampaging so they are clear, and they can also see that you thought they were a griefer and won't be punished for the "false" report.
On september 8, 2014
Elentari
