On september 14, 2014
[6826491]

The forum is not the place to discuss your sanction. If you want to appeal a sanction, you contact the Mush Moderator Inbox, here. That is the only place that is appropriate for discussion of sanctions and quarantines. You must not use the forum to appeal/complain about it, because the details are NOT up for public discussion. I have deleted the relevant posts.
On september 14, 2014
Dzanek

Is it against the rules if I go to storage and inactive in order to be sold? I know suicide is sanctionable, but it isn't death. You also help your team.
On september 14, 2014
npfan

If the only way your team survives is by sacrificing yourself to be traded, that's fine. Otherwise, it's a combination of XP farming, suicide, and playing against your team.
On september 14, 2014
[6826491]

It's a form of surrender, as well. You're not supposed to volunteer to be traded, unless the alternative is the loss of the ship. You "think" you're helping your team, but you would be more help to them as an active player. Furthermore, if it's a case where you know you're going to go inactive within the first week or so of joining a ship, then DON'T JOIN A SHIP.
On september 14, 2014
Dzanek

What if I'm Mush and my partner is comms officer and there's PILGRED to buy? Sacrifing to Mush return to Sol.
On september 14, 2014
[7950824]
PatrykSzczescieWhat if I'm Mush and my partner is comms officer and there's PILGRED to buy? Sacrifing to Mush return to Sol.

Set it up really well first. Remember that the comms officer is rarely the Commander too, so the command terminal would need to be hacked, and all the ship will see that Pilgred is suddenly there and you are suddenly not, as well as the death of a mush. Much confusion, but not that hard to sort out what happened, and worse, who else must be mush and need to be gone after.

If you make a plan with your partner that handles these details (and they are surmountable) so that your team wins in a way that includes your being sold to make it happen, and someone reported your actions, I don't see that as a sanctionable action. There are very few rules which have no circumstantial modifiers (the terms of service rules are one. Not holding ship items before mush selection is another) which is why judges review ship records before assigning sanctions.
On september 16, 2014
Morgaine

We all know that life can happen and take you away from Mush midship.. So, if you've joined a ship D1, then discover a day or so later you are going to a funeral D5 and would be offline for 2 or even 3 days.... then would in those circumstances, be a good idea to go to storage for trading purposes.

This sort of situation arose for me in January before trading, but I was picked as a mush so discussed at length with my partner about strategies. I rampaged before I left to catch my coach, and also put a spore on someone... so that pilgred could be finished and mush return to sol.
On september 16, 2014
[6826491]

That's a situation that was completely unplanned, and therefore much more understandable. The SDF's issue is not with people who have something unexpected come up like that, and then make it a point to explain the situation to the people on their ship. We actually appreciate it, because under most cases like that, people typically aren't going to file reports..unless the person comes back and griefs the ship, or if they have to kill them because of crucial items being held, etc.

Major note: We highly discourage people from lying about a serious illness or death, etc. to cover for Mushy inactivity. It's not cool to use a reason that garners genuine sympathy to buy time for a rampage...especially if that act causes people to disbelieve people on future ships who genuinely have to take time away from the game because of those exact reasons. File this one under "Lines Mush shouldn't cross" - there are plenty of other excuses that one can use to justify being away from the game. You can also file it under "don't be an asshole", if you like.

Our issue with this sort of inactivity is with people who know they're about to be away for a few days, but join a ship anyway. The prime example here would be people about to go on a vacation; we don't expect people to be glued to their computers while away on a vacation, but it's also kind of selfish to jump on a ship a few days before a vacation. I've been on ships where someone joins, only to say something like, "I'm going to be away for several days, on a vacation." Aside from the obvious implications of having one less active player, it also makes the person sound like an XP farmer. One day - maybe even two - might not be so bad, but on one ship, there was someone who said they were going to be away for two weeks, and they could probably only check in once every few days! (Needless to say, we let them die naturally; this was prior to trading inactives as an option.)

That goes back to my post on the previous page: If you know for certain within the next week (or so) that you will be gone for a few days, then don't join a ship yet. It's really that simple.
On september 16, 2014
[8296864]

Is it considered as a mush test to ask someone to dump 16:pa: in research by giving them a ration? (I would imagine Chun asking this of Andie or of a generalist). It doesn't have to be artificial, since it's good for humans to rush AG or constipaspore serum.
To be more precise: if the person refuses, is it ok to kill them even if there's no other reason to think they're mush?

PS: I know about phagocyte, but it happens more often than never that Andie doesn't visit a shower dorm after mush selection, so the crew can be sure they don't have spores.
On september 16, 2014
1412

I'm gonna hazard a guess and say killing someone just for refusing such a thing would not be all right at all.
On september 16, 2014
[6826491]
zeebok

Is it considered as a mush test to ask someone to dump 16:pa: in research by giving them a ration? (I would imagine Chun asking this of Andie or of a generalist). It doesn't have to be artificial, since it's good for humans to rush AG or constipaspore serum.
To be more precise: if the person refuses, is it ok to kill them even if there's no other reason to think they're mush?

PS: I know about phagocyte, but it happens more often than never that Andie doesn't visit a shower dorm after mush selection, so the crew can be sure they don't have spores.

That's effectively a Mush test...and any person who is asked always has the right to refuse to be tested. Furthermore, if refusing to test themselves is the only evidence you have against them, then killing them is unjustified, and is indeed sanctionable.

If you DO have compelling evidence already, and a Mush test is your last ditch effort to clear them of suspicion, then it's fair to kill them if they should refuse. (In that case, the refusal isn't the reason for killing them, which is why it's justifiable.) Of course, asking someone to Mush test themselves can trigger a rampage/transfer/stealing of items and the Pasiphae...
On september 16, 2014
Kyubey

You can ask, but not force, anyway can refuse. If you see the was no reason to refuse - like "oh, before going to lab I had an idea to try to repair door and failed 10 times" - then killing is quite ok. But if he says like "I don't want to wait full ap, I have 8 now, will use 8 now and I will eat later" or something like that - you have totally no reason to kill.

If a human constantly laughs new players out and harass them, till they get inactive because of that, is that reportable?
On september 17, 2014
[6826491]
MephitioIf a human constantly laughs new players out and harass them, till they get inactive because of that, is that reportable?

It is. Harassment is very much reportable. If someone is creating a hostile environment, to the point where it's causing people to abandon the game...it should be reported. RP is not a valid excuse in cases like this, either.
On september 17, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Is it sanctionable if a player convinces newbies who get selected as mush to oust themselves with a post like this

The tips of mush for newbies (title of thread)
insert generic tips here
If you're mush be sure to tell us as you play a very special role on this ship

or is falling for that just stupid?
On september 17, 2014
[6826491]

Don't try to get the newbies to break the rules. If they become griefers because they were taught wrong, that will have far reaching implications not just for them, but for people on their future ships.

It's one thing to manipulate them into killing someone innocent (feeding the paranoia, so to speak.) It's another to suggest that they out themselves, because that's incitation to spoil the game.
On september 18, 2014
Irishpolak

Is it necessarily playing against one's team if the majority of the crew decides to cure a mush and you go alone and kill the mush? Say that mush is your only technician or pilot or shrink. Especially if the crew had made plans to meet at a specific cycle to rush the cure and inject it into the mush (and you were privy to those plans).

(Probably should have asked this before submitting a report, but I was a bit livid at the time)
On september 18, 2014
[6826491]

That could be considered playing against the team, especially if the plans were in place long before the murder was committed, AND there was no immediate threat to prompt that action. We'd have to look at the logs, though.
On september 18, 2014

On september 18, 2014
[6826491]

On september 18, 2014
npfan

Keep in mind that someone may have acted because they don't use the chat much or whatever. There would have to be clear evidence someone killed the Mush in order to hurt the humans. You can't force any one player to do what you want even if there is a clear majority.
On september 18, 2014
[6826491]

If they acknowledged the plan, and didn't argue against it...then they'd need to show that that there was an imminent threat to justify making the kill. I'll grant that players may panic in a situation like that, but as I said, we'll have to look at the logs to be sure.
On september 18, 2014
[7950824]

It's also probably a pretty good idea to make the supporting details that already existed when the kill happened as clear as possible.

When making the report, it's probably more helpful to report the thread where that player agreed to the plan of curing the mush, or where that player was involved in the debate, or at least where the plan was discussed, then it would be to connect that thread to say, the death message of the mush.

The important part for the judges to understand is not if the mush was killed or not (and that's easy to tell if happened), but instead what the circumstances are that show why that killing may have broken rules.

It could be useful if the plan was discussed in multiple threads or with a lot of other interspersed information, to describe and sum up what you feel the evidence is, and list where that evidence can be found if it's scattered across many threads.
On september 21, 2014

On september 21, 2014
[6826491]
Cagnols

sorry if asking something allready discussed, but just for be sure about Team rules:

1) If a Mush figgured out he was got it (100% corridor room log, hidden mycoalarm, not see camera or eleesha observant,...), do he must rampage/transfer or could wait for the serum without any harmfull actions? (and change if he's the last mush on the ship?)

2) if humans figgured out a 100% mush. did they must kill him or save? or just understand what is better for the ship?

3) when ex-mush is cured, could him betray the old mushes allies, saying who they are, how many spores infected,...?

(probably unpopolar, but i would kill mush allways and anyway no matter if they are Raluca, Janice, or other essential player. and on other hand, i would rampage allways if figgured out as mush...)

1) Mush don't have to Transfer or rampage, but they MUST resist being cured. No Mush can ever want to be cured. If they just wait to be cured, it can be considered a form of surrender.

2. They CAN kill the Mush, but if they can rush the serum and cure the Mush safely, they should try to do that instead. One more active person can make the difference toward reaching Eden. Of course, if they can't cure the Mush quickly, killing the Mush before they can convert someone or rampage is your best bet. Whatever you decide, discuss it first.

3. See my post here.
On september 22, 2014
[1757645]

On a note on 2: They should avoid letting the MUSH know that the cure is finished.

Since MUSH can't allow themselves to be cured, letting them know it's done forces them to act.
The mods might also see a MUSH not doing anything after the serum is finished as wanting to be cured, so it's best to ambush them with it.

At least in my opinion.
On september 22, 2014
Cwovictor

If the mush are supposed to resist, it is okay if a mush finishes the research, and injects it into a confirmed human? They would probably have their cover blown but they could just rampage then.
On september 22, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Of course it's okay, and their cover wouldn't necessarily be blown. They can inject it into an inactive human and take Anonymush. Or inject it into a random human and claim they have "cured" their partner, and then one of them takes Anonymush. Injecting the serum is completely invisible, unless you use it on a real mush (and even then, only the cured mush sees anything). So nobody can know what you did with the serum after you pick it up.
On september 22, 2014
Dzanek

1. Is it against the rules if you pick totally useless skill, for example Optimist for Roland or Opportunist for Stephen, or use Apprentice for useless skill?
2. Can you read Mage Book without consulting with crew. What if it's important Mage Book, for example Shrink or Technician, if there's no shrinks nor technicians?
On september 22, 2014
[4950627]
PatrykSzczescie1. Is it against the rules if you pick totally useless skill, for example Optimist for Roland or Opportunist for Stephen, or use Apprentice for useless skill?
2. Can you read Mage Book without consulting with crew. What if it's important Mage Book, for example Shrink or Technician, if there's no shrinks nor technicians?

1. It isn't against the rules on its own.
2. You can, however the crew will probably find you very suspicious, so its probably best to prove your humanity before you try it.
On september 22, 2014
Dzanek
RedTiger2. You can, however the crew will probably find you very suspicious, so its probably best to prove your humanity before you try it.

What if I read the important Mage Book without proving my humanity before? If IT Expert, Firefighter, Pilot... I understand. But what if, as I mentioned, Shrink or Technician - if I'm the most needed then?
On september 22, 2014
Rain
PatrykSzczescie1. Is it against the rules if you pick totally useless skill, for example Optimist for Roland or Opportunist for Stephen, or use Apprentice for useless skill?
2. Can you read Mage Book without consulting with crew. What if it's important Mage Book, for example Shrink or Technician, if there's no shrinks nor technicians?

It really depends on the player's other actions, and motivation. Maybe they're a new player who doesn't know mage books are a one time use thing, or that picking one skill over another as sole skill will make their ship more difficult. There are other legitimate reasons for these actions. You can't really expect other players to always try to play in an optimal manner or even know what that would look like.

What you can expect is that regardless of whether or not someone has a sub-optimal skill or reads your skill book without discussion or whatnot - is that that player will still be trying to work towards the good of their team, overall. We can't always tell motivation, but we can look at the overall actions of a player, their words and deeds to see if they were an overall negative impact or positive. We can also see their experience level, to gauge whether it is likely that odd behavior/choices are honest mistakes or attempts to troll ships.

An experienced player has a lot less leeway than a new one when it comes to things like this, but the above still applies.
On september 22, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescie1. Is it against the rules if you pick totally useless skill, for example Optimist for Roland or Opportunist for Stephen, or use Apprentice for useless skill?
2. Can you read Mage Book without consulting with crew. What if it's important Mage Book, for example Shrink or Technician, if there's no shrinks nor technicians?

1. If you're an experienced player, you wouldn't do this for the benefit of your team. It may not be sanctionable on its own, but if your other actions on the ship lead you to hurt your team, then it's definitely a strike against you if you get reported.

2. You CAN, however that does not mean that you should. People can get killed for doing that, especially if it's a skill they have no intention of using, or if it's a skill they'll never have the AP to use. This is one of the reasons that experienced players discuss who gets to read the book, and often enough, those people are confirmed humans.

Case in point, I was on a ship with a Jin Su who read the Medic book we got. He didn't tell anyone he was going to read it, and he didn't bother to prove his humanity before doing so. I was seriously injured, bleeding out, and I even had to punch Chun out of the Medlab bed to try and save myself. What did Jin do? He knew I was injured, and said he'd try to help...but he walked right through medlab, and intentionally made no attempt to even heal me, much less perform surgery. He quite literally let me die, when he was the person on the ship with the best chance of saving me.

When the player has been around long enough to know that Mage books are a consumable, and they then deny the rest of the crew the use of that skill, it reflects very badly on them as a player, and it could be seen as an act of griefing - not on its own, perhaps, but in the case of the Jin Su from my ship, that wasn't the only thing he did that created a negative environment.

Don't be selfish, like that like that Jin. Even if you absolutely need someone with that skill, have the respect and courtesy to have a discussion about it first, and work with your crew; someone might be a better candidate than you for that book.
On september 22, 2014
Kyubey

2) My opinion - if you are experienced player, if you are human and if you are sure you will be active and use it often - just read the book without discussion. Just tell other about that after. "Meta" right now is to wait with the book, not using it at all, "while mushes are alive", so you don't risk to give it to mush....So you have options - to wait very long without team having a skill at all with "discussion", or to read yourself and use it for human team.
It's totally wrong to take the book, when you have no need in it (like you have already pilot job, you don't need biologist), or you are not active for a job (you log once a day and read tech) or just unskilled to use it properly. But a human (and you can be sure of yourself) who uses skill is always much better then book being held/hiden (or even just lie on shelf, waiting to unskilled/mush to waste it, how very ofter happens).
On september 22, 2014
Dzanek

Could you include that you might be infected or transferred? You lose this skill from Mage Book after transferring, don't you?
On september 22, 2014
[6826491]

On most of my ships, discussions over the mage book distribution have happened. In the vast majority of those ships, mage books were distributed to people before the Mush hunt was over. It doesn't have to wait until the hunt is over, though the risk of conversion is certainly a valid reason to wait on some ships.

My take on it: Try to have that discussion before reading it, and if you're an active, confirmed human, that should make the case for you reading the book an easier one...assuming you're also someone who can effectively make use of the skill. These aren't requirements, by any means; they're general guidelines. If the crew agrees to let you read the book, make sure you make use of the skill, so they don't ever regret that decision. (It's one thing if you become Mush after reading it; but if you're human, you shouldn't ever waste a Mage book.)
On september 22, 2014
Dzanek
SpazticusCase in point, I was on a ship with a Jin Su who read the Medic book we got. He didn't tell anyone he was going to read it, and he didn't bother to prove his humanity before doing so. I was seriously injured, bleeding out, and I even had to punch Chun out of the Medlab bed to try and save myself. What did Jin do? He knew I was injured, and said he'd try to help...but he walked right through medlab, and intentionally made no attempt to even heal me, much less perform surgery. He quite literally let me die, when he was the person on the ship with the best chance of saving me.

Good story. I know which ship you mean. Once you told that if someone is reported, he'll be quarantined after his current ship. Why did you quarantine Jin Su in that ship?
On september 22, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieGood story. I know which ship you mean. Once you told that if someone is reported, he'll be quarantined after his current ship.

You misunderstood. If a person is reported on their current ship, the judges can't see the logs until after the ship is finished. Sanctions (and quarantines) are only applied after the logs are reviewed, true - but the ship on which they were reported has already ended.

Why did you quarantine Jin Su in that ship?
I didn't. 1. Because of the reasons I already gave, and 2. SDF members are explicitly forbidden from judging reports from ships on which they were present. It doesn't matter if we file a report, were the subject of a report, or filed no reports while on that ship. Our intimate knowledge of the events on the ship automatically prevents us from being impartial, and we don't ever judge those reports.

Furthermore: If someone has one or more reports against them from a previous ship (or ships)...then those reports can be reviewed by judges, and sanctions may be applied. That's why some people who get quarantined can have it happen on a ship on which they haven't broken any rules. The reason this is the case is so that all of a ship's logs can be reviewed, in their entirety; it's already over, so no new events can influence the decisions of the judges.
On september 23, 2014
Dzanek

I'm a pilot, sleeping 6 cycles and another pilot hit me, claiming my bed because, as he said, "I've made nothing for 16 hours." There's no free beds. I hit him and claimed bed just before cycle change, but he hit me again after cycle change and threated me that if I hit him again, he'll kill me. What can I do, without breaking rules?
On september 23, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

This game is based on communication, and the best way to communicate is talking, not hitting each other. When you have a problem in real life with someone, you don't punch them, you talk first.

You said yourself that you had slept for 6 cycles, which means that you had full AP and did not need the bed. The other pilot could have asked first, but maybe he thought that you weren't online or that it was too close to cycle change and you wouldn't see his message in time. Hitting someone to get a bed when you need it isn't an aggressive gesture in most cases, especially when that person doesn't need the bed (because they had full AP, like you, or because they're not active enough) and when you need it more than them (pilots usually get priority for beds since they need lots of AP).

So the first thing is that you shouldn't have hit him. You didn't need the bed, he did. If you didn't like his method, you could have said it instead of punching. Just tell him that next time, he should ask first and wait to see if you let him have the bed before cycle change.

You should also ask someone else to let you have a bed next time you need AP. Or ask the commander to order someone with a less AP-consuming job to give you their bed.
On september 23, 2014
Dzanek

1. He punched me about an hour after cycle change, not close to the end.
2. I asked him why he claimed my bed. 45 minutes waiting, no answer, then I hit him because it was about a minute to cycle change.
3. He hit me just after cycle change, 10 minutes later.

EDIT:// And I noticed he hadn't asked me, talked about claiming the bed after hitting me.
On september 23, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

So... ? What's done is done.

You have a choice now : either keep on punching each other, wasting AP, hurting each other (and over a bed that you don't even need, since you don't need a bed and you certainly don't need that bed). Or behave like civilized adults, let him have the bed, and ask someone else (not a pilot) to give you their bed when you need AP. As I said, you can also ask the commander to make the decision.

On september 29, 2014
[6826491]

It's not sanctionable to take a suboptimal skill, on its own. However, a suboptimal skill choice is often the first sign of someone being a griefer, especially when it's clear that they have more experience. Consider this before you do anything "out of being bored".
On september 29, 2014
[7950824]

There's a difference between 'I did this because I felt bored' and 'I did this because I have decided to help the ship one way versus another way'.

There's even the awesome 'I did this because I talked over the circumstances with my shipmates, and we agreed that doing it this way is best for this ship'

I see a distinct difference in how the idea of picking sprinter was introduced, the first reason given for it, and the second. I really wish Patrick would put more effort into trying to communicate clearly and honestly, and effort into not appearing like he's trying to be a person making bad choices, or effort into trying to appear like he's making choices for bad reasons, that when challenged he corrects and claims are for more acceptable reasons.

It's really a waste of time the way it's being done.

[4950627]

On september 30, 2014
npfan
PatrykSzczescieCan I also pick optimist because there's nobody who helps me with morale?

You may choose Optimist if you have good reason to do so. You may not choose not to have certain skills to hurt your team. For example, citing a real case, a Chun cannot purposefully choose not to have Mankind's Only Hope to give humans a harder time.

It has less to do with what skills you actually choose or don't choose, and more to do with why you choose the skills you have chosen.

[6826491]
FlashThis has probably been answered before but is it against the neutral play rules to dismantle one of the showers before Mush selection?

No, it's considered fair game.What about the dismantling of other items such as blasters or the knife for scrap metal or safety (assuming parts of the crew wants the technician to)?Not explicitly; there's no specific rule against doing so, but I wouldn't suggest doing so without the explicit consent of the active crew. The problem with dismantling weapons without the consent of the crew is that it can easily be seen as a griefing move.
On october 4, 2014
Flash
SpazticusNo, it's considered fair game.Not explicitly; there's no specific rule against doing so, but I wouldn't suggest doing so without the explicit consent of the active crew. The problem with dismantling weapons without the consent of the crew is that it can easily be seen as a griefing move.

Alright thank you for the answer.

On october 12, 2014
Dzanek

On october 12, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, you could potentially report Chun, for killing the cat. Note that this is only if you felt that she was intending to grief by doing so. If it's obvious that she's a newbie, and acting on incorrect information (that Raluca won't lose morale if the cat dies) then Chun would probably be cleared.

As for the person who gave Chun incorrect information, they could also be reported for incitation to spoil the game, IF they KNEW that Raluca would lose morale when the cat died, and gave Chun false information - even if they're Mush. The reason for this is that Mush aren't allowed to mislead newbies so that the newbies break the rules...such as telling a newbie to "kill anyone who is dirty, because they might be Mush." While there is a tiny bit of truth to that statement (namely that dirty people might be Mush,) it can also lead to someone creating a murdership based on the flawed logic of that assumption.

It is possible that the person who gives Chun this false information doesn't know better, and that's why we investigate if it's reported.
On october 12, 2014
Dzanek

Mush can't mislead the newbies into breaking the rules.

On october 12, 2014
Syvaris

So say that Paola and someone else are battling it out real time, and they are out to kill each other. Paola then makes a general announcement of no meaning just to lag the other person out. Is this sanctionable?
On october 12, 2014
npfan
PatrykSzczescieSo if Ian was Mush, she could have misled Chun to kill the cat. He wouldn't do it as pacifist because it requires much AP snd he couldn't have been injured. His aim was to do all to kill Raluca and how would the Mush feel if it said "Comfort Raluca because it may kill her". The Mush saying it should do

A Mush Ian doesn't have to tell Chun that killing the cat can kill Raluca. If a Mush only told Chun that the cat could be infected and should be killed, and Chun kills the cat, that is perfectly fine. If a Mush tries to get Chun to kill the cat, and Chun asks what would happen if the cat is killed, and the Mush lies that nothing will happen, that is sanctionable. On the other hand, if the Mush acknowledges that killing the cat will cause Raluca to lose 4 morale, but then lies that Raluca has enough morale to survive, and Chun decides to kill the cat, that is also perfectly fine. The key point is that Mush can claim something that might be true, but may not be. However, the Mush cannot take advantage of a player's lack of knowledge of the game and claim something that is never true.

SyvarisSo say that Paola and someone else are battling it out real time, and they are out to kill each other. Paola then makes a general announcement of no meaning just to lag the other person out. Is this sanctionable?

That's fine.

On october 16, 2014
[8191055]

Moved here by suggestion on Q&A...

I understand suicide is against the rules. However, I have a quick question on one particular scenario where the rules for playing effectively as Mush conflict with this: Assume you are a Mush with low HP (due to various circumstances). You are aware that the crew has figured out you are the Mush, or will within the next few cycles, and have the Retro-Fungal serum to use on you. Now, according to rules for playing as Mush, being cured must be avoided by all means nessicery. Pilot Lock is on, so fleeing with vital items (which aren't very vital by his point in the journey), is not viable option with AP reserves. You do, however, have enough AP to basically insure you can kill a human or do a solid amount of damage to the ship if you rampage/set fires like crazy. In such as case, would it be sanctinable for you to suicide yourself by showering with your last AP, to prevent the humans from getting you for their side? This is the most likely to cause maximum damage to the human team, but is technically killing yourself.
On october 16, 2014
[7950824]

For any mush who understands that they are about to die or lose: Do the most damage possible. That never includes showering yourself to death - doing that even saves the crew the AP to kill or cure you.

If the cure has been made, who has it? Do what you can to kill or control them. If you can kill the person with the cure and then pick up that cure, even if you lack the AP to use it to destroy it (maybe you have allies, or maybe you've used roomtrap or fungal kitchen in a way that though all the mush may be gone once you die... there may be future allies on this ship) the humans still cannot use that serum until they kill you. Make them kill you. Fight them to the end, and make that end as expensive as possible.

Can transfer be used to muddy the water? Muddy that water, with blood if possible. Pick your transfer target based on the harm losing that body/the harm you can do with that body, be it get around pilot locking or anything else you can think of. You have a few AP to use to try and kill someone? Use it, try to kill someone, be absolutely as effective as you can. Make curing or killing you be absolutely as expensive as possible.

If you shower to death and are reported for suicide, if I am judging your case, I'm going to look at everything I can find that you seem to know. And I'm going to count the AP you spent on that shower, and look at any AP you died with, and think about what you could have done. I'm going to think about the AP the humans didn't have to spend killing or curing you, and I'm probably going to agree, yes, that player had options. They could have made their death more expensive for the humans, but they didn't, and they did the one thing under their control that ensured that they died without any further cost to the humans. That sure sounds like surrender to me.
On october 16, 2014
ZaphodBeeblbrox

Also if you have an important role in an average ship... in my example, I was Andie with Pilot/Polyvalent, which meant that dying meant they lacked biologist, diplomat and one pilot less.
Also they lost one damn fine active player
That counts for suicide too, I think

On october 17, 2014
[4950627]

If I was a mush in this scenario,you have two choices.
A) try to do some damage to the humans but you fail to do very much and they get another active human.

B) do the above but save the last few AP to kill yourself so the crew doesn't gain another crew member while also doing some damage

I would go for B here.
On october 17, 2014
[6826491]
RedTiger

If I was a mush in this scenario,you have two choices.
A) try to do some damage to the humans but you fail to do very much and they get another active human.

B) do the above but save the last few AP to kill yourself so the crew doesn't gain another crew member while also doing some damage

I would go for B here.

You still aren't allowed to kill yourself via the shower, etc. because it will probably be reported as a pathetic suicide. Even if they have the Serum, some crews will kill a Mush who rampages, rather than curing them. You don't know that they'll use the cure on you regardless of what you do, so taking yourself out isn't the best option, nor is it an option that the SDF can endorse.

It IS viable to openly spike someone as part of your rampage, if you can Transfer and do more damage. Yes, it's revealing yourself, and you'll probably die trying, but at the same time, you're presumably in a position to deal out more damage to the humans.
On october 17, 2014
BadBlanket

Every self-respecting Mush should get transfer eventually. If you feel that they're working on the cure to use specifically on you because you feel your cover is blown, nothing is stopping you from showering until you're hurt, transferring into a pilot, killing your old body with a punch or two and escaping with important equipment. It's a low form of play but you would be doing your mushly duty. Sometimes, you can't avoid being serum'd, rampage. The doctors at the psychiatric hospital may stick you with the tranquilizer but you can at least give them something to remember you by. Hell, you can even form 2 spores and put them in an important pill. Never know if that person is going to go on a cristallite expo later, Polyvalent Andies are good targets. There's no rule that says you have to tell everything you did as mush. You just had your personality ripped and rearranged, it's traumatic. At least I think there's no rule, right? You don't have to tell where everything is trapped upon being serum'd, right?

I think some cases it is preferable to die as who you are, because you're causing them more damage that way.

On october 17, 2014
[6826491]
BadBlanketThe doctors at the psychiatric hospital may stick you with the tranquilizer but you can at least give them something to remember you by. Hell, you can even form 2 spores and put them in an important pill. Never know if that person is going to go on a cristallite expo later, Polyvalent Andies are good targets. There's no rule that says you have to tell everything you did as mush. You just had your personality ripped and rearranged, it's traumatic. At least I think there's no rule, right? You don't have to tell where everything is trapped upon being serum'd, right?

I agree with the rest of your post, but: If you are cured, you MAY say nothing, but you are specifically forbidden from lying. If they ask you if you are the last Mush, you can't lie about it. If they ask you to reveal any plans/traps, and you give an answer, it has to be a truthful one. You can't be intentionally deceptive about it. So your suggestion to spore a pill will probably backfire.

(If there are other Mush, and they act entirely on their own *after** you got converted, that's slightly different, assuming you had no prior knowledge of their plans. E.g. you can't exactly be blamed for a rampage after being cured, when the plan up to that point had been a slow conversion process.)

That said: If you're intending on giving them half-truths, or withhold crucial information, then you're inevitably playing against your team. I'd rather a cured Mush say nothing, rather than tell me they're the last one left, but NOT tell me about a triple spored pill, for example. You're human now, so that's why saying nothing is permitted, but not holding back information if you do give them anything. As a human, you can't want for them to be converted, much less try to convert yourself.
On october 17, 2014
DarkTheRaven

So Spazticus what you're saying is:
if you're cured either give the full details or give them an ambiguous answer ie: are they any trapped shelves, say either: "yes the one in RC" or just "yes there are"

Cause that doesn't seem right to me, just correct me if i'm wrong
On october 17, 2014
[6826491]

Whatever answers you give must be 100% true. If you're going to say anything at all, then don't hold back, because any lie you tell could get you sanctioned. You can think of it as being an all or nothing situation. Be 100% truthful, or say nothing. Just know that there are risks to your continued existence if you say nothing. A cured Mush CAN choose to say nothing at all (e.g. "I don't remember.",) and that is within the rules. The human team CAN kill a Mush who does so, however. They can also kill you if you talked. but purposely withheld crucial information, like the existence of an Anonymush you clearly knew about, a triple spored pill, etc.
On october 17, 2014
[7950824]

I once had a ship with a cured mush Janice, who chose to tell us that there were no mush left. Like five or six days after her cure, the mush channel lit up - someone had gotten a spore from a room trap. There was brief panic; Janice told us that she had made some room traps but she didn't remember where anymore and didn't remember if they had been triggered before or after her cure. When the game ended, everyone expected to be human was; that must have been a roomtrap that she had forgotten about or possibly even one her partner had made and never told her about. I didn't report her for that lapse of memory, even though it seemed likely that she, not her partner, put that spore there.

Technically, you are allowed to say "There are roomtraps, but I don't know or don't remember where they are", but that's really walking a finer line, unless that is true. The reason why it is permissible not to talk is because some players feel it ruins the mush hunt to just give the whole team away because one player who knew everything is converted to the mush team. So if you feel like you're ruining the game by talking about what you knew as a mush before you were cured; don't talk about it. You may be killed, but you won't be sanctioned (note, if you did break rules, you could be sanctioned for those broken rules, but you won't be sanctioned for not revealing mush information after being cured). Conversely, if you feel like it's fine to talk about what you know, talk about it.

If you are a cured mush, regardless of if you choose to talk about what you knew as a mush or not - you are now human and must now play as a human, working for human goals. That means that if you know where traps are or a spored food item, you are absolutely forbidden to go get yourself converted. If you become a mush again, it had better be from some glorious mush play done by the remaining mush, without your knowledge and against your will. It absolutely is reportable, and considered extremely pathetic surrender/giving up to purposefully become a mush if you are human. Such things are likely to receive strong sanctions.

This could put you in a few types of difficult situations. Lets say that before you become cured, you put 4 spores into a 3 AP pill, expecting that a human will someday eat it, but then the humans cure you. You are allowed to not tell them if there are other mush, and not tell them about that pill - but you are absolutely not allowed to go eat it yourself, and I would strongly frown on you encouraging anyone to eat it for any reason, even a gentle reminder that there's a 3 AP pill in medlab. You personally have knowledge of what that pill is and means for the human and mush teams. There is no escape or leeway in that. You are now human, and if you choose not to reveal that there are or are not other mush alive, or that there are or are not means for converting to mush still in play, you absolutely must play to remain human and achieve a human win.

I wish to stress that this 'apparent exception' of the freedom of a cured mush to speak or not about their mush-play knowledge is a unique area where the rules specifically say the SDF will not make judgements about this choice of a cured mush, unless that mush lies. This is not an exception, it is not a precedent, it is a fully defined unique category that has its own specific set of rules. It is not appropriate to look at this unique category and decide 'well, in this case a human can play against the human team, so I will play against the human team in other areas and compare that to this to defend my actions' - that is no defense and not acceptable. The case of a cured mush revealing what they know is a unique category, with exact rules to cover it, but those rules to not apply more generally, this is not a fit example of precedent.
On october 17, 2014
Dzanek

- Yes.

- You should work out who is.

No, no, no. You're trying to justify an intentional lie of omission, in a way that MOST CERTAINLY hurts the human team. The rule here boils down to, you say nothing. or you say everything. None of this passive aggressive "I'm telling you there's Mush, but I'm not going to say who" bullshit. What you're suggesting is exploiting the rule to play against the human team, and it will not be allowed.

I also said this: That said: If you're intending on giving them half-truths, or withhold crucial information, then you're inevitably playing against your team.I've told you that you can't do what you suggested, and I've given you the reasons why a cured Mush can't do that. Would you like another forum ban, or are you going to stop arguing with me on this?
On october 17, 2014
Dzanek

1. What if the cured Mush says it and he kills them in his own way?
2. What if he answers "yes" that there are Mush, but when they ask who, he won't answer - just ignoring question?
On october 17, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescie1. What if the cured Mush says it and he kills them in his own way?
2. What if he answers "yes" that there are Mush, but when they ask who, he won't answer - just ignoring question?

1. Killing them immediately would be acceptable, provided that the cured Mush doesn't hold back any other information. Waiting to act would be a problem, because then the cured Mush can be accused of intentionally stalling to help the remaining Mush. The only reason I'd accept an immediate killing of the remaining Mush before they can act, in lieu of saying, "This is who the Mush are", is because it's being demonstrated through their death(s). That said, the cured Mush will still need to state if any Mush remained, to their knowledge.

2. Then the Mush is intentionally holding back information, which they're not allowed to do. They shouldn't pick and choose what knowledge to share, as long as the information they give is the whole truth. If they're asked if any rooms are trapped, and their partner(s) did all the trapping in secret, they can say there are traps, but truthfully say they have no knowledge of where they are. This is not the same thing as choosing to answer one question, but ignore another. The problem with what you're suggesting is this: If they might not be telling the full truth about one aspect of their story, then the humans are left to wonder what other information they're holding back. The end result of this is that the humans can't be sure the cured Mush is now playing for the human team. Do you not see why people would be justified if they report such a player?

On october 17, 2014
[6826491]
RedTigerI have another scenario, if you are mush trying to kill someone like Chun, and you are one bit away from killing her, but you are cured but you haven't refreshed the page so you don't know that and you kill Chun, would you be reported?

The timing would have to be very close for that to even be the case. If it were to happen, and the logs show you were literally in the middle of killing her when it happened, then you'd probably be cleared - assuming it's reported. The page refreshes between attacks, and the Comrades Bar (as well as your room log) will reflect the change. Losing access to the Mush Channel might also be noticed, assuming the human team doesn't have Pheromodem yet.

In short, you'd probably notice being cured...but if it should happen, and someone gets killed anyway, explain yourself immediately.

Kyubey

To kill a player you don't need any discussion with any of crewmembers, you don't need to have very strong proof either. All you need - some kind of information, why you find him as a suspect. While such kills are not recommended, lead to mistakes and sometimes chain of human kills (killer is killed for a kill, then his killer is killer for that kill....), especially if you are not experienced enough, they are not not forbidden. So if you were suspecting Hua in your channel, it's totally normal for KT to act himself in same way.

If you have reason to think X is mush - you can kill him. Even if team has other plans, suspect other players or trust your target. Sometimes one player can be right, when all others are wrong, and talking will be just a waste of time. I had already games, where I was constantly from all genius ideas I saw in the chat, so I just took weapon, said "I'm the law" and when a yellow icon with a skull appeared, I explained why I did that.

On october 23, 2014
[7950824]

If the ship has moved, or moves before they collect it with the Pasiphae, or if the Pasiphae is lost, then yes, items and living players 'lost in space' are lost forever. If they haven't lost the Pasiphae or moved yet, that can be used to collect still-living players or the inventory items that dead-in-space characters dropped on death.

[7950824]

Theory, but however *phero*modem works, well, it's pheromones, smells.

They linger for a time. 8 cycles, to be exact. The technology that decodes and encodes back and forth between 'mush scent' and human understanding, it works as long as the pheromones can be sensed.

Which is why you can use the mush channel, if you can use it at all, even with a smashed tongue. You're actually making those pheromones.

On october 23, 2014
Cwovictor

In the chat, what kind of langauge is allowed? Obviosly, attacking people for whatever reason is not okay, but is there any rule against dropping the eventual F-Word? As long as they don't do so every 5 seconds of course.
On october 23, 2014
[6826491]
CwovictorIn the chat, what kind of langauge is allowed? Obviosly, attacking people for whatever reason is not okay, but is there any rule against dropping the eventual F-Word? As long as they don't do so every 5 seconds of course.

Short answer: Swearing in general, in a stressful situation, is generally okay. So, saying "Fuck, 21 new hunters!" is not going to earn you a sanction.

Swearing at someone, with the intention of continually harassing them, is not okay. If you make it a hostile environment for everyone because one player made a genuine mistake, then we may not be so lenient. Repeated insults over the course of days would be considered harassment, especially when the insults are out of context. Beating a dead horse doesn't help matters.

Let me be clear, though: No matter your intentions, racist, sexist, and homophobic insults will NOT be tolerated, because they violate the site's T&Cs. "Rape" jokes also fall under this category. RP is not an acceptable excuse for rule breaking, so do not cross this line.
On october 23, 2014
Gallade

http://prntscr.com/4z0kjh

In-character jokes are acceptable though, as long as, well, everything said is at least PG-13.

So for example, a Chao mush has infiltrated a mush hunt, they begin suspecting you to a point where they ask you to leave or take a food test, you can deny the test as well as sell out your mush buddy in order to further the mush cause, it is advisable that you bring evidence that humans could come across so it doesnt seem too obvious that you are getting info only a mush could, because if both of you end up dead it might be sanctioned if the other mush reports it
On october 25, 2014
Kyubey

Main rule - do whatever it takes to get a win for your team. All the rest stuff like "don't tell humans you are mush and your partner's name" is just part of that rule, as it will make you killed/cured and mush lost.

Sacrifice yourself if needed, help humans to kill your partner, maybe even kill him yourself.
Every action can be ok, but all depends on your plan and situation. If you are sure it's the most profitable thing to do - then do it.
On october 25, 2014
[8281354]
Kyubey

Main rule - do whatever it takes to get a win for your team. All the rest stuff like "don't tell humans you are mush and your partner's name" is just part of that rule, as it will make you killed/cured and mush lost.

Sacrifice yourself if needed, help humans to kill your partner, maybe even kill him yourself.
Every action can be ok, but all depends on your plan and situation. If you are sure it's the most profitable thing to do - then do it.

And make sure you EXPLAIN your thought process, even if it's in just a PM to yourself. That will cut out a lot of guesswork if you do get reported and the mods have to try to piece together your goals.
On october 27, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Something I've been wondering: if someone reports an issue, and a judge notices something sanctionable outside of the report, will they address it aswell or is it void since it wasnt reported? Assuming it wasn't an absolutely terrible breach of rules
On october 27, 2014
SummerMcLovin

The way the reporting system works means that the SDF can only apply any penalty to the person that is directly reported. If you reported one player for murdering someone without reason but it turned out to be someone else who did it for no reason (say you couldn't see the logs, as perhaps you were killed as well), they couldn't sanction the actual griefer.
On october 27, 2014
[6826491]

Generally speaking, if it's not reported, we don't go after the player in question. That's why we say that if you believe a rule to be broken, you should report it yourself. Even if someone else says they reported it, they don't always do that...and rule breakers may go unpunished.
On october 29, 2014
DarkTheRaven

It's an open chat, theyre not being offensive, just slightly annoying that every time I refresh there's 20 more posts
On october 29, 2014
[7950824]

From what you've described, it's not against the rules, but if it is disturbing you, you can let them know it does, and ask if everyone interested in the conversation would enter a private chat to allow you to avoid it. They don't have to, but they might not mind doing so. It's also possible that the situation causing the high level of conversation may ends soon.

"flooding" the chat is against the rules, but that's frequent posts without content, or frequent posts with content but clearly made with an intention to attempt to prevent normal gameplay or conversation.

On october 29, 2014
Gallade

Question...can I report someone that plays the game, but does absolutely zero communications causing the rest of the crew to waste AP just to double-check on them?

Our Ian has been silent the entire ship, and each day we have to go check the plants because he never announces when he waters or treats them.
On october 29, 2014
[7950824]

There is no rule that one must communicate to play (but if you communicate, it must be in English); there's not even a rule that you have to cooperate with others (but you must not act against your team winning - however you may try to win a different way than what others are discussing; unless your way breaks rules, it is fine to attempt as either human or mush to 'do your own thing' as you progress towards a human win.

Do note that 'winning as a human by jumping the ship back to Sol as soon as possible without discussion and very widespread agreement that the players all wish to return to Sol, when the ship is able to continue' is NOT accepted as a 'different way to win', that is considered a sanctionable act: Hostile return to Sol

Those of us who choose to communicate on our ships and work as a team with others usually appear to enjoy the ships more, and those ships often do better overall for the communicating and working together team. Players who do not speak, but do play, they probably are missing out on some of the fun they could be having - but there is no rule that requires communication or prohibits silence.

It is up to the players on that ship to decide what to do about a player who is not communicating and/or not cooperating. I personally advise you to do your best to consider if you think they are helpful or harmful to your team, and act accordingly. If you are human and you think they are not harming your chances to win, and are probably not mush - it's a bad, bad idea to kill them, because you waste that AP in the kill of a human (if you're right that they are human) and you lose all the AP they were likely to silently spend doing what they did. If you don't kill them, you don't waste your AP in the kill or their AP they are likely to spend in the future helping the human team.

If you see evidence that the silent person is acting to harm the ship, it is allowable to kill them, even if you suspect or know they are human and you are a human. If they are playing harmfully to your team, you may cause less harm in stopping them than in allowing them to continue. Note that it is often best to discuss what to do about them with the communicating shipmates, and get consensus and clearly discuss why the player will be killed - this can be useful to the SDF if you are reported for killing someone 'for no reason'.

It's also up to you if you want to continue periodically opening a PM with a silent player (if possible to open any PMs, maybe through whisper) and talking to them some, offering suggestions, assistance, or asking for help yourself. Probably best to assign one person to do this, if the rest of the ship is working together, so the silent player is not endlessly spammed 'a little by each person'.

As always, you can report anyone you feel is breaking a rule, but it's best to only report people who are breaking rules.
On october 30, 2014

You have to access the BIOS Terminal and set Vocoder Announcements to "Authorised". To do this you either need to be NERON Admin (not necessarily Janice, although she is the default titel-holder) or use the Hacker Kit, but hacking in won't actually allow you to send any messages as NERON.

On november 4, 2014
Voovits

I have a bit of an odd question. My ship did not play out this way but it easily could have and I would liek a rules clarification in case something similar comes up in the future. I was Janice and was converted to mush. It was blatantly obvious as Raluca entered the room I was in and the active crew immediately noticed the extra mush. It was confirmed I was mush now after killing Raluca and she turned out to me a mush.
So as mush naturally I have to try to extend my life cycle as long as possible. They know I am mush, but I'm of course denying it. I hinted to the fact that I would cooperate any way possible, keep my nose clean and help out with morale and stay out of the room with the shower. The humans were talking (to me even) about possibly rushing the cure and turning me back.
Now my offer to cooperate was just so I could buy enough time to build up the AP to make my move (which didn't play out quite as expected!). But if the humans did in fact rush the cure and use it on me before I had a chance to do anything, it would look really bad for me like I was playing against my team because I stated my willingness to cooperate. Nobody would know my real intention because I did not have anyone to talk to about it.
What would happen in a situation like that? I wouldn't want to get in trouble for playing against my team when I really wasn't if the situation played out that way (which it didn't).
On november 4, 2014
Kyubey

You can open a privite chat with just yourself and write everything there - SDF will see it if you will be reported and they review your case.

The big problem with your situation is - it cannot happen unless one of the sides want another to break the rules. If humans offer mush to be cured - they either ask him to break the rules or want to double-cross him. If mush asks to be cure - he either break the rules or want to double-cross humans. So the only situation where it can happen without anybody breaking anything - when both teams are sure their enemies and lying, but think themselves to be smarter. As it also very unclear for new players and can easily make them think mush surrendering is ok...

So do your plan and then post them, that they cannot really deal with mushes.
On november 4, 2014
TeufelsAdvokat

It's always good to write a PM to yourself, if you're about to do questionable things. Best would be to do it in advance like "I'm going to kill xyz, because ...". If that's not possible, at least in retrospect like "I had to kill xyz and the circumstances made it necessary to act fast, so I didn't have time to explain because..." or in your case something like "I haven't done anything against the RFS because I had no AP and would've died otherwise. So I decided to buy some time."

I was told, the judges would consider PMs to yourself and that they could possibly clear you.

Is it wrong to take advantage of humans who may be willing to break the rules (talking to me about possibly giving me the cure) to extend my life longer? I did consider it to be a possibility that they were just saying that to keep me from rampaging as well so I dont know what they were really thinking.
To be clear I never asked for the cure I only stated I would keep my nose clean and would cooperate. In fact I never once came out and admitted to being mush though I know they knew I was lying. It was too obvious.
On november 4, 2014
[7950824]

-You- are not allowed to break the rules, but the rules do not tell you how you must respond to someone else breaking the rules.

We ask you to report the rule breakers, and I really, really hope you do.

But what to do about them in play? ... Don't break the rules yourself, of course, but respond to the person breaking the rules however you see fit.

Like if a player tells one or all humans, "I am a mush, please cure me, my partner is so and so, kill them and cure me. Hurry, that person plans to use the grenade in the lab next cycle and then firestarter, and means to kill chun for sure and break the plants and grav sim if possible."

What do you do with that player? Report her, yes (if she is human or mush, if she is lying or not; either way she has broken rules in what she said). But then you get to decide if you want to kill her, cure her, or whatever you do - and yes you can decide if you kill that partner immediately or not or whatever else you want to do about that information. Unless your decision about what you are going to do breaks the game rules, you can do anything you want in response. You didn't break the rules yourself just to be talked to by someone else breaking the rules, and once you have information (possibly true, possibly false; that could be a human griefer telling you this) you may do what you see fit.

As a mush being offered the cure, if I think there's any chance the humans could be wrong about my conversion, I'd tell them flat out they would be wasting the cure on me. If I had no or low AP and thought I had time to get some, I would wait if I had to. I might go pick up the disk, I might transfer, as Janice I might flip pilot lock to research lock and take their disk and another great item or two off into space to try and get more AP before I land and cause more damage if I'm still alive. Instead of falsely claiming I accept the offer and will cooperate, I would probably stay silent and just collect AP until I could act.

If there is nothing you can do, there is nothing you can do. Judges won't sanction you, even if reported, if you don't break the rules. If you get converted, the humans are sure you were converted because of how you were converted and tell you 'hold on, we'll save you', and the humans use the cure on you before you can get AP enough to even move.... no team of judges is going to call that 'you surrendered'... and if somehow they do, write to the mod inbox and ask about it. Discuss what you did and why with a mod there. The mod will tell you what they think they see happening in the room logs and why it looks like a rule was broken by you - and if there's a misunderstanding, the mod will consider your explanation and see if they agree the rule was actually broken or if there was a misunderstanding.

As long as you are playing to win for your current team at all times, and not breaking other rules, you are very safe in your play.
On november 5, 2014

Stephen says that Roland won't die if they hit the button to return to Sol. Chun thinks that Stephen wants Roland to abandon and kills him being afraid that he could hack into Command Terminal or convince to commander to leave Roland in the space. What would happen to Chun if reported?

On november 5, 2014
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieCopied from wrong thread to the right one.
What would happen if someone kills somebody because the killer wrongly thought that the victim misled?
Example: People are deciding to return to Sol. Roland is going scavenging and he's stuck outside. They decided to return to Sol after Roland returns. Stephen says that Roland won't die if they hit the button to return to Sol. Chun thinks that Stephen wants Roland to abandon and kills him being afraid that he could hack into Command Terminal or convince to commander to leave Roland in the space. What would happen to Chun if reported?

Assuming the ship was already confirmed to be Mush-free, then it would be up to the judges to decide if Chun was acting maliciously or not.

Of course, if Chun were to search the forum, then she'd find that answer - Stephen is telling the truth, since even people currently lost on an expo will return with the ship the moment the return is initiated. Killing Stephen in this example is a rather extreme reaction, and it could lead to a sanction - even if the intent was not to grief, such a killing is still harmful. A bit of patience and a quick forum search could definitively answer whether Chun was being deceived, and ultimately prevent a needless death.

Does that guarantee a sanction? No. Is it still possible to get one, for acting so impulsively, and killing someone needlessly? Oh, definitely yes. Short answer: If you don't believe what someone on your ship is saying, check the forum and wiki, and/or use the IRC to find an answer. I'm usually in there every day to handle such questions, as many players already know.

To echo the other response you just got, let me just make this very clear: Do not ask questions in order to look for loopholes in the rules, or attempt to justify acts that would tread towards potential griefing. "Boredom" is not a valid reason to ask such questions, and it often wastes the mod team's time. Furthermore, it make the person asking look like a griefer, and it will be severely punished. As you have already been banned for "just asking questions" while trolling the forum, I will remind and warn you to tread carefully with any future questions you have.

On november 6, 2014
[7950824]

You do need to be able to communicate to play, by the rules.

You can report if you feel the rules are being broken, however what I would do in this case if I was on that ship:

I can understand those messages. So I would not report. Furthermore, she can understand what she is being asked. She shows that by her answer to the one question she is asked - broken English or not -

She tells the ship she fixed the door because she couldn't get into the room otherwise.

Sure she is probably wrong (could go around) but it is possible she doesn't know that.

It is not against the rules to just silently play. But if you do speak, it needs to be in English. She is trying, and with more practice, she will probably improve.... one suggestion you can make to her, if you wish -


Use Google Translate to check the message you are about to send, translate your translated message back into your language. Does it still make sense to you? You can click on parts of each sentence and select the best meaning of how to translate each.

When I first started using Google translate to play on the foreign servers, I probably sounded much like her, only probably worse, cause I usually talk a LOT, not just a short sentence at a time.

A player there helped me understand how to use the translator to 'check' my translation, and to understand that if I wasn't getting my message back then I needed to fix my message before I shared it with the ship.

On november 6, 2014
[7950824]

Ships are private. When you place a report, you 'open' that ship, making it possible for us to review the events. Without a report, we don't get to peek at the happenings.

You know what you played through, but only you do. We try to use unbiased judging, normally if you are a judge or a mod and were involved in a ship where rulebreaking happened, you are expected to sit out of judging that ship. There are other judges and other mods who can deal with it, and since they didn't play through it, they're not (as likely to be) biased about it. It's another layer of protection for everyone, from the possible rulebreaker to the reporter themself.

We are also instructed to ignore happenings which are not reported, except in 'exceptional' cases. We're allowed to determine ourselves what 'exceptional' means, and we do. That does mean, sometimes, that we grind our teeth when we get a report on X, and observe that Y broke some especially important rules and really affected the ship's outcome in an unfair way.... without a report on Y, we're not supposed to sanction Y, unless that rulebreaking was 'exceptional'.

So we do indeed need your reports. I take comfort in trusting that over time, rulebreakers will be reported. That it doesn't matter if they get punished for their bad behavior on 'this' ship or 'that' one; if they keep breaking rules sooner or later they will be reported for it, and we can appropriately handle it then.

I hope that comforts you guys like it does me. And that you're comforted that mods like myself cannot easily get mad at a specific person and mess them up! Just cause we want to. We have to have appropriate reason through the actions of others unconnected to ourselves who are going through the set formal channels, and more than one individual is involved in making the decision that 'yes, sanction is deserved for this specific reason'.

[7950824]

Little known fact: You do NOT have to complete your endpage comments to see your previous ships, including the one that just finished. Just click on 'my account', then 'my file'. That will take you to all ships that have 'ended'.

If everyone is dead or back to Sol/Eden - you can see your ship's endpage if you do that. If anyone is still alive, it will not be visible.

It's not a terrible idea to check that page before you complete your endpage commentary and likes, up to you if you want to for future ships.

On november 8, 2014
Kyubey

SDF Rules, Explanations, Quarantine!
SDF Rules, Explanations, Quarantine!
You can report players who do not respect the rules of Mush .
Below is a list of not exhaustive things you can report other players for:
~ Rushing or finishing Mush research before the ship is full and Mush are selected.

This sentence is quite clear - not-anti-mush stuff like projects, lenses or medkit are allowed - they do nothing against mushes (some stuff can be even useful for then, 2 lenses + machine gun rampage for example, or 3 spores in anabolics) - just giving ship chance to survive longer does not mean it's better for humans. mush have a lot of different tactics.

While stuff like gas, serum, scanner only limit mushes against humans. Scanner/Mushicide Soap are not big deal in most of situations, as they help not much, but costs a lot of ap to make. Still until they change the rule or explain why scanner/mushicide soap are not anti-mush research, I'll report anyone who was working on it

On november 8, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Personally it's the same for me, mushicide soap for example basically makes the mush have no chance to infect everyone causing them to forcefully pick between killing everyone or the Daedalus
On november 8, 2014
npfan
KyubeyStill until they change the rule or explain why scanner/mushicide soap are not anti-mush research, I'll report anyone who was working on it

It's not guaranteed everyone will scan themselves. Even if they do, it's very possible for Mush to convert them in between scannings. Mushicide Soap could get burned in a fire, so it's not as reliable in removing spores as Spore Sucker that needs a Dead Mush to research. Basically, researching Scanner and Mushicide Soap fall in the same level as installing cameras. Mush can still do a lot with 4+ spores each day and few rooms protected.

I will say now that if you constantly report people who work on Scanner or Soap and the like before Mush selection, I will give you a Report Abuse sanction.
On november 8, 2014
sperbi

On november 9, 2014
[6826491]
devikingCan i leave someone who im 99% sure is mush alive until we can kill another mush and we can finish the cure since the player would have a important skill like shrink

You CAN, but it can be quite risky. They could Transfer, rampage, or hurt the ship in a number of ways before you even catch the other Mush. On the other hand, as long as neither team breaks the rules in the process, such as offering the cure or a cease fire, then delaying the murder of a suspect can be fair game. That said, if you don't tip them off that they're even a suspect...you might be able to pull off a quick kill of their partner, followed by using Genius on the RFS.

That was done on one of my ships, and it was quite effective. If you're lucky, you might even catch the Mush you plan to cure while they're offline.

On november 11, 2014
[7950824]

It is not acceptable to help the other team win.

In the case where you are the last human left and are aware of this, you are still responsible to attempt to get a win for your team. There is no shame in failing - however you must try.

If you die your team has lost. All chance of your team succeeding dies with you. You may not suicide, and this is always true.

You may undertake plans which could result in your death, while trying to get a win for your team. You may take risks while trying to win. It would not be acceptable to pick up and drop something until you died, with or without the justification "I would rather the ship be destroyed in space than risk them going to Eden" - that 'plan' has no chance of human win.

Even an Ian can save up 12 AP and punch 4 times. That Ian could watch for a roomshake or a plate drop to take someone guarding him under max health... possibly under 12 health. 4 punches can cause up to 12 damage. It's also possible for random events to outright kill some, potentially all of the mush.

But if Ian elects to die, humans have won. Luck no longer matters, Ian's team no longer has a chance.

Dzanek

I'm copying a post from Spazticus there here in order to not spam that "Win Thread".

Spazticus

You took the last O2 capsule, not so the SHIP will survive longer, but so that YOU would survive longer. You admitted that you took it to get the LMS distinction. You are treating this as a win, when you manipulated the situation so that you alone would be in a situation to earn the distinction.

You said: And you did this, at the expense of the rest of your crew.

If you had a confirmed Mush left, and you were trying to outlast them, it could be understandable.

If you were the last Tech, and Pilgred was nearly done, it would also make sense in that context.

If EVERY other member of the crew was inactive, I could even let that slide.

It's your motive that is being called into question. You've been warned about playing selfishly, and this is just another example of it. You did it to benefit YOU, not to prolong the ship.

To be honest, I'm a person of strict scientific and I count a lot of things. I must admit it shouldn't be a win, and I was wondering to which thread I should put the thing I did.

To have the more chance to get LMS (Last Man Standing) distinction I could take 3 units of oxygen, starting the asphyxia much earlier, but I'd understand it'd be count as an action against my team because it harms them and kills them earlier. I took the last oxygen capsule so it won't be wasted. If I didn't take, this ship would be destroyed earlier, but there's written "Survive" and "Maintain the ship". Taking this capsule will hold this ship a cycle longer, and even more, if someone finds some oxygen in space capsule, as it was in my ship once. When Paola found this oxygen, I didn't take it, I put my one and next cycle took it. I also was going to put this capsule after day change, when the plants produce more capsules, but I didn't do so, because on cycle 1 we've got 2 units of oxygen and both oxygen tanks had got broken. I tried to repair one of tanks, then got exhausted, wasting these 2 units and someone died. If it had been comsumed before day change, no suffocation for this cycle would have happened and crew would have survived more.

You can choose to work in collaboration with crewmates or to act in your own interests.
There's said that selfish playing isn't forbidden..

I wanted to increase my chance to get LMS, right, but... my crew was semi-active. We had one technician, Kuan Ti, and the Mage Book, but nobody was active enough to repair the PILGRED from 0%. They play once per 24 hours. I was in the end of cycle and nobody took this unit, so I took it 10 minutes before cycle change. I was one of 2 pilots and also a shooter. My job was important. This ship was going to die and the last people might have died due to ship destruction. You said that I did benefit for myself, but not for ship. I did benefit for ship, as I said. While asphyxia, the chance for each person who'll be forced to comsume the oxygen unit or die is equal and when the next person dies, the chance is increasing for one person, but if someone comsumes the oxygen unit, there's one more person alive and the chance doesn't increase.

You say that "Playing against one's team" is when somebody does something for his OWN purpose, completely the opposite to that one I mentioned. It's like somebody doing piloting instead of research when no biologists there are, it'd be sanctionable, right?

I'd like to see rules appropriately strictly, because the explain "Playing against one's team" and other points in rules are so subjectively and you put a new rule every time when something dule happens.
