On november 13, 2014
[7950824]

Ehh, the two places that may cross the lines are 'incitation to spoil' and 'passive negativity'.

Intent matters a lot, as does a pattern of behavior, patterns especially matter in considering is it passive negativity.

Incitation to spoil has to do with using peer pressure or otherwise encouraging someone else to break rules, like telling someone to hold items before mush selection or telling a mush to surrender, or asking a human to come eat a ration you triple spored.

It can be a bit of a judgment call and if I was to judge the example asked about, I'd want more than one quote, I'd want full context and I'd be considering a pattern of pressure in that direction. We get that through reports made, it allows judges to view that ship's records once the ship is over and done.

Passive negativity has to do with creating a prolonged unpleasant playing environment for others, maybe through purposeful bad advice, put downs towards the players or the game, prolonged negative comments and attitude, or similar.

Again, I could not judge passive negativity based on a single comment, that is a pattern of hostile behavior. A single comment, possibly pulled from a heated argument - not necessarily sanctionable, I absolutely cannot determine from the evidence I see.


That's why it is 'generally' a good idea to report stuff that you feel is questionable. If it seems like it might be breaking a game rule, you're probably justified in reporting it. We -can- flip a report back on the sender, and penalize people for 'report abuse', but we're not going to do that if you make a reasonable report. Clear examples of 'report abuse': You made up what you reported, what you say happened never did. You 'report' something that has nothing to do with the rules, like 'Hi! Did this waste your time?'.

What Aerial asks is not, 'Is that player breaking a rule?'.... which is good, because I can't tell from what I can see in the quote. Instead, Aerial asks 'Is this reportable?' The answer is sure, that is a reasonable thing to report, especially if it is part of a pattern of generalized hostility across the length of that player's time on the ship.
On november 13, 2014
[7950824]
AerialIs it okay to announce that? Infortmation control is important part of the mush hunt after all.

Arguably it is fine to say that. Again, we're looking at a single quote, which could be part of perfectly acceptable play, or rulebreaking. I cannot judge that without context - but by itself it doesn't break the rules. It gives more than a wink to 'incitation to spoil', but it doesn't, by itself, clearly cross that line.

Technically if someone announces a player has passed a human test and is confirmed human as of that moment, that player is doing nearly the same thing as announcing that the player is a great conversion target because humans trust that one more than most now.

If the mush are new, that may be news to them, but most players are aware that 'confirmed' humans are pretty sweet conversion targets and some are aware that there's ways to convert humans in the process of 'confirming' them human. I've heard some players call it 'confirmed not-alpha-mush', and refuse to say anything about them being human still.

On november 14, 2014
[7950824]

Though I am a mod, a lot of what I answer with here is my own opinion. Facts are facts, but I have opinion to offer here, not a set in stone SDF answer about this sort of issue, though my opinion is of course affected by my understanding of SDF standards and the rules.

From what you have quoted, it's reasonable to report either Terrence, Chun, or both. The rest of the players quoted are behaving very appropriately.

Here's the thing. If your Chun was a silent player who wandered around and played a little, in ways that were reasonable and not harmful to the ship but with no real teamwork with the rest of the ship, she would not be sanctioned for doing that, even if she was reported for that.

She has stated she is not cooperating with the rest of the crew, which is (in my opinion, not by the rules) a bit of a waste and not one of the more fun things to do with ones time on a ship - but is that worse than if she were silent and just 'did her own thing' without cooperating or communicating? From the little I know, no. There's no rule saying you have to stay in any PM, or that you have to involve others in how you play. You are likely to have far more success if you do those things, you're also more likely to have fun and for others playing beside you to have fun.

However, is your Chun causing more harm to your ship than she would be if she were completely inactive? If yes, I would definately report her if I played beside her. If not, I don't know if I would or not. I'm not on your ship, so I don't know unless a report is filed, in which case I find out after the ship is over when and if it needs to come to my attention (I am not the only one handling things that need handling). That you feel uncomfortable about what she does or says and genuinely wonder if you should report her - that alone to me is reason to report her. If the judges find her behavior to fall within the rules, she will be cleared. You can't get her in trouble - only she can get herself in trouble, or not.

Terrence risks crossing the line because T&C prohibits us from making personal attacks against each other. From that one comment, it's borderline. Also, one should not create a negative playing environment, and if there was a LOT of that kind of talk from him, it could make the ship a super unpleasant place to be, both for everyone and also her.

Because she does have the right to play as she pleases, as long as she doesn't break the rules. So does every person on every ship.

When someone clearly is breaking the rules, it's not appropriate to constantly discuss having reported them, being about to report them, or any other threats. I especially dislike a lot of 'out of game' threats, such as threatening to report someone. Such things can create a feeling of harrassment, especially as the threat is made repeatedly. Discuss it once if you wish, sure - tell them what rule they are breaking and that you will report them if they keep breaking it/that you have already reported them, but the judges will surely consider their future behavior too, so if they choose to follow the rules from now on, maybe the judges will decide no sanction is needed. Maybe they will choose to cooperate.

But if the player does not - what's the point of more negative and hostile talking in play? Let the judges and mods handle any needed explanation of what the rules really are after the ship is over, if a player still chooses to break them; heck, maybe you're even wrong about what a rule means (feel free to ask the mod inbox that sort of question, or on the forum!). You have a ship to play, and you are there to enjoy it, along with everyone else on it. Please do report rulebreakers, and if you have to kill a rule breaker, do so; otherwise play around them as best you can; either is less disruptive than regularly cussing them out, threatening them/trying to control or change them; if one attempt fails, do you really think multiple future attempts will suddenly start to work?
On november 14, 2014
npfan
PatrykSzczescieYou say that "Playing against one's team" is when somebody does something for his OWN purpose, completely the opposite to that one I mentioned. It's like somebody doing piloting instead of research when no biologists there are, it'd be sanctionable, right?

Playing against your team means doing something with the intent of putting your team in a worse situation. Piloting helps your team, so that example would be fine.

NERONEuh... Chun threatening to kill someone over stupid things like this is not good, right? How should one go about handling this mess?

I just want to point out that I haven't seen Terrence break any rules based on what was posted far. Keep in mind that Terrence does not have justification yet to kill Chun. Chun may not be helping, but she is not actively hurting anyone. If Chun legitimately feels Terrence is going to kill her, Chun has the right to kill Terrence. If Chun doesn't want to work with someone who did a Mush test, she can do so because that person could become a beta Mush. Chun doesn't have to cooperate with anyone, but she cannot purposefully hurt the team. It's understandable that the humans are frustrated with Chun, and if they have reason to believe she does more harm than good, they can kill her.

On november 18, 2014
[7950824]
DarkTheRaven

So I have a Chun currently with the premonition skill along with MOH, for some unkown reason they're using premonition a lot or at least we assume since they apparently need 2 morale boosts every cycle. sometimes she shares the results, half the time not so much even in the mush hunt

if this ends up killing her could it be sanctioned?


The question really isn't 'is this sanctionable', but 'is this reportable'.

In order to answer the first question, you need to know what she is doing and why - to determine if she is breaking rules. Our judges and mods determine that to the best of their ability, using ship records which players in the heat of the moment do not have access too, except for their own play.

Sometimes things are blindingly obviously sanctionable, you probably wouldn't bother asking about those, but for most cases, judging is needed. Because that judging hasn't happened yet, all I can say is 'Maybe. Probably not.'

In order to answer 'is this reportable', you really need to ask only one question: Does this seem to be breaking a rule?

If it appears that Chun is doing anything to harm her team, report her. If she appears to be playing to try and suicide, report her.

Once the judges have all the evidence after the ship is over, if you do report her the judges will decide if there is evidence that a rule was broken, but you're fine in reporting as long as you honestly think a rule is being broken by what you know about.

So do you think the human team is being harmed by what Chun is doing, that she is trying to suicide, or that she is breaking any other rules? If so, report. If not, do not report.
On december 4, 2014
Annette

Hi Mush community!!

I'm sad to announce that I've given Buzzard my resignation as Mush mod. All is well, I'm just really busy IRL these days and don't foresee that changing.

It's been amazing learning the nuances of the game and the SDF, getting to know the judges, fellow mods and players. This is seriously a special game, community and developer.

Peanutz, Spazticus and Impet will look after you!
Annette/Scout

On december 10, 2014
Aceb

Can I play for example on French Server using google-translate (I know how bad it translate whole sentences) and they will not kick me out or ban?
On december 10, 2014
[7950824]

I have done so, I actually simultaneously used Google Translate to play on the French and Spanish servers, as well as EN; and got a lot better at figuring out how to use Google Translate to communicate I will never do it again because it was SO MUCH WORK but I sure enjoyed doing it once.

I was not kicked out or punished, though some people commented about how badly I was communicating.

A couple tips that seemed to help:

Be willing to translate one sentence at a time. After you turn your sentence into French, consider translating it again back into English.... does it still have the same meaning?

Be prepared to reword your attempts to communicate. There's many ways to say something in English (and probably in French too) and some ways may be harder or easier to translate.

Be sure to have fun!
On december 10, 2014
Flash

You can also play without saying a single word since apparently that's not against the rules.

On december 10, 2014
[7950824]
AcebJust hope that if something that can happen to me on french, won't have effect here.

Here will not be affected by what happens on the other servers, unless you clearly are trying purposefully to be a major rulebreaker there.

The servers are essentially utterly separate. You would need to do terrible things that break the Terms and Conditions and risk the deletion of your account to be affected here by what you do there.

I'm not encouraging you to break the rules there by any means. But no, you don't need to fear trouble from there coming to you here, for anything a normal, reasonable player would do. If you struggle to communicate there... that's not going to touch you here.
On december 10, 2014
Aceb

On december 10, 2014
[7950824]

Glad I can help calm you down. If you're trying to enjoy the game and follow the rules, I don't think you're going to have any trouble at all. Remember to write in French when you write there, and everything should be fine. That's what I'd tell a French player, if one asked me if he could come play on this server; I'd encourage him too, and just remind him, write in English on the ship.

The servers are different, they get updated at different times and the culture is a bit different; so you may notice some game mechanics are different on the other servers. If you want to ask here about something there, be sure to mention you're asking about something happening on a French (or Spanish) server ship, that will help us feel more confident when we tell you we have no idea, we've never seen that happen on any of our ships - maybe it's a server difference, of which there are some.

Enjoy a lot! Have fun! Play a lot and love it!

On december 11, 2014
Aceb

I am on a ship with Multi-teamster Janice and Paola (I assume it's one person?). Both characters took beds and we had a Gioele (human) who was trying to get killed by other human. (He was accusing random people) and on the end asked "what I can do with phagocyte". I assume Gioele (newbie or not) should get reported but what with Janice and Paola aka Multi-teamster?
On december 11, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, Gioele should be reported.

A player is only allowed to have ONE Twinoid account, and there are no exceptions. When it comes to Multi-teamsters, you don't have to report them, unless there is another rule being broken. The system immediately and automatically flags both accounts, and they must contact the Mod Inbox if they want to be able to play again after their time on the ship is over.

Example worth reporting 1: One of the two is Mush, and the two characters work in concert to spoil the game.

Example worth reporting 2: Griefing with a killing spree, with any or all characters involved as humans.

Those are both extreme examples, but bear in mind that if it's worth reporting a single player for it under normal circumstances, then it's worth reporting both accounts when one of them breaks the rules.

It's important to note that sometimes couples start the game together, and may end up on the same ship, or family members, more commonly. If they don't do anything else that violates the rules, just let the Mod Inbox handle it from there.

Well, I just entered new ship and... this is what I read first.
"Hi, I am Eleesha and I will be off for few days (while few means more than 2 at least)"

2. It's reportable, isn't it?
On december 12, 2014
[6826491]

Yes, that's reportable. If someone KNOWS they're going to be gone for a few days, they should not join a new ship.

Emergencies happen, like accidents, illnesses, and funerals, etc. Those are considered understandable, since people generally don't plan to have those. DO NOT lie and use any of these as reasons to cover for Mushy (in)activity, because it makes things harder for other players who actually have to go inactive for these reasons.

npfan
SpazticusDO NOT lie and use any of these as reasons to cover for Mushy (in)activity, because it makes things harder for other players who actually have to go inactive for these reasons.

I just want to say that choosing not to use excuses like accidents to cover for Mush inactivity is a matter of preference. Mush are allowed to lie as far as the rules go, and it is up to the humans to decide whether that person is telling the truth or not.
On december 14, 2014
Aceb
npfanI just want to say that choosing not to use excuses like accidents to cover for Mush inactivity is a matter of preference. Mush are allowed to lie as far as the rules go, and it is up to the humans to decide whether that person is telling the truth or not.

Lie in game because of game things or lying "I'm going to bed, cya" I think it's acceptable.

But I would myself really push to border with a mush claiming to be inactivie because "someone of theirs dead" and then suddenly pop-up later to kill people saying "Sorry and things" to later for him saying "I lied."
On december 14, 2014
[6826491]
npfanI just want to say that choosing not to use excuses like accidents to cover for Mush inactivity is a matter of preference. Mush are allowed to lie as far as the rules go, and it is up to the humans to decide whether that person is telling the truth or not.

The inherent problem with "lying for sympathy" rests with the aftereffects on future ships. If a Mush lied and said, "I have to attend a funeral" in order to stall for time to rampage, and one of their crewmates sees someone else say the same thing on a later ship, they're likely to be less trusting, and may even kill that player...even when that funeral they have to attend is genuine. It's the mentality of, "I've been fooled by this excuse once before, and it won't work on me a second time."

I'm not suggesting that Mush can't lie. They most certainly CAN. What I'm suggesting is that they shouldn't choose an excuse like the ones I listed, simply because it will garner sympathy. They shouldn't use a lie like the ones I listed, because it can cause someone who is telling the truth on a future ship to get killed. Emergencies happen, and I don't believe they should be fabricated and exploited just to cover for Mushy activity. There are plenty of work or school related lies one can use; it doesn't require taking a lie that far, and the effect of exploiting lies like that certainly ripples onto future ships.

While legally, they CAN do so...in a meta sense, doing so falls under the auspices of "don't be an asshole", for the reasons I listed above.
On december 14, 2014
npfan
AcebBut I would myself really push to border with a mush claiming to be inactivie because "someone of theirs dead" and then suddenly pop-up later to kill people saying "Sorry and things" to later for him saying "I lied."

It's distasteful, but still not against the rules.

Spazticus

The inherent problem with "lying for sympathy" rests with the aftereffects on future ships. If a Mush lied and said, "I have to attend a funeral" in order to stall for time to rampage, and one of their crewmates sees someone else say the same thing on a later ship, they're likely to be less trusting, and may even kill that player...even when that funeral they have to attend is genuine. It's the mentality of, "I've been fooled by this excuse once before, and it won't work on me a second time."

I'm not suggesting that Mush can't lie. They most certainly CAN. What I'm suggesting is that they shouldn't choose an excuse like the ones I listed, simply because it will garner sympathy. They shouldn't use a lie like the ones I listed, because it can cause someone who is telling the truth on a future ship to get killed. Emergencies happen, and I don't believe they should be fabricated and exploited just to cover for Mushy activity. There are plenty of work or school related lies one can use; it doesn't require taking a lie that far, and the effect of exploiting lies like that certainly ripples onto future ships.

While legally, they CAN do so...in a meta sense, doing so falls under the auspices of "don't be an asshole", for the reasons I listed above.

I don't disagree with that, but I just want to make it clear that it's not a matter of following or breaking the rules.
On december 14, 2014

On december 14, 2014
npfan
Aceb

I know, it's not against the rules, but how you mentioned it, "distasteful" it's very... little and enough polite meaning of "move" like that. Personally, I would just post somewhere guy's name and use every possible tool to dodge any more ships and warn people of something like that.

I really know balancing on border and stuff, but if we clearly say it's OK to use that kind of distraction, people might start to use it which I highly don't want to see.

I'm not encouraging anyone to use it. However, the rules should be made to make sure the game isn't broken, not just because we don't like something. Some people don't like Mush tests. Too bad, it's still legal. People don't like immediate rampages. Too bad, it's still legal. This is a social game, one that centers around trust and paranoia. Making up rules and new restrictions just because we may not like it is not a good enough justification. As long as someone isn't inherently breaking the game (e.g. killing a bunch of teammates), let people do as they play. In time, players will see what works and what doesn't. If this strategy works, then players will just have to prepare for that. If it doesn't, it doesn't become an issue then.
On december 14, 2014
Aceb
npfanI'm not encouraging anyone to use it. However, the rules should be made to make sure the game isn't broken, not just because we don't like something. Some people don't like Mush tests. Too bad, it's still legal. People don't like immediate rampages. Too bad, it's still legal. This is a social game, one that centers around trust and paranoia. Making up rules and new restrictions just because we may not like it is not a good enough justification. As long as someone isn't inherently breaking the game (e.g. killing a bunch of teammates), let people do as they play. In time, players will see what works and what doesn't. If this strategy works, then players will just have to prepare for that. If it doesn't, it doesn't become an issue then.

Well, you compare 2 diffrent things. Yes, it's nearly true, everything you said but. But i will try to show you something on example.
Stephen: Oh guys, I have go to work, then university and stuff, I won't be longer.
People are like "Oh sure, see ya, when you back make us rations with "
Then suddenly Stephen wakes up 3h later and kill 3 people. It's okay, part of gameplay. Few people my suspect something and everyone know clearly it was mostly just smoke bomb.

Derek: My grandpa died. I'm off for days.
People are like "Oh Sorry to hear that/condolence/We are with you... and stuff//
Then suddenly Derek wakes up 3h later, kills 3 guys and says "HAHA!".
It's actually making people even effect emotional towards certain player thus not even suspecting him to make actually a smoke bomb. It's distasteful, it's wrong, it's not even right. In this moment "game" stop being funny, start being "wrong" for certain (or most) people. There's no fun in that. If there's no fun in that, people start getting angry/mad/quitting and stuff. Rules are rules, but some borders shouldn't been crossed, even if you know, you can do it.

I hope you understand my point now. Lie is Lie, gameplay is gameplay, but game should stay game.

On december 18, 2014
[6826491]
DarkTheRaven

Also while I'm here a question for the judges, can a casting advertise itself on a ship? Basically the idea is make a mass PM so it doesnt spam the main chat, anyone interested can talk there anyone not can close the tab

From my investigation I cant find anything against it in Mush rules or the T&C, but rules regarding castings have not been clarified very well

The rules on that are that a casting may make one post per ship to advertise their casting; any more than that is considered spamming. People can reply to you in PMs after that. (Say, five people reply to the post, and you open a PM with all of them to discuss it.)

[6826491]
KyubeyIf somebody on the ship, which case you are reviewing have an illness, that changes his posts (like coprolalia) do you see what he wanted to write, what others saw in chat or both?

When we review the logs, we see what everyone else sees, if the person has Coprolalia, for example. So if we were to get a report of someone flooding chat, and the person was just trying to update a thread (but had their posts changed half a dozen times) we'd clear it. Given that I have Coprolalia on my current ship, and there is no living Shrink, I know exactly how frustrating that can be.

On december 24, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Which is what I'm worried about, the chances are fairly low from what I saw around 1/27 posts was changed but they all can cause major issues if it ever happened during a tense situation, this happens in private messages as well which is where I tested the odds

Changes I noticed
Character is mush, you all know this right? This one seems very common

I think character is dirty way too often... Seems rare at most

On december 24, 2014
[7950824]

Every player is free to do anything they want about the messages - including the person saying it (note if you choose to break the rules in what you do about it, you choose to face the consequences too). A hasty correction, 'That's my paranoia talking!' or similar is a very, very common reaction to 'saying the wrong thing', especially at the worst times. Good-intentioned people tend to look like they have good intentions across the life of their ship, which tends to make deciding if the player was trying to cause harm to their team or not quite easy if they are reported when bad luck strikes, or an actual mistake of some sort is made. Similarly, players with rule-breaking intentions tend to have those all ship, making judging a bit easier in those cases too.

It's fine to think about, and if you really want to, worry about such a thing being the difference between getting a sanction or not.

But really, I don't see that game-modified message being the deciding factor. It may cause chaos on the ship at the time it happens, but we're going to be trying to understand motive, and we have the whole ship to look at. Including the player's behavior after a paranoia or coprolalia message is said at the worst possible time, if that's what happens.

You yourself, as the player affected by the disease, have the power to immediately give the judges (and your shipmates) more information about what's going on, if you feel that is good for your team or your personal safety.

On december 25, 2014
[7950824]

PatrykSzczescieIs it sanctionable what Raluca has done?

Patryk asked if it were sanctionable. That can be a complicated question to answer, because it depends on what evidence the judges see in the ship logs - which may or may not have been perfectly and completely relayed to us in Patryk's tale.

No idea if it is sanctionable without the ship's logs, but I am certain what was described is reportable. No player would be punished for 'report abuse' if they reported actions like what Patryk described.

I urge players to not worry if something is sanctionable or not. You often don't have enough information to be sure, unless it's clearly griefing, so don't worry about that.

Instead, if you find something to be suspicious of breaking a rule - report that. No problem, we're glad of the reports.
On december 28, 2014
[8167465]

Is it permitted to report someone whose gone Grand Inactive?

If they're mush, they are pretty much playing against their team or abandoned the game (both are against the rules). This is especially true for an alpha mush who goes inactive prior/at to mush selection as it completely derails any balance the game has since it reduces the number of spikes per day and gives an easy target for humans to kill later giving them access to the cure they otherwise may not have.

For human Grand Inactives: they generally mislead mush hunting, idle in completely unprotected areas giving the mush easy targets, and waste their own resources (human resources) which could be used to assist the team in some way. This is especially true is an inactive Chun since most crews are then stuck having to heal and comfort her. In the worst cases they end up idling on a bed wasting it as they'll never use it anyways. Lastly, they're pretty much guaranteed great transfer targets for mush as they'll always have max action and movement points which is information that a mush shouldn't be able to get otherwise unless they literally count a player's point usage which is highly unlikely.
On december 28, 2014
npfan
DraconicEpicIs it permitted to report someone whose gone Grand Inactive?

No, unless you have evidence that person is XP farming or purposely left to hurt their team. If you report someone with your only evidence that they're a Grand Inactive, you risk getting a Report Abuse sanction. Having said that though, when the admins implemented the Grand Inactive tag, they also allow anyone to kill Grand Inactives with impunity, unless of course there was something obviously sinister behind that.
On december 28, 2014
Flash

Has anyone even been sanctioned for XP farming? You can't really prove that they are farming unless they outright tell you and looking at their ship history is not necessarily telling.

1412

Using a foreign language is only sanctionable if that's the only language you ever use. This is the english server, and t is expected that you type in english,but if you use a bit of french in a pm or something it's not a problem.
Now, if you speak french and ONLY FRENCH, and make no effort to, say, use a translator, then that is sanctionable.
I think that's right, anyway. Feel free to correct me.
On december 29, 2014
npfan

1. If you have to use Google Translate, you probably shouldn't play. As long as you at least try to communicate, it's fine.

2. People who know a different language have gotten away with talking amongst themselves in that foreign language. While we encourage everyone to use English at all times, being caught using Transfer like that would not be sanctionable per se.
On december 31, 2014
DarkTheRaven

As a note I've had pretty long random conversations in different languages and never received a sanction, though I would recommend if you're going to have a lengthy conversation in another language move it to a PM, constant use of a second language for a random/unrelated conversation on the main chat could end with a sanction

And if you have to translate every sentence you read or type it's probably (in my opinion) best to just play in your native language server until you learn some english
On january 1, 2015
TheTylerLee

I'm not sure if this is the place, But does using AP on a ship increase the difficulty of the ship starting at day 5? Or every day the ship gets harder at a specific rate, regardless of how much AP is being used?
On january 1, 2015
[6826491]
TheTylerLeeI'm not sure if this is the place, But does using AP on a ship increase the difficulty of the ship starting at day 5? Or every day the ship gets harder at a specific rate, regardless of how much AP is being used?

The exact system for it isn't publicly known, not even to the mods. The game definitely gets harder after certain points by default, and the total AP spent is also a confirmed factor. Every AP spent adds to the overall difficulty of the ship, and that includes the number/frequency of hunters and events. This is one of the reasons why AP efficiency is so important, from the beginning to the end of the voyage. A lot of AP wasted early in the voyage can lead to a situation in which you have dozens of hunters per wave before Day 7.

Also note that having a very low AP expenditure for several cycles in a row can lead to a situation in which you having dozens of hunters outside during those cycles, yet the ship stays alive. You'll also find out (as I did firsthand) that the cycle after you start spending AP en masse, they'll all fire.

On january 1, 2015
npfan

Those questions are better suited in the Questions and Answers thread. To answer your question, difficulty increases the longer a ship lasts no matter what. How much difficulty increases does depend on what percent of your crew is active. The more active, the smoother the difficulty increase. The less active, you start out pretty easy for the first few days and then the difficult shoots up.
On january 2, 2015
DarkTheRaven

So on a recent ship I logged a report for suiciding, later I found evidence specifically in the last words of said comrade so I couldn't have re-entered the report, while I'm sure his verdict has been decided by now for future reference should I message someone from the SDF team if I were to find such evidence

Also TheTylerLee in the future the place to put questions is in the Questions & Answers thread, people there are from the community answering random questions you may or may not have
On january 2, 2015
[7950824]

Probably better for this sort of question to be in the questions and answers thread, 'mechanics' are a sort of 'rule' but not the sort one usually needs to ask how to not break.

The difficulty increases based both on passing time and how much AP is spent - that said, the random events are random, and a 'lower difficulty' cycle or few cycles could have a string of unusually frequent bad events, or a 'higher difficulty' cycle or cycles could lack those events. There are also projects and skills that can have some effect on the ship's difficulty in both directions.

The odds of good and bad zone results on expos do not appear to be connected to the ship's difficulty.

I don't think the difficulty increase starts on day 5, I think it starts when AP starts to be spent. The command terminal does change what it informs you as to the type of 'space' you are travelling through at two points in the ship's life, but that happens at a set point in the game and is not an indication of the difficulty at that point. For example, ships with many inactives on day 4 would be expected to have had fewer bad events than ships with many actives at that same point in time.

Furthermore, the category of space stops changing at a certain point, but the difficulty level does not stop increasing - a ship on day 13 is vastly different in difficulty than that same ship on day 20.

I would not recommend trying to avoid spending AP to try and keep the difficulty low, but it is reasonable behavior to try and not waste your AP on things that don't help your team's win conditions, intending to both directly try and help your team win and to indirectly avoid making it even harder for your team as time passes.

edited to add: Ho hum, teach me to not see if there's another page of responses already

On january 2, 2015
[7950824]
DarkTheRavenSo on a recent ship I logged a report for suiciding, later I found evidence specifically in the last words of said comrade so I couldn't have re-entered the report, while I'm sure his verdict has been decided by now for future reference should I message someone from the SDF team if I were to find such evidence

You can only place a readable report on one character once per ship, so even if you had not closed your endpage, you still could not have successfully edited or added to your report (the game will let you try - we just don't get to see it).

Your work around: If you wish to let us know about something new about a report you have submitted, you can contact the mod inbox: http://twinoid.com/tid/groupDiscuss and explain in a message there.
On january 2, 2015
DarkTheRaven

Will this work if the verdict is already decided? (i assume no) This ship was ~3 weeks ago so I'd be surprised if the report hasn't been reviewed
On january 2, 2015
[7950824]

It will 'work' in the sense that we'll get the message, yes.

'Is it needed' is much harder to establish.

Endpages happen off ships, judges do not view the endpage comment as part of the evidence considered in their decision.

So use your judgment. You're the one who knows what you know. If you think it's relevant and important, send the message. If you think it is neither relevant nor important, don't.

[8550239]

What do you do when over half your crew could be considered reportable? i.e being offensive, destructive, holding onto valueable items before mush selection etc, etc?
On january 6, 2015
[6826491]
NGJonWhat do you do when over half your crew could be considered reportable? i.e being offensive, destructive, holding onto valueable items before mush selection etc, etc?

The short answer is that you report the players (and their infractions) that you can, and let the SDF sort it out. Just know that if a report isn't filed against a particular player, they will probably not see a sanction for any rule-breaking activity.
On january 7, 2015
deviking
SpazticusThe short answer is that you report the players (and their infractions) that you can, and let the SDF sort it out. Just know that if a report isn't filed against a particular player, they will probably not see a sanction for any rule-breaking activity.

On january 7, 2015
[6826491]
NGJonderek picked up important items before mush selection (apron and armor) not sure if he hid stuff before mush selection too. AND he is human

Items can't be hidden prior to selection, so that would be impossible. It IS a Neutral Play violation if they're intentionally kept in your inventory prior to selection, however. Note that there have been times in which people were moving with items between rooms at the moment of Mush selection. Provided they drop the items right away, that's typically something we'd clear.
On january 7, 2015
[8550239]

On january 7, 2015
[7950824]

Totally.

I'd rather players report probably rulebreaking behavior than not report it.

Think of it this way - if someone is breaking the rules, do you want to play with them again, and again, and again? That could happen if you fail to report them.

Do you want rulebreakers breaking the rules on other peoples' ships again and again and again?

If I end up with 'your' unreported rulebreakers still breaking rules when I join their ship at some point in the future, do you think I'm going to thank you for not making more work for the judges when you could have, or wish that you or anyone else had please reported the rulebreaker(s), and helped to prevent an unknown amount of future rulebreaking?

Hint.... I'd rather work outside of the game, and play inside of the game, myself.

On january 13, 2015
[7950824]

Trust the system. How it works on this server, and as far as I know all servers: Every report has equal weight. Doesn't matter if one person makes a report or 15 - if the reported person didn't break any rules, nothing will happen to them.

To be sanctioned, first you have to be reported.

The mods will handle their decision about 'report abuse' or not, should Hua actually be reporting you for being English (I am assuming you have been communicating in French as you have said you were). If you feel a hostile environment is being created (passive or active negativity) or any other rule is being broken, make your report.

Every server is completely separate. There's nothing I can do about your French server game or reports.

Play with confidence though, at least as far as being English goes - there's no rule in mush or terms of service which prohibits players of any nationality, and the terms of service prevent discrimination.
On january 13, 2015

On january 13, 2015
npfan

I just want to bring attention to a caveat:
Do not take for granted that the SDF rules or how the SDF view cases are going to be exactly the same as those in the French server. In general, the rules are the same. However, each server is independent, so if you're wondering how the FDS might rule cases, the best advice you're going to get is from an FDS member. The same goes with the Spanish server.

On january 13, 2015
[7950824]

For whatever reason I've been treated pretty well by the French.

I've only played one game on the French server, and initially my use of Google Translate was pretty raw; I got mocked a bit as I figured out that I'd better 'double translate', to translate the French translation back into English and make sure it still meant what I hoped it would, and to translate just one sentence at a time for better results, using shorter and less complex sentences, and so on.

That game was actually one of my more intense mush games at the time, and I was treated pretty well actually, for all that I was a bronze Paola on a ship full of mostly golds. Jin came and stood over me in medlab, sharing his logistics and giving me missions "aussi pour le comm", and Terrence opened a PM with me and invited me to talk to him in English in the PM only, we discussed the game and the differences in the game.

A bit later, Terrence claimed he got transferred into, and I helped clear the new body because he had the same English vocab and grammar issues that Terrence did.

Turned out that Terrence was alpha though, and sure there was a transfer involving him, but he was so not a victim. And a pilot decidedto go to a volcano O2 planet with several damage zones with just the pilot and I, me having the weapons. I got MIA'd and the pilot died to damage, and Jin came back down solo, rescued me, waltzed us past the volcano, even grabbed two fruit from a forest or something on the way back to the fighter.

Sadly the pilot got the O2 before he died, so no O2 for us, we all died.

Still, I had an incredible adventure, and it's still one of my favorite ships: http://mush.vg/theEnd/38490

I've made one post on the French forums, this: http://mush.vg/tid/forum#!view/93847|...

I was responded to favorably, but I think it shows an interesting mindset that (at least some) French players felt unsure of their welcome in the EN server.

On january 21, 2015
Alyarin

So, here's a scenario:
- Giole has an O2 Planet
- Giole and Roland are Mush
- The ship has 2 O2 remaining
- Giole and Roland approach Jin Su, and state that they have an O2 planet, but will not reveal the location until Jin Su willingly gets converted to the Mush

Is this sanctionable? Along with withholding food ETC? Hasn't happened yet, but i'm considering doing something along these lines.
On january 21, 2015
[7950824]
Alyarin

So, here's a scenario:
- Giole has an O2 Planet
- Giole and Roland are Mush
- The ship has 2 O2 remaining
- Giole and Roland approach Jin Su, and state that they have an O2 planet, but will not reveal the location until Jin Su willingly gets converted to the Mush

Is this sanctionable? Along with withholding food ETC? Hasn't happened yet, but i'm considering doing something along these lines.

The mush team can do anything they want with that O2 planet from revealing it to not revealing it, both long and short game mush strategies are allowed.

However the rules specifically forbid surrender; under no circumstances can any player surrender at any time to the other side. Doing so also is a form of playing against your team, also specifically forbidden.

What you describe sets up a situation where you put pressure on another player to surrender to your team (alternatively, they may denounce you and gather the human team to kill you).

Unfortunately, there is absolutely no path within the rules for Jin to cooperate with your demand. You don't put Jin at risk of sanctions by what you say to Jin (You do risk yourself though), but Jin cannot surrender to you. Jin may be allowed to trick you about his surrender, to claim that he will cooperate to try to get the information and not actually cooperate at all, but that walks risky ground, especially if there is evidence of cooperation and/or he does become mush anyway and there's evidence that he knew he was likely or certain to by doing what he did.)

It is risky TO YOURSELF even to suggest or put pressure on someone to break the rules (such as recommending that they surrender to you); that is called incitation to spoiling and may be sanctionable if reported.

It is also risky TO YOURSELF to reveal that you (or anyone else on the ship) are mush. If you find a way to do so which does not harm your team's chances of winning, and are reported for revealing yourself as mush (or others! much more dangerous to YOU as there are perhaps no circumstances where revealing another person as mush is anything but harmful to your team), you may escape sanction, however the rules allow for no form of cooperation at all. To win, the human team must kill or cure all mush (and only one cure is possible at best) then get to Sol or Eden. To win, the mush must prevent the humans from achieving that goal, and remaining undetected is often an essential facet of that. Revealling yourself as mush, in a conversational, harmless way (Instead of a destructive, rampaging fashion) often puts the judges in a difficult position, should you be reported - especially if the ship does go on to have a human victory. If it looks like you are playing against your team, then it looks like you are breaking the rules.
On january 27, 2015
CyberiumShadow

On february 1, 2015
[7950824]

I will remind every player that sanctions and SDF points are not to be discussed in public; messages which do discuss them will be deleted. The message you receive if sanctioned is automatically generated - there definitely is room to question the content of that message, but the public forum is not the place to do so.

Players who receive a sanction absolutely are invited to discuss them in the mod inbox. Your sanction message includes a direct link where it says it does HERE to that mod inbox - select the mush mods option and type away. The actual link it has HERE is this: http://twinoid.com/tid/groupDiscuss, should any of you not have a sanction but feel you wish to discuss something in private with the mods.

In private, and when possible (it can take a few days), a mod will review your message then your ship's log. The mod can and will explain what you were reported for and what rule(s) the ships logs show that you broke. If the mod determines that you actually did not break rules on that ship, the mod is able to clear that incorrect sanction from your record (this is rare, but mistakes can be made, and if they are, they can be corrected). The mod may choose to discuss with you how you could have, or the closest you could have, achieved your goal on that ship without breaking game rules, so you are aware of more legal ways to play that you might wish to use in the future.

The automated sanction messages are not very clear, and it is entirely possible to receive one, read it all, and have little or no idea what you were sanctioned for. That is one thing that the mod inbox is for. Please use it if you want a sanction explained or looked over to make sure it was actually earned - I would be comfortable with seeing every player who does not feel they are absolutely certain what rule they broke use the option of asking the mod inbox for an explanation. After all - if you don't know what you have done wrong, you're likely to keep doing it. So ask .
On february 2, 2015
Infection

I have a player on my ship that want to kill me because i sayed to others to kill him as he don't help the ship. He now says i'm a "Griefer" for asking that.

Aceb

Generally, you can't report someone if he just kills you because he has any suspects. Your case my sounds like someone who is a total ... male human part of body ... might just kill you. It happens, you can't do nothing to that. Griefers sometimes accidentally kill a mush like that and well, some of them turn from giefer to lucky guy and enjoy ship (yes, it happens on rare occasions). Only obviously, 100% known griefer should be report for killing. (like someone is sick and still got killed by other human).


I often myself, depending on character, create a personal diary which who I would kill without saying a word, because I don't want to warn my potential victim that I suspect to be mush. In 90% cases I was actually correct. Well, if I am wrong, I try to clean myself as much as possible.

On february 4, 2015
[7950824]
AcebOnly obviously, 100% known griefer should be report for killing. (like someone is sick and still got killed by other human).

Well. My take on that is, if it looks like a random kill to you and you cannot get an explanation (maybe you are dead and the player(s) don't explain the evidence; maybe you are alive and those involved won't explain the evidence), a report is reasonable.

Sure, many will be cleared, but you're not wrong to report if you think you are seeing rules broken.

Killing someone who got sick is, unfortunately, not always 100% known griefer activity. After all, can't a mush transfer into someone (other than Chun) who got sick? Can't a mush convert someone (other than Chun) who has been confirmed not to be an alpha mush?

I know that if I see good evidence that a 'known human' is no longer human, I'm taking them down, usually involving most of my ship. These are all grey areas, and to say 'sanctionable' or not does take all the evidence in the ship's logs. But if you think rules may be being broken, your report is appropriate.
On february 4, 2015
Aceb
Impet

Well. My take on that is, if it looks like a random kill to you and you cannot get an explanation (maybe you are dead and the player(s) don't explain the evidence; maybe you are alive and those involved won't explain the evidence), a report is reasonable.

Sure, many will be cleared, but you're not wrong to report if you think you are seeing rules broken.

Killing someone who got sick is, unfortunately, not always 100% known griefer activity. After all, can't a mush transfer into someone (other than Chun) who got sick? Can't a mush convert someone (other than Chun) who has been confirmed not to be an alpha mush?

I know that if I see good evidence that a 'known human' is no longer human, I'm taking them down, usually involving most of my ship. These are all grey areas, and to say 'sanctionable' or not does take all the evidence in the ship's logs. But if you think rules may be being broken, your report is appropriate.

Your situation doesn't prove one to be 100% human (transfer and stuff) and it's easy to discover it. It's easy to see a difference between griefer kill and silent detective/suspect kill (or call it how you want).

I can only say: "You're 100% sure it's griefer or enough convinced": report. If you suspect a player to be griefer but you know you can be wrong. You can report it to be safe but... you will only give more work for mods.
On february 4, 2015
[7950824]

I am a mod, saying that I consider a report made by a player who suspects a rule may be broken to be an appropriate report, and that players are not required (and often are unable) to be 100% sure a rule has been broken when they make a report.
On february 4, 2015
Aceb
ImpetI am a mod, saying that I consider a report made by a player who suspects a rule may be broken to be an appropriate report, and that players are not required (and often are unable) to be 100% sure a rule has been broken when they make a report.

It's fine. I'm not saying that reports shouldn't be made if not sure. My point is just for those who are making report and aren't sure about it, reconsider that decision. There's no harm for one to sit for a minute and think about whole situation.
On february 4, 2015
npfan

While I agree that people should think if there was any reason someone could think you could be Mush before reporting, but I encourage anyone who thinks someone has broken the rules to report, whether sure or not.

[7881960]

3 Situations:

1) An Alpha mush go rampage. Forced to rampage because spotted by 100% proof, (i.e. mycoalarm, or bad public log). At the end of rampage (no more ap/mp, no more chances to hurt humans), could the other Alpha mush attack him for gain the human crew trust?

2) Same as before, but the rampage is not forced but simple decision of single mush (maybe in disagree with the other mush). Could a mush attack a mush?

3) The 2 Alpha mush go rampage. during the rampage done a total infection on a player (not ask why, but it's happened). could the new beta mush attacks the 2 alpha mush? maybe he was online during the actions and active on the mush-hunt chat.

p.s. i would say "no" at the first two. in the third situation, i was able to not attack ("lost internet connection" ) but was really a bad moment and no good reason.
On february 4, 2015
[7950824]
DarkTheRavenI have a concern regarding a casting's special rules as I believe they go against MT rules, to bring up these concerns I assume I should use the 'contact an official group' button and choose mush mods?

That's a perfectly acceptable option. Other options include PMing a mod, and/or creating a multi-member PM with the leader(s) of that casting and other key people who are involved in deciding what rules that casting will follow and one or more mods.
On february 4, 2015
[7950824]
Cagnols3 Situations:

It's all a big grey area. To judge such things would require much of the ship logs. The question foremost in my mind as I reviewed the logs would be "Would a reasonable person agree that the actions the reported person did were within the game rules?" The rules I would be most focused on would be "Do not surrender" and "Do not play against your team".

It is not specifically and absolutely forbidden for a mush to kill another mush. Doing so carries a very high cost to the mush team - limited mush resources (AP) are being put into doing what humans most need to win. Face it - to win the humans need all mush dead or cured. There is no circumstance under which the humans can win while any live mush remain. Sure, humans also require Pilgred completed - but for most ships eliminating live mush is (vastly, I hope) greater challenge.

To be completely safe from sanction, a Mush player making the choice to attack another Mush needs clear and compelling evidence that doing so helps the Mush team more than the other options that exist (two obvious other options which typically would help the mush team more: 1) Not attacking - like most of the other humans are probably doing... It usually doesn't take a whole ship to kill an exposed mush... then trying to win later when the time is right. 2) Attacking the humans instead of the mush, causing them an even greater need to spend AP right then on killing obvious mush, and maybe getting more dead humans in the bargain)

It's OK to be wrong or misunderstand. Success or failure of the plan does not determine if it was a reasonable plan or not - what matters is the core concept, was it done out of surrender or to hurt the mush team? It is hugely helpful to the judges if the attacking mush explains their reasoning and what evidence they were working with. Would a reasonable player agree that under those circumstances, the actions taken were within the standards the rules require? That question's answer is what I would be using to determine how I would vote on that report.

DarkTheRavenCan you report the 'Murica guy even if he's mush?

Flash
Addendum: is it allowed to use the 'Murica griefer (or just griefing in general) as a scapegoat to get away with Mush transfer-kills? It's bad sport of course but can people get sanctioned for it? This is a serious question unlike my other one above There have in fact been copycats, and they have indeed been sanctioned for it. Some of them were experienced players who wanted to get away with griefing their ships. We don't care what the motives are, or which team you're on. Don't do it. I'm not directing any ire at you for simply asking the question, though my answer applies to everyone reading this post.

On february 10, 2015

@ edit -> I mean, you will be observed, people maybe will remember players names and generally... bad stuff can happen.

MURICA is a thing never be used. There's no need to explain why.
On february 10, 2015
[6826491]
KyubeyWell, reading the answer, I feel like you misunderstood the question Ofc griefing for humans is bad.

I understood the question, Kyubey. The problem here is that shouting that phrase leads to reports, which can lead to sanctions, even for players on the Mush team. I'll explain the position further:

If you have to invoke the tactic of a serial griefer just to gain some sort of advantage, you will harm player morale in the process. It's not just that it's unsporting, it's unhealthy for the playerbase, because people who think, "Oh great, I just got griefed, again." might actually quit playing the game after that ship.

It doesn't matter that the incident was fake; if one or more players actually quit the game over such an incident, no amount of people saying, "It was legal Mush play" will get them to come back. The effects are apparent, and we can't allow that line to be crossed.
On february 10, 2015
Aceb

Spazticus explained it so well that I would even highlight it somewhere or put into official F&Q xD

On february 11, 2015
[6826491]

You know, I brought it up, so it's not entirely fair for me to "tease" the curious players here.

Just this once, I'll explicitly mention it on the forum, and give some details about my involvement. I promise I will never make another post like this again, so please indulge me, just this one time. For the record, I try to get our players to try out Mush, too.

The game is Quintet. We got Greenlit through Steam on December 29th, and we've been scrambling to get everything in order for the Steam launch, coming up around the first week in March. It's been playable for two years, actually - so "launch" isn't quite accurate. It's also constantly being updated and worked on. We have one guy (its creator) doing all the programming, while the three of us who comprise the team collectively work on new features, scenario creation, ship balancing, bug hunting, and all that other fun stuff. I've been involved with Quintet since its Kickstarter campaign two years ago, and I eventually transitioned from being "just a backer" to becoming part of the team; the other guy who works with us was also a backer, and he runs our Teamspeak server.

The game is a free to play (NOT pay to win) multiplatform bridge crew simulator, with each person controlling a separate ship station and working together to control the ship. If you think that sounds like Artemis, it's only somewhat close to the mark. Quintet features drop in/drop out gameplay, and unlike Artemis, you can play it solo even if you don't have any friends online, or just randomly join other ships in progress. It runs on just about anything, since it's built in Unity. Phones might be too small to handle its UI, so desktops/laptops (and tablets, too) are recommended.

Depending on the size of the ship, you can have one to five people all playing online on the same ship, along with multiple ships in the same scenario. Our most crowded instance so far was 37 people, split across 18 ships, all in the same scenario, and not one of them was sitting in the same room as another player. According to the documentation from our hosting service, we can support much more than that.

I've personally designed a few of the scenarios, and I am considered the pro-level benchmark for whether a particular scenario is "too hard" for even a small fleet of 2-3 ships. I go into it on my own, on a ship that normally uses a crew of three, and still tear it up. For reference, most of the harder scenarios normally require 3-5 fully crewed ships. I've still beaten all but one of the scenarios we've created so far, under those conditions. Then again, part of my job is to find ways to win them, despite near impossible odds, and without cheating (yes, I have magical game dev powers there.) The scenario I'm currently designing absolutely requires 7-8 fully crewed ships at least, and will take 45-60 minutes to complete, IF they can win. We're talking "Kobayashi Maru" level difficulty, here.

Just last night, Carmine (the creator) and I were interviewed about it. If you're interested, you can watch it here. It will be archived on Youtube within a few days, as of this post. We even made the Steam "launch" date announcement during the podcast, as an exclusive for them.

If that doesn't cover "just about everything you wanted to know" about it, you can just PM me. I won't mind.

On february 11, 2015

I cannot stress enough how important that report is.

If I hear about rulebreaking, and there is no report filled.... All I can do is breathe deeply, watch my navel, and go Mmmmmmmmmooooooooo, which sadly is the opposite of Oooooooooooooommmmmmmm and doesn't seem nearly as effective against griefers.

Note that not ALL rulebreakers will get more than a close look from a mod. Certain types of rulebreaking are a bit outside of our intended judgement system - those we will decide if action should be taken immediately about. Normal rulebreaking goes through the normal sanction process. If you think you have a really serious problem on your ship, 1) report it 2) throw a PM to me and Spazticus. Step 1 is not optional.

On february 12, 2015
Aceb
NGJonWhile we are on the subject, the use of radio pirate would seem to be to get players to distrust other players and turn on each other. so what is legal and illegal to use radio pirate for. obviously i'm not gonna start spouting racial and homophobic slurs or anything but i can use it to for example get human players to provoke other players like ' geez does commander jin even do ANY work on this ship?'

If 'murica case is closed and you speaking of any other situation yes. I saw sometimes mushes who transfer with someone and use pirate radio to talk as their old body. I mostly find this skill useful in hands of someone who's creative, good in making disguise or well... make a bigger chaos.
On february 12, 2015
[7950824]

"geez does commander jin even do ANY work on this ship?" Sure, you can use stuff like that.

Here's the dividing line I'd recommend for mush play - do not use any tactics which you think would either:

1) Make a reasonable player believe rules were being broken.

2) Include 'negative out of game factors', such as copying a griefer's taunting message or repeatedly threatening to report someone for random killing if they actually do kill you.

Mush can be in some interesting situations, and a very confident mush who got caught with some pretty significant evidence, against a not so experienced human team could for instance say "That evidence you claim is hogwash. It's not enough evidence, and if you kill me or get me killed I'm reporting you. You're breaking rules if you kill me and risking losing the chance to play" - that's not a fair lie to hit a player with. Especially not over and over. If you want to warn someone they break the rules - and you're telling the truth - do so once only. If they keep breaking that or other rules - treat them like the rulebreaker they are, but there's no benefit in repeatedly 'warning' - that becomes threatening and a form of harassment. If you're mush - find a way to try to win that doesn't include lying about what the rules are or if someone's behavior is breaking rules.
On february 13, 2015
npfan

Let me just make a succinct point:

Mush play or not, do not mimic a griefer. That only glorifies the griefer, and will only make the situation worse, not better. You are ruining the game of Mush in many different ways by imitating a notorious griefer. Also, there is no guarantee your profile may be safe from the crosshairs of mods who are doing the best they can to quickly stop this griefer.
On february 13, 2015
DarkTheRaven

So something I've been wondering: is it against the rules for you to help your team from the grave,

i.e. you die but happen to know each others usernames and the surviving mush provides you with details to which you make plans for them
On february 13, 2015
[6826491]

Is it explicitly against the rules? I'm going to say no, but it's not exactly "fair", either.

If a player reveals information in the forum or IRC about the ship they're currently on, it's generally considered fair game to use that information against them. Sure, it's metagaming, but that's why we usually suggest that people not give too many details about their current ship on the forum.

Things like, "I'm Mush Raluca and my partner is Hua. We just converted two people!" will probably get the person making the comment (and a few other people) killed. That's what I'd consider a newbie mistake, all in all. Sometimes people have to learn the hard way not to reveal more information than they absolutely have to on the forum, even when asking a very specific game question.

Let's contrast that with a now-dead player giving secret (and specific) advice to a still-alive partner. Assuming nobody else from the ship is giving out detailed information about the ship's events, that dead player is still influencing the ship's outcome, in a direct fashion. It smacks of being unethical to me.

That said, if the living player were asking for a rule clarification, or general game advice, that wouldn't be questionable. I think it might cross an ethical line if it went from general advice to "This is how you win.", if you see the distinction I'm making here.
On february 13, 2015

Professeur Hershel Layton pour vous servir

If you leave the bridge, I will shoot and kill you. If you take ANY action before eating two bananas at the beginning of next cycle in front of everyone on the bridge, I will shoot and kill you.

If you leave the bridge, I will hunt you down and kill you. If you take any action before consuming two bananas in front of the entire bridge crew, I will shoot and kill you.

TeufelsAdvokat

Spydu62

On february 13, 2015
[6826491]
Spydu62One player is saying this in my game against our Paola. We're agree it's against the rules to oblige her to do the food test ?

You're correct. You may not compel a player to food test themselves, and killing them solely based on their refusal to be tested is definitely reportable. In other words, there is no evidence, other than the refusal to test themselves, so the murder isn't justifiable. Murdering someone under those circumstances can lead to a sanction.

If the player(s) doing the killing already have good reason to kill the player (in this case Paola) without the test, then it's within the rules to ask them to test themselves. Then that would be giving the player a chance to exonerate themselves with a test, because there is enough existing evidence to justify killing them.

One clarification: Players can always ask someone to test themselves, and that's legal. Saying, "You should be a confirmed human before you read a Mage Book." is acceptable, for example. It's up to them whether they want to test themselves, and then read the book.

What isn't legal is forcing someone to test themselves.
On february 13, 2015
[7950824]

If you have enough evidence against a player to legally kill them, because they appear to be mush, it is legal to 'require' them to take a mush test or be killed. Here's why it's legal:

1) In this circumstance, you could legally kill them outright instead. This is technically a complex and risky method of killing them.

2) If they are mush, you've chosen to weaken your position - you're letting your target and the mush team (including them or not) that the person is caught. A good mush team, or even just a good accused mush, now knows they are in that situation, and I assure you they will be deciding what to do about it. A common response of a real mush to such a tactic would be to rampage at a moment of their choosing - if you hadn't warned them by demanding test or die - your team probably wouldn't have had to risk their rampage at a moment of their choosing. Thus by offering this 'choice', you actually risk hurting your team.

3) If there is all that evidence they appear to be mush, but are actually human - they are a legal kill, but you actually hurt your team by taking the kill. In that situation, you are actually giving your team (and maybe the community) the best, (but risky!) gift possible - you are telling this (inexperienced? Unlucky? Newbie and innocent?) player that they have a chance to save themself. For a newbie who followed tutorial tips and had some bad luck, that can be the difference between frustration at being killed with no real understanding why, and (hopefully!) learning more about the game and being treated to some very intensive instruction (your suspicious player, now proven non-alpha if they cooperated, is still a player who apparently doesn't know how to not be mushy - you're going to help this person for the rest of the game, right? If I'm mush on your ship, please say no.... I'd love most to convert that 'proven human' but always acting mushy person )



Under most circumstances, forced mush tests are sanctionable - just like under most circumstances, killing another character is sanctionable. You need evidence, reason to believe that your target is an appropriate target, to avoid sanction. Best 'rule of thumb' I can offer: If you feel sure you could kill that person without risking a sanction, you probably are safe to offer them a mush test or die, without risking sanction.


'Too much' threat can be a problem too. It's possible to be so hostile in how you threaten that you earn a sanction for T&C 'do not threaten' rules, or the Mush rule about not being actively negative. However, there's grey surrounding those hard rules, and the intent is not to prevent drama or acceptable strategy from being used - just to prevent abuse.
On february 13, 2015

Flash
SpazticusIf the player(s) doing the killing already have good reason to kill the player (in this case Paola) without the test, then it's within the rules to ask them to test themselves. Then that would be giving the player a chance to exonerate themselves with a test, because there is enough existing evidence to justify killing them.

When exactly is 'enough evidence' considered enough?
On february 14, 2015
Aceb
FlashWhen exactly is 'enough evidence' considered enough?

When it's not your imagination and you take it out of blue. Evidence that might actually proof something and isn't forced to be one (aka self-explain)
On february 14, 2015
[7950824]

Totally a grey area.

It can be wise, below a player's death message, to explain why they were killed. In case the dead one has no idea why they died (new players are almost always in this category, but the experienced can feel this way too), list the evidence. This can also help save your life from confused and suspicious shipmates who had no idea why that player was suddenly killed.

How much evidence do you need? For that - I advise you to assume that it would need to be acceptably convincing to a group of experienced, honest players who know the rules and intend to be fair - I think I'm safe in describing the SDF team as such.

For myself, things which I find greatly unconvicing have included in the past: Moving to kill or forcibly test more than two players, just going down the line of suspects, all of them roughly equally suspected and all getting killed or tested. Picking one character out of a crowd of similar suspects to target, with no other reasoning - example if 3 players get dirty without explanation, and you lock on one of them, and that's your evidence - that player got dirty without explanation... I'm unlikely to feel you did anything but randomly select one of the crowd.

It's important to mention that you do not have to be correct - just honest. Being wrong is not against the rules, and this IS a game about tricking people not on your team... at least that's one of many acceptable ways to play. Getting tricked is not going to make you sanctionable, but you should be able to show a clear evidence trail leading to your decision to kill a specific player - and ideally be flexible as new evidence continues to come in.

But again, it's a grey area, and if you're reported for possibly random killing, a team of judges and maybe mods as well will look it over and vote. If you are trying to be reasonable and honest, we're likely to notice that and vote about what we see.
On february 14, 2015
DarkTheRaven

On february 18, 2015
Infection

Can someoen report you for joking around with Neron?... I said once chun was dead (obviously she wasn't) and that the second shower was dismentled...
On february 18, 2015
[6826491]

It can lead to a report, if people take you seriously. People who don't know about the /neron command have a tendency to panic when they see "joking" announcements like that. People have even been killed on Mush-free ships just because someone decided it would be funny to use /neron to claim that someone was Mush. The same end result has happened via the Pheromodem, too.

That said, err on the side of, "If it might cause a panic, or get innocent people killed, then don't risk saying it."
On february 18, 2015
Infection

Can it lead to a sanction? He didn't say anything on chun's death (nobody's dead on the ship), he just said he reports me cause he's tired when i announced the dismentling of the second shower...

It doesn't hurt anybody

On february 18, 2015
[6826491]

Without looking at the logs for your ship, I'll just say that in general, statements like those could potentially be seen as Incitation to Spoil the game. In other words, someone panics because of that announcement, and kills an innocent player all because of a joke...thus spoiling the game. That doesn't guarantee a sanction, of course, but there's no reason to think it's worth the risk.

"It doesn't hurt anybody" doesn't really apply here, since you really don't know how people are going to react to it, and every crew would react differently to seeing something like that.

I was recently on a ship with a player who used /neron to state that (paraphrasing here) "An Anonymush was detected.", several days after we were confirmed to be Mush-free. The crew definitely panicked, until I managed to reassure most of them that we were indeed Mush-free. Even through the end of that voyage days later, a few people were still in doubt whether there were any Mush among us. Someone could have very easily been killed over that "joke".

You might want to think of what was said on your ship versus mine in terms of scale, but you shouldn't.

You actually just proved my point about why you shouldn't make announcements like that. Someone took it seriously, and reported you, specifically because they took it seriously. Further, just from that snippet of text, it suggests that the Stephen player may even give up on the game because of it.

If he does give up on the game after this point, then your ship loses an active player, the active skill of a Shrink, and the human team ultimately suffers. Oh, and since surrender is against the rules, Stephen giving up on the game would also be a rule violation, if he takes that step.

So, please rethink the notion of "it doesn't hurt anybody."

On february 18, 2015
[6826491]

Part of our job as the SDF is to make sure that people don't get killed, just because someone took a joke too far.

The act is questionable, at least in this particular context. Bear in mind that some people really like to troll their ships, and they don't care if anyone dies as a result. If we make an exception for this sort of "joke", it leaves the door open for people who want to push the allowable threshold even further. I'm not guaranteeing a sanction for this incident, but sanctions aren't the only possible ramification here, as my other posts stated.

So if we do allow it...it's then a question of exactly where to draw the line, especially in a game like this where paranoia gets people killed literally every day. People get killed for all sorts of reasons, and sure, you can't please everyone when defining the lines to not be crossed. However, this isn't as simple as saying, "don't say this." It's along the lines of, "If you make an announcement like that, and someone (including you) gets killed over it, then you're the one who will be held responsible for that outcome."

More to the point, I'm erring on the side of "don't be a dick." Getting people to panic over the (fake) loss of a shower very nearly crosses that line. I've never said that you can't joke around with your crew, though there are limits on what you should and shouldn't say on ships.
On february 18, 2015
[7950824]

Here is how I like to best summarize the two rules that affect jokes like that, and here's how I'd be thinking if a jokester was reported, and I had to get involved in the sanction process for it:

Do not play against your team.

Do not be so negative that you make interacting with you and the game you are a part of a horrible experience. It is not necessary to be perfect, but consistent generalized or specific negativity or hostility can be sanctionable. Additionally, do not encourage, invite, or demand that others break these rules - attempting to do so, successfully or not, can be sanctioned.

I see those as two different rules, by the way. An action could break either one, or both, or neither.

A player's intention to make a joke means far less than the effects of their joke - and how that player reacts to those effects. We do get to judge on perceptible intention - but we also are allowed to judge based on perceptible actions - and we get the whole shiplog of actions to review. Your intentions we often have to guess at - your actions and words we can see as facts. Judges often like facts.

If you do something on your ship, or cause something to happen on your ship, which reasonable people are likely to agree was harmful to your ship - well, what did you do then? What did you do as the harm was starting, or even as you made your joke to begin with, that helped ensure you were not harming your team even if harm to your team was a possible result? Do your intentions appear to follow the rules? Do your actions support your (claimed? guessed?) intentions?

Making a threatening joke can kind of be like starting a dangerous expo. If you were reported by someone who felt you launched an expo at a bad time or in a bad way, one that got people killed needlessly - we'd look at that those two rules most. Would a reasonable player think that expo (or joke) was good for the ship? Would a reasonable player think your timing and preparation was suicidal for yourself or others, or otherwise trying to hurt your team?

Sometimes you have to make an expo, but you never have to make a joke. The best way to safely joke on a ship is to be aware of and considerate of others' enjoyment of it - don't make a joke only because it's funny to you, think for a moment longer - decide if you think your shipmates will get enjoyment from the joke - or at least not freak out from it. If you're making your joke for the purpose of trying to freak people out, well.

Ladies and gentlemen, the interpretation of the rules above is pretty clear that this is potentially sanctionable: Additionally, do not encourage, invite, or demand that others break these rules - attempting to do so, successfully or not, can be sanctioned if you're hoping people freak out, you're hoping they do what, exactly? If you don't care about them enjoying what's going on or not, you also are risking wandering into this territory: Do not be so negative that you make interacting with you and the game you are a part of a horrible experience.

Risky stuff, if you choose to take your play there.
On february 23, 2015
