Sorry to necro the topic if it's inappropriate but I wanted to add my opinion :
Rules aside, I don't see how this is a great achievement simply because it's theoretically not very difficult to do at all.

A silver Raluca can do this with help of one other person in a single cycle if inclined. I've seen it happen many times. The PILGRED rush + captain transfer mush strategy comes to mind. It happened to me two ships ago, in fact (all 0% to 100% done in a single cycle; they still lost because I guarded + ceasefired in FC when I saw the ER party in PDA though). On my randoms that aren't utter trainwrecks, or castings, PILGRED is usually up from 0% to 100% in 1- 6 cycles, especially if I'm tech.

Really, the only reason this isn't happening every other game is the lack of inclination.

And because we're all a bunch of goodie-two-shoes law abiders?
Not murderous lunatics AI like cough-someone-cough...

- The Mush infect and kill all but one human
- They are revealed to all be Mush
- They keep the human alive as a Hostage, so that NERON doesn't kill them. They order the human not to attack them, and the human obeys. Finally, they give a few ground-rules such as 'stay out of the lab!'

Would this be possible without any party being banned? Or would you have to imprison through a mix of jamming doors and shoving with Solid?

On march 16, 2015
[7950824]

Cooperation is not allowed.

So long as every player on that ship is trying to get a win for their team (Humans for human win, mush for mush win) there is nothing wrong with

- The Mush infect and kill all but one human
- They are revealed to all be Mush
- They keep the human alive as a Hostage, so that NERON doesn't kill them.

Secrecy is NOT required of mush. If you can see a way to get a mush win without secrecy, go for it. Roughly one third of my mush wins occurred after I was known to be mush (Sometimes I died before the humans finished dying, sometimes not). I've had a blast being a known mush and manipulating situations so that I could not be killed yet, or so that it cost so much to kill me right then and there were other urgent priorities that needed doing as much or more than killing me... Rarely I've managed to inconvenience the active humans so greatly that they were mostly defensive. There are strategies involving ceasefire and the capacity limitation of Icarus Bay that can help mush survive after being revealed.

If you have something like 8 active mush and 1 active human, the human probably cannot kill all the mush and get back to sol - but that human has to try. That human will be a pain to keep alive - because only humans get panic attacks - with only one human, that player will get ALL the panic attacks, potentially many per cycle.

This is a problem though:

-They order the human not to attack them, and the human obeys. Finally, they give a few ground-rules such as 'stay out of the lab!'

Humans and mush cannot knowingly cooperate. That human may -choose- to appear to obey while preparing however they are trying to win.

Example: I am your human. I think 'Oh @#$@#, I have 1 move, 0 AP, and there are 8 living mush and me'. You tell me to cooperate and you let me live as human for now, I tell you thank you (maybe report you for inciting spoiling - that is sanctionable of you to do), and use my time to get AP to try and kill you all. I have to - have to - I cannot win while there are mush alive. I know who the mush are. I MUST kill you or die in the attempt. I will not stop trying to kill you (thus I am not sanctionable). I'm not in trouble because you made the deal to me or because I appear to accept it - so long as I try to win for my team. You can be in trouble for offering it.

A very legal way to do this plan:

Keep 1+ humans alive and human, the ones you believe are easiest to trick. They can even be inactives that are kept alive by Janice comforts and medkit fighting off starvation. I recommend keep more than one alive - panic attacks are NASTY when there's only one player getting all of them. Do your very very best to make those humans believe you're all human, and seek Eden together.
On march 16, 2015
sperbi

Imagine mush team woudl offer to take care of moral and health if human is doing certain things... if human wouldn't do that, human would die, which would be not too much different from suicide, which is also against rules actually
I think there are... quiete a lot mush player here who would enjoy being in the situation of either the mushes or the victim, the last human.
But even then the human would/should probably just wait for an opportunity to strike back and kill one or more mushes.
On march 16, 2015
[7950824]

Personally, I'd love being that one human, other than that I know panic attacks would kill me quickly

I'd probably explain to the overwhelming mush horde that it's on them to win for their team... and on me to win for mine. And their game ends when I die, and they want a specific win - that's all 100% legal. Up to them I guess to keep me alive if they want to try for that win! I don't have to do anything they say, THEY want their specific mush win. I don't have to cooperate - and I won't. (And duh, I'm punishable if I DO cooperate). I'd probably be perfectly clear about not being at full health and encourage them to heal me (Mush AP being spent to help human, I human am OK with this). I'd probably be quick and frequent to point out that I might not be max morale - and maybe they should fix this. I might even agree to DTT, reminding them that they don't WANT me spored, do they? They want their precious different win, me converted isn't going to get them that.

Cause me staying alive doesn't conflict with a human win - it's an essential part of it if humans are to win when I am the last human.

Mush resources being spent on an essential part of a human win condition does not disturb me as a human getting those resources spent on. Nor does it bother me as a mod - because it is legal for players of either side to play for a specific win - as long as the mush are keeping that human alive FOR that specific win (even if it is just a longer time the ship is alive while they try for Eden) and not so that the human can kill them all and reclaim the human win I wouldn't vote to sanction it.

Now, I'd expect as that human I'd get away with murder, literally. I wouldn't try to kill the mush most needed to keep me alive first - I'd try to kill the others. Shrink and leader mush would be the last I tried to kill - they have to go but they don't necessarily have to go first. The mush want their precious better wincon - are they really going to throw away their chance to get Eden because me solo human managed to kill one of their number? I don't think so.

The real stress would be if I managed to find a way to get several of them dead - the mush team is obligated to kill or turn me before they lose if it gets close to them maybe losing.

Like if I managed to kill the one with the hacker kit and move away from the planet during an expo, maybe now there are just 2-3 mush left. Those mush probably will need to kill or convert me fast, before I can get the AP back to kill them.

I don't see a human win happening. But I'd love to try.

On march 27, 2015
spacekadt

Guys, people are allowed to be upset. They're allowed to be glad that a ship is over if they weren't having fun. They're allowed to express their displeasure.

If it's *abusive*, that's a different story. Report anything you see that crosses that line into abuse, but few judges (if any) will sanction anyone for saying "go fuck yourself"... especially if they're provoked (whether intentionally or not).

On april 4, 2015
[6826491]
BubaBut people common we are on a ship in a middle of the space, there is no law,

Incorrect. The SDF rules (and MT's rules) are the law, and if you don't follow them, you do so at your own peril. you don't have to listen to people if you don't want(but this will raise questions if you are mush), my point is if chun wants to research the mycoscan research it, if terrence or raluca wants to dismantle shower dismantle it, That's fine, to an extent. You still need to work with your team, and sometimes that means you compromise in order to do what's best for the team. Dismantling both showers as a human is clearly playing against the team, and such behavior leads to a sanction.if the ship is not full than go early to sol,NO. Returning to Sol before the ship is full is a Harmful Return. NEVER do this on a random ship, or there will be severe consequences. why don't you erase hunters until everybody wakes up, we don't want to give humans advantages if the pilots use ap to kill hunters before mush selection do we(because the pilot can be the mush), or the ship to take damage there for damaging humans. Because that is the way the game is designed. If your ship is slow to fill, and your pilots don't shoot down the initial hunters, you could be at under half your armor before the ship fills. Then you deal with the consequences, and play the game to its natural conclusion. Developers need more thinking to do, before they apply the rules because the game is not perfect. And again we are in a middle of the space its just 16 people on that ship, not the whole government.This in particular is an irrelevant argument. The SDF, both the mods and its judges, are comprised of players, and the rules apply equally to everyone. The rules are intended to give both teams a fair shot at winning, in an environment that encourages team play. That's why the Neutral Play rules exist, why we sanction griefers, why RP is not an acceptable excuse to break rules, and why occasional swearing (at nobody in general) is tolerated, but swearing at other players isn't. We have rules of conduct for these reasons as well. Anyone who can't follow those rules should not be playing the game; the community will be better off without them.

On april 7, 2015
Aerial

When the mush team is winning and an angry human PM me and said "u faggot" it's reportable, right?

On april 7, 2015
[7950824]

It's reportable. Definitely potentially sanctionable. I'd prefer that you didn't try to purposefully try to get them to become less of a grey case (and that if you did, that you're also reported for it, as 'incitation to spoiling' is also sanctionable, and far less gray!) by trying to provoke them to swear at you more.

When I view such cases, I try to look at both the specific accusation, as well as any other broken rules I spot (You may not have known they held an item before mush selection, but if they did, I will know), and also their general overall play.

Some people play strongly and clearly inside the rules for most of the ship, then do something that could be wrong. Something that intent matters about.

In those cases, I consider how they played all ship, and assume that they probably had similar intent when they did that grey area.

Likewise, if someone has been very marginal, playing close to the edge of the rules, more for their own enjoyment then to say, try to help their team (and themselves) win, I am far more likely to assume that the gray area motivation is much like the intentions they showed all ship.

We really don't care about minor, provoked swearing, especially if it's not personal. (Bleep! 53 hunters! We're bleeped!) We really, really care about people making ships horrible places that are a pain to interact on. (What are you doing, bleep? The bleep you thinking, can you even think?)

To be 100% safe, stay on the side of the angels, if you swear, make it impersonal. When you interact, do so in a way that welcomes and encourages others to interact positively back with you. I've yet to see someone sanctioned for doing that.... and I can't wait to clear any I ever find.

On april 8, 2015
[7950824]

I'd love to have Kuan on my ship, on my team. Enfold him and offer him a chance to learn how to see these challenges as challenges, not as brick walls smacking him at 60 mph.

Report him if you feel he is breaking the rules.

If you do, the judges will read all the evidence, including noticing how many ships he has played, and will vote on a verdict. We're even capable of providing a warning that is only a warning, (not cleared, which is innocent, not sanctioned, which is guilty), about language use.

If this ship were in my hands only to judge, with everyone quoted having been reported and all the evidence I had was what you've quoted (I'm not saying quote more), I wouldn't vote sanction any of you. I wish Kuan was speaking (and thinking) differently, but I also would be pleased to see Chao speak a bit differently too. Chao's not breaking rules, but could he handle things differently? Well sure. Perhaps 'more of this'

"If someone had secured an extinguisher in the event of pyro, the ship would not be on fire.
If someone had healed Jin Su after he was roasting in the fire for several cycles before asking for a heal, he would have had too much hp to kill practically;
If someone had fixed the shower temporarily so Finola can clean off, or dtt, she wouldn't have committed suicide
These things only take about 4-6 pa tops, instead, everyone is wasting all their pa attacking mush, giving them ample time to heal in between, not even focusing attacks on the same one ..."

Perhaps more guidance and support (wait, what, a mush guiding and supporting humans? Well.... why not? Long as the mush wins, why not be oh-so-nice about it? Hats off to you, Europa... and others I won't name at the moment ) helps make future games better, for everyone involved.

Maybe Kuan's saying that because he's a jerk who wants to bring down the mush team's win and ruin good feels. But maybe Kuan's saying that because he doesn't understand his (and his team's) options, and because angry words are some of the little ammunition you know have, when you feel powerless and believe yourself mocked in your helplessness. Maybe he doesn't know how to win as human or mush.... Personally, I can love to gloat... but I don't get much from gloating over the inexperienced.... now, let me pin a pro, who could have stopped me but didn't? Gloves off, baby, lets go for three rounds. If I got taken to Kuan's position? Typically, I'm going to love every moment of it, and my words to Chao would be full of poisonous praise as I fought regain my team's direction and recover. But I know how. I've won and lost as both sides enough to have options that a player talking like Kuan wouldn't.

Some philosophy from me about how I decide 'grey area sanctions'... Something I might tell someone who wrote to the mod inbox asking about a sanction for something that sounds like a grey area to me:

I'll also look over 'everything' you've done of course... that's very useful in figuring out what your intentions in general are. If many of your actions are useful, good for your team stuff - that helps me assume that your intentions are mostly innocent, and if I see grey areas I should assume your unclear intentions there were the same as the rest of your intentions. Similarly if you didn't do much that appeared to be trying to work for a win for your team, then in areas where your intentions are hard to tell, you probably were not working to help your team then either.

That's part of why I keep talking about 'needs more evidence', that I would need the whole ship logs to say. Because this is potentially gray area; sure, it goes into the area of 'personal attack', but is it also 'provoked'? Probably. Would a few words of advice and guidance prevent future problems, or is this Kuan someone who was hard to get along with in good times and now impossible to interact with in bad times too?

But the above is very much part of my personal opinion. Interpretation of the rules is something we allow the judges to often do for themselves. If reported, the judges will review the ship and vote. If the player is warned or sanctioned and contacts the mod inbox, that's when I get a chance to possibly step in.

And I'm not saying that the Chao quoted above must change his behavior or intentions in speaking either. Just.... in my opinion. If I'm -that- much better a player than someone. If I have 50 ships to their one, and can glance at three rooms worth of roomlogs and read their whole strat; and they don't even know when to scream mush about pretty obvious play on my side.... well. I -may- tease them a bit. But my tone in it is going to be tuned towards 'and here's how you could have caught me, here's where I messed up and you could have won', instead of 'and here's how hopeless your situation is, and here's why you cannot hope to win'. Just a style difference. Both are legal. Both are fun. One's more fun for more people on a ship.

Course, if I think I got a pro pinned.... Well. I might treat them just like I'd treat a newbie. That's a.... very nice way to be.... extremely insulting too. If that's my goal, and it doesn't break any rules either.
On april 8, 2015
kreton

Or killed him, I really wasn't far away from it and as Chao with wrestler I would have been able to do it easily.

For me, I think if it's done with sensitivity and sportsmanship, it can add to the fun of both sides. But like anything else, it can be taken past the point of fun for one side, or even both.

On april 8, 2015
NERON

I was the Chao...

Since apparently everyone in this thread has missed it the first time, I'm bringing up :
Chao : Let's play a game!! The rules are simple; you must try to kill me before I spike you. If everyone becomes mush, you lose. If you kill me, you still lose because you no longer have pilots!
Hua : chao is the mush now
Finola : you're a genius hua

[ one day later]
Chao : It would have been fun to win. It would have been fun to even screw up the mush plan. It's not impossible. You had your pilots, more than one, even. You had your technician and magebooks. The stuff I said before was misinformation meant to be demoralizing. Causing chaos on your team is good for my team, after allNotice how the first person to reply to the post on their lack of pilots was a character whose level one skill is pilot? Pointing out how hopeless their situation was (while it totally wasn't yet) was something I was doing as a tactic this run to prevent them from organizing themselves into something that could develop into a problem to me. If you tell some people that they're out of options repeatedly enough, they're going to stop using the mental resources to look for them, which is exactly what happened in this instance


But that was just my secondary goal in all that text. To understand my primary goal, you need to understand the situation at the time; - Chao - Alpha; outted immediately spiking Ian; has Crazy Eyes
- Ian - Outted immediately on conversion
- Janice - Alpha; never outted; communication was difficult, this made her less valuable
- Raluca - Converted and outted mid-game
- Stephen - useless muteOf the available mush, if the humans were smart, they would attack Ian first. This removes pacifism for all of the other mush. Who should the humans absolutely not attack first? The one we'd want you to :Chao : Let's play a game!! The rules are simple; you must try to kill me before I spike you. If everyone becomes mush, you lose. If you kill me, you still lose because you no longer have pilots!
Finola : kill chao firstCrazy Eyes stack with pacifism. This makes 5AP per punch. To be honest, it was a shot in the dark but once I realized it worked, it was too good to shut down. Janice, Raluca, Stephen never said anything about being mush and in turn never got hit once despite extracting and being spiked in public. Ian got kicked off the bed a few times, especially once he started speaking up. If you check out the end page history, you'll see that they were attacking me more than anyone else (Kuan Ti actually attacked me twice in the middle of our exchange posted earlier).

As also mentioned, sometimes when humans are focused attacking mush, they're not bothering to upkeep themselves or the ship. That was also part of the plan. Finola and Jin Su died as a direct result on that ship

Anyways, the taunting was for the purpose of tanking for my team (not that I wasn't also enjoying it to an extent). It wasn't as if it was out of control either. The worst that came out was maybe :Kuan Ti : Has anybody seen the Extinguisher?
Jin Su : i have been in all storages and corridors and there is no extinguisher, i think its logical to think that mushes took and hid it.
Chun : then would i say, that this will be the end
Chao : Hey now, don't be so pessimistic! I'm sure that extinguisher is lying around behind a shelf somewhere. You just need to search. We can make this the minigame; find the extinguisher, before the fire finds you!

^ trying to make them waste AP searching there

NERON : Death registered : Jin Su
Chao : Well, what do you humans have to say for yourselves? He was screaming for your help for hours, you know. You only have yourselves to blame

^ that much was true

Chao : Wow, a grand total 3hp damage from the all of you over 8 cycles? Humans really are squishy

^ another 'demoralizing lie'
Kuan Ti never said anything about it until the F-bombs came out spontaneously (his, not mine). I toned it down after that. The game was over for real by then so there was no point keeping it up. If it makes it any better, the other 4 mush really were having a good time. The rest of the crew, though probably not having a good time, weren't hurling those kinds of insults

So really, that was psychological warfare gone ... uh ... too well?

On april 9, 2015
[6826491]

When it comes to multi-teamsters, you should only report them if they commit any griefing. In that case, please report EACH of the accounts, so we have a report on file for all of them. If you strongly suspect them of XP farming, or breaking any other rules, it's fair to report that.

Otherwise, treat them like any other inactive: Watch them for Mushy behavior, and trade them away if the opportunity arises; or kill them if they survive longer than they reasonably should.
On april 9, 2015
[7950824]

Or if they are active, treat them like you would any other active; watch them for questionable behavior. it can be very difficult for even say, two siblings who both play mush, perhaps from one computer in their home's living room..... one of them is mush and the other is not.... how to hide that so you don't even appear to be hiding something?

It's often an impossible situation for the both of them, to avoid breaking any rules and both play their best for their teams on that ship. The SDF doesn't have any easy answers either for people in that position, but easy or hard, the rules really do need to be followed.

...and to answer your question, you can report people by hovering your cursor over any post you feel is related to a (potentially) reportable behaviour, then the "Report?" button should appear. You can do it as long as you didn't confirm your death. After that, it's too late and you can just hope someone else does it in place of you.
On april 10, 2015
Kyubey

There can be really lots of reasons to abadon players like that.
- a human forgot to check who is outside - well, making mistakes and killing humans like that is sad, but not reportable
- a mush saw you, but acted like a human who did not check
- you were outside for too long, and team decided that waiting for you is hurting team more, then abadoning
- or maybe humans thought you are mush and just used a good chance
Once we had a mush suspect, he was pilot and we wanted to kill him. A lot of hunters came, so we asked him to do all 10 shoots and to land two cycles later. He did it...and was abadoned. Hunters killed, mush killed, no ap used at all (anyway we wanted to visit that planet).

You can report them ofc, we will look and decide what really happened there. While it looks unlikely to be some kind of rule breaking - you can report in any situation you are not sure if any rules were broken

On april 14, 2015
Interrobang

Actually, from what I remember from a few threads around the time of the beta, Neutral Play was mostly intended to keep any individual player from gaining the upper hand. For example, holding onto or hiding a blaster or knife before mush selection so that you were the only one who knew where it was. Or even going so far as to hide the apron so that if you got selected as mush you'd have a sizable lead.

This also seems to include rushing and finishing certain anti-mush research before everyone was on board, like the Anti-Mush soap and the Mycoscan. (Which are really the only two particularly anti-mush researches you can do before the ship starts). So I don't very much like the "there's nothing to detect, so it's neutral" logic. By that logic, both the mycoscan and the super soap would be totally okay to rush pre-mush selection.

I would argue that, unlike the research, moving the cameras is:
1. Reversible. Mush could take them down and do away with them if they're clever. The mycoscan not so much.
2. Low cost. You don't have to pour more than a few AP into getting cameras set up. Research, not so much.
3. Standard, as stated before. I've never seen a ship that didn't put cameras in each dorm. And only a few ships I've had put the 3rd camera somewhere other than the bridge.

Plus it also walks that line in which there are some things that are beneficial to the humans that it would be incredibly silly NOT to do before mush selection. Like shooting hunters and dealing with the banana plants.

tl;dr, from what I know it isn't NECESSARILY neutral, but it's not against the rules as most of the community seems to agree it balances things out somehow.
On april 14, 2015
Kyubey

individual player from gaining the upper hand
Cameras are same as anti-mush research, that was removed before selection, it helps all humans, not a single player like carrying stuff. And it's totally not neutral.

Still it's allowed as an exception to balance the starting conditions, as a lot of players cannot be online exactly on mush selection and the game will turn to "who was active first gets great advantage". Check castings - there mush and humans start together with no cameras installed and everything is ok for humans (even too well )

But if you don't want to install any cameras before selection - don't, it's up to you.
On april 14, 2015
[6826491]

Back when I made this thread, the Neutral Play rules were clarified in the initial post. If an individual player has an unfair advantage, then so does their team, by extension. This is why Chun is subject to Neutral Play rules, and she isn't allowed to hold onto the armor and/or any weapon(s) prior to selection. They can most certainly be moved to wherever she is, but everyone has to have an equal opportunity to pick up items at the moment of selection.

Regarding cameras, it can give the Mush team an extreme advantage if cameras aren't in their usual places at Mush selection, since two high level gold Mush can convert a player in an unprotected dorm in just minutes. On the other hand, not every newbie knows to stay under a camera, so there are almost always unprotected targets a Mush team can go for instead. On random ships, having cameras in place prior to selection tends to make for a fairer game. (There's a reason humans who remove cameras from dorms when there are confirmed Mush aboard tend to receive sanctions for griefing.)

Research was also clarified in the initial post of this thread, and neutral researches were defined. This also includes the NCC lenses, because if the Mush want to play the long game or seek an infiltration win, then blowing up the ship runs counter to their strategy. To that end, the Lenses are considered potentially helpful to both teams.
On april 14, 2015
npfan
KyubeyBut if you don't want to install any cameras before selection - don't, it's up to you.

I think this is a key point that needs to be made. If you don't want to install cameras before selection, that's up to you. No one is forcing you. If you want to install the cameras in places other than the dorms, fine. That's up to you. What you can't do is pick up a camera, wait and see what team you're in, and then install it.

InterrobangThis also seems to include rushing and finishing certain anti-mush research before everyone was on board, like the Anti-Mush soap and the Mycoscan. (Which are really the only two particularly anti-mush researches you can do before the ship starts). So I don't very much like the "there's nothing to detect, so it's neutral" logic. By that logic, both the mycoscan and the super soap would be totally okay to rush pre-mush selection.

Those two specific researches are okay as far as I'm concerned. After all, the super soap can burn up and the Mycoscan is only as good as how often the humans check themselves. The whole neutral play issue was partly in response that on some very active ships, particularly the early MMMs, humans were rushing Antispore Gas, Constipaspore Serum, and/or Mycoalarms before the Mush were even selected because the Mush Sample was spawned when the first person woke up. That issue has been mitigated since the devs changed that so the Mush Sample spawns after Mush selection.
On april 14, 2015
Kyubey

Spazticus likes to much these if the Mush want to play the long game or seek an infiltration win, then blowing up the ship runs counter to their strategy
For me it sounds much more then "taking unnecessary risks", when they have to help humans not to stay hiden, but protect the ship from being destroyed.

Still NCC lenses are cool - 2 lenses, shooter and old faithful can easily score 4 kills.
Anabolics are cool too - humans like to take them, and adding 3 spores at the very start, before alarms, is very nice.
Mycoscan looks like not a fair thing, but as it's not very powerful, but takes a lot of ap, I always suggest not to research it before selection - if I'm human, I prefer different stuff, if I'm a mush, I don't want to see such things appearing before I could do anything against that.
On april 14, 2015
Interrobang

I don't know that the issue is with Mush Soap and Mycoscan individually. It's when you have both that it's a huge pain before mush selection. Humans have the means to both detect spores AND destroy them. Yeah, yeah, soap can be destroyed by fire, but I think a fire would pretty much have to start IN the dorm for that to happen. Which I haven't seen happen yet. I'm sure it can, but I haven't seen it. People tend to find fires nearest the dorms pretty quickly in my experience.

Again, neither one on its own is a game over for mush. And people can use their own discretion when helping with those researches knowing full well they could become mush upon selection. As noted before, though, knowing that didn't stop people when they could research more aggressive measures pre-selection. But it does still say in the SDF rules that rushing/finishing anti-mush research pre-selection is against the rules. And those are the only two anti-mush things available pre-mush. So I would assume finishing those two researches is not allowed until mush are on board.

Is that not the case anymore? If it isn't, shouldn't that be taken out of the SDF rules? It's more or less been a non-issue on all of my ships so far, though I have seen some people start work on the mycoscan pre-mush selection. But I wouldn't consider that rushing it.
On april 14, 2015
[6826491]

Let me put it this way: I wouldn't explicitly forbid either research prior to selection at this time, and I can safely say that most ships aren't going to rush both of them before the ship fills. If it suddenly became common practice to rush both of them, and the net effect was a clear and extreme human advantage in game after game...I'd be more than happy to reconsider that position. I don't foresee that happening.

Most research teams will focus on the research that requires the Sample, and that requires some AP to be saved up...AP that likely won't be spent on advancing the soap or mycoscan right away. That all having been said, the strongest position I can take at this time would be to discourage finishing them prior to selection. It's more a guideline than a rule.

It's quite possible to find a planet to expo prior to selection, and you might hit a Mush trap event while there. I theorize that's why both of these can be completed without needing the Sample. (As unlikely as this scenario is, it would be justifiable to have both the Mycoscan and the ability to remove any spores in this instance.)
On april 14, 2015
[7950824]

.... Dark.....

...No. Drat a casting cannot test this, cause they are mush selected as soon as the ship starts.

If anyone ever does an expo to a mush trap crystalite planet before mush selection, then becomes mush and gets a free spore, speak up about it. And/or if you ever get mycoscanner done as well as a mush trap, and know you have a spore but don't get it removed before you become mush, speak up about whether that spore becomes a 'free spore' for you or not. I assume not, but I want it tested..... if it ever happens anyway and someone is sharp enough to report it.
On april 14, 2015
DarkTheRaven

Could that even be tested within the rules? Since it has to be a random


Also to add on Impet:
Assuming the mush who gets the 'free spore' transfers check if the body they leave receives a spore for no reason
On april 15, 2015
[7950824]

Transfer has no reason to be checked; we already know a transfer target loses all spores.

A human becoming a mush through normal means loses all spores (a human who has 2 spores and who eats a triple spored ration becomes a mush with 0 spores).

The only 'untested' part of this is the becoming an alpha mush part. I don't know if the code turns alphas into mush at that moment.... or if it treats them as if they had always been mush (technically they were always mush). If they are treated like they were always mush, then technically that spore they gained from mush trap was given to them as a usable spore, since they were actually a mush (but didn't know) when they got that spore.

Hrm. The most advanced casting ships can have gradually appearing alpha mush, right? That could potentially be a way to test this as well, both through mushtrap and someone eventually becoming alpha with spores (cooperative mush could tell from mush channel who got spores from mush trap, and all can track when/if infected become alphas to see what happens to those spores).

Similarly, cooperative early alphas on gradually appearing mush settings can spread spores around, to see if the late-activating alphas lose them like converted betas would. Related note, probably already known on the French server.... technically since late appearing alphas were always mush and didn't know it.... are they even possible to spore? Would be a neat twist if an early alpha can tell who is going to suddenly realize they are going to become a mush.... because they already are... because it's impossible to spike that 'human' just like it's impossible to spike any other mush.

All this code is already in game, it's just us finding out if it works one way or the other.
On april 15, 2015
[7950824]
DarkTheRavenCould that even be tested within the rules? Since it has to be a random

Sure, stuff gets proven all the time in normal ships without any rules broken.

The thing is, you cannot purposefully set it up if it is playing against your team or breaking neutral play, or breaking any other rules.

However, if say, Interrobang is on a ship as Frieda and scans for a planet, and gets crystalite, and while the ship has 12 people the team decides to do an early expo...

Interrobang helps fill out the expo team....

Mush trap.... Maybe scanner is done, but soap isn't. People work on soap....

Ship fill next cycle....

Interrobang is now a mush. Has access to the mush channel....

Now Interrobang, after the ship is over, can tell us so! much.

Did the mush channel show the infections from mush trap, if any? Neat if the mush channel works even before there are mush.

If it did show who got spores, did Interrobang get one? Or did the other alpha?

Did it show a human infection like normal, or the message of a mush getting another spore in the confusion (since alphas technically were always mush)?

Either way, does Interrobang start his/her mushy career with 0 spores at hand, or 1 spore from the trap?


In that sort of scenario, many, many questions could be answered (after the game is over.... Interrobang grab us loads of screenshots please!) and no rules were even bent in what I described.

Well, there's at least one reason, why to try stay alive as long as possible - casting ticket you (and everyone else from that ship, even if dead long before that) would get, if you make it to day 10.
There may be others but that's one objective I can name right off the top of my head.

Then there are subjective ones - challange, possibility to try things you couldn't try on ship with others beacuse it would be wasting of resources or something like that, distinctions for those things and so on.

On april 19, 2015
spacekadt
1412There's also the fact that (as I'm pretty sure a mod has said at some point), if you ever are reported, having deaths by "putting the "fun" in funeral" can look bad on your permanent record.

That death message could just as easily be a case where you had 1hp left and needed to pick up the medikit to heal yourself and go the random damage. Granted, it's *usually* an actual suicide, but isn't always.

That said, the judges are the ones that go through and assign sanction points and we have no idea who the people are. We can't look at ship history, end words, anything of the sort. We've got the complete ship logs and that's it. You past ship information doesn't play into sanctions in the slightest.
On april 19, 2015
1412

Oh, really? Could've sworn I heard otherwise from someone at some point... ah well. Thanks for clarifying!
On april 19, 2015
[6826491]
1412There's also the fact that (as I'm pretty sure a mod has said at some point), if you ever are reported, having deaths by "putting the "fun" in funeral" can look bad on your permanent record.

I have definitely said that, and there are times when I'm looking at a report and then I'll check the reported player's history. That may include their past ships, how they died, their last words, what else they were reported for (if anything,) and more which I really don't need to reveal at this time.

As Spacey said, the judges aren't able to do this sort of checking, but the mods can. Now, that also doesn't guarantee a sanction because of what could be an unintentional suicide on a past ship...but if there's more than one, that doesn't seem like it could be just an unfortunate coincidence. It could contribute to a big picture of what kind of player you are, and it might influence whether you get sanctioned.
On april 19, 2015
Dzanek
spacekadtThat death message could just as easily be a case where you had 1hp left and needed to pick up the medikit to heal yourself and go the random damage. Granted, it's *usually* an actual suicide, but isn't always.

Remember that healing in the Medlab is safe, but smarter people know this.
But it depends on circumstances. When you got steel plated twice and wanted to heal yourself picking up Medikit and dying by it, it isn't sanctionable even when this person knew the risk. Maybe life isn't more expensive than few MP used on the way to Medlab and back.
Once remember when I had Mush who I provoked to rampage, forcing to eat rations. The Mush got armor and blaster, transferred into Derek, picked up the armor and died because of low HP Derek had while starving inactivity. Still, 2 HP might make all actions risky.
Once I had a plan don't eat 3 days, then lose HP to 1 and transfer before cycle change, leaving this person upon starvation. But still, my plan required removing camera, maybe dismantling would be a choice, with 1 HP. I can't do it on 3 HP because this person might log back in 3 cycles and warn crew.
Sanctionable should be not reporting low HP as human, that you got steel plated, shook in room you were in, burnt, etc. Reportable is when somebody frequently picks up and drops items, or goes to expedition on low HP. This is a kind of suicide which isn't tolerated as a harm against one's own character.
On april 19, 2015
[6826491]
PatrykSzczescieSanctionable should be not reporting low HP as human, that you got steel plated, shook in room you were in, burnt, etc. Reportable is when somebody frequently picks up and drops items, or goes to expedition on low HP. This is a kind of suicide which isn't tolerated as a harm against one's own character.

Actually, that's not how it works. You're partially correct, but I need to set the record straight on the rest.

If you remain active, but don't make any attempt to report your health/morale (assuming the ship's Mush free, and it's safe to do so) you can also be reported for suicide. Basically, part of your job as an active human is to keep yourself alive as long as possible. Allowing yourself to die because you don't care to keep yourself alive, or don't do enough to keep yourself alive, can lead to a Pathetic Suicide sanction.

Some examples of Pathetic Suicides not involving the picking up and dropping of items, and this is NOT an exhaustive list:

Going to a dangerous planet with under 8 (or even 10) HP, without reporting your HP, then dying to accidents or combat can be considered a suicidal act. It's up to you to ask for healing, or to drop the expo gear you're carrying and let someone else go instead. (There are times where the crew is aware of your low HP, and you all know the risks, but you still go anyway - because the alternative is losing your Diplomat and nobody else is online to heal you or take your place, for example. The big difference is in communication, or the lack of it.)

The same applies to long ships in which you don't report your HP (and you've clearly been online to see room events drop your HP.) The loss of an active player almost always hurts the chances of success in voyages, but even more so past D15.

Risky actions taken with your morale can be an issue, too. We sanctioned one player because they died VERY early on, due to morale loss. It was around D4 or D5, as I recall. The reason they died wasn't through other players dying, but because they kept eating rations that were not cooked. Aside from the risk of getting spored, they didn't bother to ask for a Speech or Comfort, nor try to DTT with another player. They just thought that the risk was acceptable, and it wasn't.

Another player was sanctioned for suicide, because they took a pill with a -2 morale effect on it...not just once, but twice. They then died a few cycles later. Once might have been excusable, since it's possible they didn't know what the pill did. But they ate that second pill just two cycles after consuming the first pill, and then died a few cycles later. (Before you ask, they had no illnesses to treat.)

One of the crucial components in each of these cases is a lack of communication. If people don't know you're in trouble, they may not know that you need help. It's not so much "killing themselves with the cat" as "letting themselves be killed in a totally avoidable fashion." Sometimes you can't help it. Morale sources can be exhausted, or you get plated two or three times in a row while sleeping IRL. But if you're human, and you CAN avoid a needless death, then you need to try.
On april 20, 2015
Syvaris

On april 20, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

No. If you have 2 hp left as a human, it's because you were careless and did not ask for healing. And please don't tell me that you can't ask for healing if you're under suspicion. You would have to be extremely unlucky to lose 12 or 14 hp in the first days just by doing actions (which are invisible injuries). If you are so low, it has to be because of roomshakes or steel plates, which are visible for everyone. Unless you crew are so bad at mush hunting that they don't check roomlogs, they will see why you were injured and need healing.

[7838255]

Is it possible to report a player because of what he have said in the End Game Statistics ???

On april 24, 2015
spacekadt
MandyIs it possible to report a player because of what he have said in the End Game Statistics ???
It's not that it annoys me but it is really a Bad word.

People are allowed to curse. If you think it's bad enough that it violates the Terms & Conditions of the site, you can report it directly to a mod, and they might be able to do something about it (but unless it's EGREGIOUSLY bad, that's not likely). But judges cannot see end words nor punish based on them.
On april 25, 2015
wLink

Is it allowed to kill Commander or Communications Officer who isn't doing their job properly e. g. isn't issuing missions, isn't moving ship, etc?
On april 25, 2015
npfan

You should try your best getting around that, such as using the Hacker Kit. However, if the current commander is doing nothing more than hogging the title, you can kill him.
On april 25, 2015
Kyubey

Any kill, that is for best of your crew is allowed.
Mushes can kill mushes, if it helps them to stay hiden or if it's part of their plan. Humans can kill humans to get title or item, they are holding.

There is big difference between "forbidden actions" and "not best actions in this situation" ofc. So if you ask if you will be punished if you kill commander and say it's for title - you probably will not. But if you ask about best tactics around semi-idle commander...then it depends.
On april 25, 2015
sperbi

I don't think you can say it that clearly, Kyubey.
It is probably sanctionable to kill a commander just because the commander is "only" active 2 times a day and moving the ship then, but not able to move at other times though the crew would like to have a more active commander.
If the commander is at least helpful at the times he is active and isn't going inactive, then the crew has to find a way to deal with that situation without killing him unless there are suspicions about him being mush. That's probably one of the reason why there is a hacker kit in first place.

Ps: a hint for people who complain about the many aps of hacking: as soon as someone made it into the system with the hacker kit and doesn't close the window of command terminal, that person can stay logged into it.
So someone may stay there for example to move to a planet and move out of orbit afterwards. Maybe even longer if ship has to flee from hunter waves.
During mush hunt I wouldn't trust everyone to do the hacking though

On april 25, 2015
Kyubey

I don't think you can say it that clearly, Kyubey.
Yes, when we did our statements we had different pictures in mind.

If you have to move just once, when your commander is not active, but he does his job when he comes - ofc hacking is better. But, if you see, that this commander would be constant pain for crew - killing him is good way to deal with problem.

When I suggest to kill commander:
- if your commander gets mark of idle from time to time and doesn't explain that
- if your commander just ignores anything you post in planet thread/pms
- if he delays expo on purpose and doesn't listen to opinions of others, when mushes are present (as it's good mush strategy "we have 20 O2, if he get another +24 it will be a waste, let's wait for 8-10", then move to wrong direction, and kill astroes, then his partners make sure next planet will be missed too)

When killing is bad:
- you have a newbie commander, who try to learn, but don't know stuff - just explain how to do it, what threads to check and how to move the ship
- if he is active regulary, but not too often (here can help talking to him, for example if he's active C5-C6, move to planet on C5, do expo on C6, leave orbit, everyone is happy)
- if he is going to be idle for some time, but warns the crew about it (hacking is good option here)
On april 28, 2015
Dzanek

Is the player punished if he misreads some messages?

She entered Alpha Bay 2 and there were no logs on this cycle. She claimed that logs were defaced. She also claimed that just Terrence would enter the Alpha Bay 2 while defecing and killed him just for it, although he was very useful and trustworthy person.
Another example: Chao checks Raluca and in her actions there's "Extract spore". And she's killed - human. Anyway it made chaos and people were looking for transfer, while nobody thinks that she used Spore Sucker and there was action "Extract spore" when Mush while extracting does "Extract a spore".

npfan

Is the player punished if he misreads some messages?
I don't think anyone should be punished for mistakes, misreading logs included. Ofc if it's done on purpose and it's quite clear from report, it'll be regular griefing.
On april 28, 2015
[6826491]
KyubeyI don't think anyone should be punished for mistakes, misreading logs included. Ofc if it's done on purpose and it's quite clear from report, it'll be regular griefing.

That also depends on how the mistakes were made, how many of them there were, and how it affected the ship.

I had one Eleesha player killing people from the start of the ship, under the premise that "If they're dirty, they must be Mush." Not only was she killing people who got dirty before selection, and it was announced as such...they were all human. This was just barely two cycles after selection, and we had three dead, including Eleesha - we killed her to stop other people from being killed, since she just wouldn't listen to reason.

Even if the intent is not to grief, a player can still seriously spoil a ship's chances of success. It may not have been deliberate, but that level of harm caused by a human player in my ship's example is unacceptable.
On april 28, 2015
[1820396]

Personally, when judging reports about mistakes, attitude of the offender towards his own mistake makes a difference for me too. I tend to be more lenient in cases where the person admitted their own mistake, said sorry and tried to remedy or calm down situation somehow. As opposite to people who tend to be outright arrogant or aggressively defensive when called out.

Everybody makes mistakes from time to time. The point is to admit them and learn from them. Not remain in delusion you've done everything right and the the cause of your mistake is somewhere outside you.
On april 29, 2015
[7838255]

Everybody makes mistakes from time to time.

I got a wrong equation and solved it wrong. Instead of 3 (which is really my morale is) , it showed it should be 4 .
.

spacekadt

Beyond that, I think we've already covered that if someone makes a mistake, it's generally not going to earn a sanction. But in a case like this, it's really not even her mistake, it's yours. She was acting on the information she was given.

On april 30, 2015
[6826491]

The rules regarding cured Mush are that if they decide to talk, they may not lie. You know this rule, since we've had this conversation before. If your cured Mush knows this rule as well, then they are probably telling the truth.

That said, it might be better to not "demand" anything. You have a point in that Pheromodem is probably not needed immediately (unless you have a Cristalite planet lined up) but it's still useful to have later on. Your cured Mush can probably confirm if anyone caught any spores, and that may even change your priority to the Super Soaper or Spore Sucker.

Demanding anything might get someone killed (you or them) so take things back by a step or two and try to defuse the situation. Be willing to compromise and take a third option. Assuming the cured Mush says that nobody is currently spored, then you can reasonably delay the Pheromodem until other immediately beneficial research is done. Even if someone has two spores, they're safe unless they go to a Cristalite planet. The cured Mush already said there are no spores to be caught on the ship, and they can't lie...so logically, you don't need the Pheromodem yet.
On april 30, 2015
[8709657]

Well that is clearly a very controlling Chun but killing you because she disagrees with your advice is just wrong BUT if you have several people chip in, sorting Pheromodem and proving she was wasting crews AP may be the best course of action.
On april 30, 2015
[7950824]

Talk to your ship. Consider maybe cooperating with Chun - after all, will it actually hurt the ship to do it her way? If it is unlikely to change how the ship ends, then it doesn't matter if it's your way or her way. Think about it - it's rare that, assuming there are no more mush, the ship will die sooner because pheromodem was done before scrambler, distiller, and pomade.

Pheromodem helps with communication before brainsync, and it helps with expos to planets with mushtrap crystallite. It's not useless, even with no mush.

One thing to consider discussing with your Chun, is there fear that maybe that 'cured mush' is lying?

If so - discuss the rules. A cured mush has two choices: To tell 100% full truth, or to tell nothing. Since your mush spoke, either they were not actually cured (but you say Chun confirmed the skill loss? And there's no counterclaim of transfer, right?), or there are no more mush, or that cured mush is breaking the rules.

So discuss the rules. There's no shame in having a rulebreaker ruin a game. If it happens, report and move on to your next game. You guys can discuss rules, make sure someone knows them, ask them 'so are you following the rules?', let them say yes - then trust them. If they lied to you twice, with the rules (and forum links! Give them proof that it's not just something you say - link mods saying it!) explained to them... the judges will find that a VERY easy report to decide a verdict on and will surely be picking a really high penalty to vote for too.

So sure, trust them. Help Chun understand the network of rules that protect her and the game, and she may be less aggressive about saving her ship from a possibly lying cured mush. If not, maybe you should help the girl. Ask her to explain to you what benefit Pheromodem has over your choices, why she thinks it is better for the ship, and if she's right - agree with her! If she's wrong, help her understand what she doesn't understand, in some nice, friendly, 'lets work together' sort of way.

Dzanek

She saved 24 AP and I adviced her to collect scrap as piloting is unlocked, she still wants me dead as a try to delay of making Pheromodem.

If she will not listen to you, she should hopefully listen to the whole crew agreeing that your idea is better (if they do agree).

[8200803]
Impet

For example, if you are with me on an Eden-capable ship, pilgred finished for days now, I've told everyone I want us to push for D33, and we need you to eat twice to help heal or something, and you don't want to, cause it might prove you? Bah. I might facepalm so hard I die from it, irl.

I think that's a very different situation than a straight "eat twice to prove you're human." I see nothing wrong with eating twice due to an imminent threat needing a quick, heavy response, but eating twice for the sole purpose of proving humanity is not something I approve of. This is, of course, something that not everyone is required to agree with me on, I'm simply stating that I sympathize with the idea of not eating twice in my understanding of this situation, because I would make the same choice.

[8709657]
PatrykSzczescieReally? I saw just inversely.

It's not directly against the rules to volunteer it, but it is against the spirit of the game imho.
On april 30, 2015
[6826491]
LokettaIt's not directly against the rules to volunteer it, but it is against the spirit of the game imho.

Volunteering to food test is not against the rules, unless it's being done in a way that is wasteful - a way that hurts the team.

Example: Someone consuming coffee and a ration every other cycle, but not actually spending AP on anything.

I had a Chun who did worse than that, though. She didn't heal anyone, helped maybe once with research, ate rations every other cycle, hogged the Medlab bed, and spent every AP she could on the Mad Kube.

In the opinions of some players, they feel it's against the spirit of the game. Fair enough. One should also bear in mind that when there's an imminent threat, a few AP can make a difference between countering that threat, or allowing the situation to be made worse. One should not hold any moral qualms about it, if doing so is going to immediately help the ship. (You can still choose a room where it doesn't leave a log, if that's a concern.
On april 30, 2015
[8709657]
Spazticus

Volunteering to food test is not against the rules, unless it's being done in a way that is wasteful - a way that hurts the team.

Example: Someone consuming coffee and a ration every other cycle, but not actually spending AP on anything.

I had a Chun who did worse than that, though. She didn't heal anyone, helped maybe once with research, ate rations every other cycle, hogged the Medlab bed, and spent every AP she could on the Mad Kube.

In the opinions of some players, they feel it's against the spirit of the game. Fair enough. One should also bear in mind that when there's an imminent threat, a few AP can make a difference between countering that threat, or allowing the situation to be made worse. One should not hold any moral qualms about it, if doing so is going to immediately help the ship. (You can still choose a room where it doesn't leave a log, if that's a concern.

I should have specified, I find it against the spirit of the game if it is for no reason other than proving humanity. When it's needed, its needed, no questions asked but that is usually only a few characters who can justify that (often pilots or tech) unless there is a rush on to make serum or maybe get the shields up.

And as always this is qualified as a personal opinion

On april 30, 2015
Kyubey

I should have specified, I find it against the spirit of the game if it is for no reason other than proving humanity.
Oh, those "anti-food-tests" people give me headache. Don't take it personally, but those who I remember are always like that:
1) Write a big post about how bad tests are and how they will never do them before selection
2) After selection do some stuff to be suspected - like spend 10 ap and get dirty as Paola to repair bridge-FBT door
3) Cry again how much you are against food tests, after being told, the stuff you did is really strange
4) Get killed/make all humans suspect and watch you, instead of finding real mushes

Personal opinions are welcome ofc, but "I decide not to make test, when my team wants it, just because I think it's against spirit of the game and I'm allowed to do that and I don't care if it makes game more difficult for my team" sounds like "I'll take just IT as human Janice, because I personally think that skill is not worse then Shrink and I don't care about opinions of others".
On april 30, 2015
Chime
Lokettaonly a few characters who can justify that (often pilots or tech)

That's pretty narrow minded. Give me a character and I'll find a reason to eat double, triple ... I'll eat quadruple if there are enough coffees around...

But Kyubey is right, the whole food test pro and contra stuff is loathsome, tiring and pointless. I have yet to meet someone how advocates the "Let's do food tests and leave big messages in the General Chat" thesis. Nobody doubts or denies the existence of these rather odd, often wasteful food tester but the whole discussion is done between the food-test-are-evil-period and depends-on-circumstances people. Usually both sides participants know very well that you can't force someone to eat double, can't prevent them from eat double and that you need more reason than a refused food test to kill someone. So it's pointless to go on and on about it or state in neutral play how one is against food tests. It's just reviving the damn thing. Let it die already.
